Ottawa, December 10th, 1926.

Sir,

This Department is informed by the Assistant Superintendent of Education for the Province of Nova Scotia that he has communicated with you in connection with the inspection of the Shubenacadie and Millbrook Indian Day Schools. The former is 5 miles from Shubenacadie and the latter 8½ miles from Truro.

By arrangement with the Provincial Department of Education, we allow $7.50 for each inspection plus actual travelling expenses from the nearest point on your regular inspection trip to the Indian school visited. Two inspections are made yearly — one in the spring and the other in the fall. Forms for making your report are enclosed; when forwarding reports you should also enclose an account in duplicate covering the cost of the inspection and your expenses.

In visiting Indian schools, you should pay particular attention to the academic qualifications of the teacher; the progress of the pupils, and offer recommendations concerning buildings or equipment with a view to making the instruction more attractive and efficient. It should be remembered that the teacher of an Indian day school is not directly responsible to the Public School Inspector, as Indian day schools are controlled and managed solely by this Department. However, a teacher is expected to carry out the instructions of the inspector in regard to the work and the general management of the school. You should feel at liberty to report to this Department any failure on the part of the teacher to carry out any suggestions made by you.

The appointment and dismissal of teachers rests solely with the Department of Indian Affairs. Recommendations from you in this connection, however, will receive consideration. The course of study prescribed by the Nova Scotia Department of Education should be followed as far as possible.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Perrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

W.C. Stapleton, Esq., M.S., Inspector of Schools,

Memorandum:

Mr. McNeil

It is desired that you have general supervision over the Department's educational work in your Inspectorate. You have already been given a list of the day schools in your Inspectorate, showing locality, names of teachers, salaries, etc. There was attached a statement, showing where Indian children are receiving tuition in white schools.

The Department is not satisfied that the Indian day schools are giving the best possible service. They have been under the supervision of the local Indian agents and are inspected semi-annually by provincial school inspectors. The provincial officers give advice to the teachers and make an independent report to the Department concerning their academic progress. It is your duty and that of the Indian agents to see that buildings and equipment are satisfactory and to improve the attendance and the general efficiency. Whenever you find that a teacher is not making the most of his or her opportunity, you should report to the Department.

It is particularly desired that you cooperate with the Indian agent in the matter of attendance. In the past, irregular schooling has militated against the success of our work. In this connection, you should give attention to the Indian children who are attending white schools as well as to our own institutions.

There is, at Shubenacadie, N.S., an Indian Residential School, recently established and about to be opened, for the benefit of the orphaned and neglected children of Nova Scotia and the Maritimes generally. You should visit this school from time to time, so that you will become acquainted with the work there and so that you will be able to assist our agents, at the outset with recruiting and later in the determination of those that should be granted admission. Preference will be given to those applicants for this school who are clearly wards of the Department and who are orphan or neglected. Favorable consideration will be given also to those applicants who live too far from any day school to attend regularly.

Duncan C. Scott
Deputy Superintendent General.

Sir:
I am enclosing herewith the Public School Inspector's report on the Indian Day school, along with his account for inspection and mileage.

Inspector McDonald of Antigonish is the only public inspector in my district who sends a report to me. He usually visits the schools twice a year. This expenditure amounts to $25.00 per year for one school. In this district there are eight Indian day schools and if the other schools are visited regularly by the Inspector, this would mean an expenditure of approximately $300.00 or over, for the year.

May I suggest that in future, the Inspector of Indian Agencies could do this work and send in a similar report without any extra charge to the Department. This is merely a suggestion and if you consider the saving worthwhile, I should think the experiment might be tried out for a year or two.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Ottawa, March 17, 1935.

Memo: Schools Branch,

The undersigned expects to make an inspection of all the Maritime Agencies and those in the Gaspe peninsula early in the Spring.

In order that the greatest possible benefit may result it is desirable that all matters requiring attention should be noted between now and the time of my departure, shortly after the 15th of April.

I will be pleased to gather any information, undertake any inquiry, or issue any instruction or advice that your branch may see fit to request of me.

Unless I am advised of specific cases requiring special attention an inspection is, per force, of a routine nature and I feel that the work of the inspection branch can be made of more value to the Department if the branches co-operate to this end by submitting memoranda on such matters as can be given personal attention by the inspecting officer.

I may add that I will be pleased to report, enroute, on any matter of urgent importance if so requested.

[Signature]

Inspector.

In cases where grade and rank do not correspond the lower whichever it may be is followed in determining license. Thus an applicant with second rank diploma and grade A1 or even grade XII scholarship would get only a second class license and the same license would be granted to one who has a grade I scholarship and a high rank diploma. Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

I am pleased to have your letter of the 21st inst. and shall endeavour to make clear to you the licensing and scholarship system of this province. One must bear in mind first that the term grade is used for scholarship, class for license and rank for professional training or its equivalent. In a few cases yet a teacher may obtain a license without attendance at the normal College. These cases are in regard to persons who are actually teaching or who have obtained degrees from colleges and make courses in education there. The table following will indicate the chief points of our system at a glance, corresponding values being opposite each other, the highest being academic and the lowest a grade IX scholarship and D license:

| Scholarship | License | Professional Training |
|-------------|---------|------------------------|
| Grade Academic | Class Academic or A | Rank Academic |
| " XII" | " Superior First or A" | " Superior First" |
| " XI" | " First or B" | " First" |
| " X" | " Second or C" | " Second" |
| " IX" | " Third or D" | " Third" |

The grade B certificate mentioned in your letter is a misuse of terms. It should be grade XI certificate. B and other letters refer properly to licenses and to nothing else. A second class license used to be obtainable by the holder of a grade A scholarship and second rank normal diploma but for one who did not hold a normal diploma a grade XI scholarship was necessary. Accordingly in your question the second class license and normal diploma would rank the same as a class C license and grade XI certificate. The latter would mean that the person concerned had not completed the regular course in training. An attempt is being made now to reduce the regular licenses henceforth to be granted to three classes, academic, Superior First and First or as they are often called, A, B, and C. For a long time of course we shall have teachers with both C and D licenses even though no new ones of these classes are issued. If this does not render the situation clear for you kindly let me know and I will make a further attempt at it.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

P.S. I should be very pleased to meet you if you happen to be down in these parts at any time. My brother, Maurice Phelan, has long been a resident of Ottawa. His home is 72 Driveway and he is employed as an engineer in the Department of Militia and Defence.
Deft. of Indian Affairs,

Dear Sir,

In a letter dated November 1st, 1926, Inspector J. A. Benoit advised the Department that the Whyccomagh Indian Day School was in his inspectorate and, consequently, he was advised that he could inspect it. He has done so since that time and his last visit was made on September 19th, 1935.

I am today in receipt of a letter from D. C. Fraser, Port Hood, N.S., requesting authority to visit the Whyccomagh School. Has Mr. Fraser succeeded Mr. Benoit? This Department does not wish to exercise any choice regarding inspectors and we are prepared to be guided by your wishes in connection with which one of your inspectors should visit this school.

Yours truly,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Sir:

I acknowledge communication No. 1-1-6 N.S. dated November 28th. from the Acting Supt. of Indian Education, with reference to the visitation of Whyccomagh Indian Day School. Mr. D. C. Fraser, Fort Hood, Nova Scotia, was appointed Inspector of Schools for Inverness County, in September 1935. Mr. J. A. Benoit is now Inspector for Richmond County. Hereafter, Mr. D. C. Fraser may cooperate with your department in the visitation of Whyccomagh Indian Day School.

I know that Mr. Fraser would readily understand that it had been customary for Mr. Benoit to visit this special school and indeed may continue to do so to the mutual satisfaction of himself and Inspector Fraser. Mr. Fraser may think it more convenient to have this school visited by Inspector Benoit, and the Department will raise no objection.

I am sending a copy of this letter both to Mr. Fraser and to Mr. Benoit, for their information. The Department suggests that Mr. Fraser, the Inspector for Inverness County, visit the Whyccomagh Indian Day School on behalf of the Department of Indian Affairs.

Very truly yours,

H. R. Shinner,
Asst. Supt. of Education.
Ottawa, December 5, 1935.

Dear Sir:

On receipt of your recent letter in connection with the inspection of the Whyceosagh Indian Day School, the Department wrote the Superintendent of Education, Halifax. In his reply, he states that he has written both to you and to Mr. Benoit, who has been inspecting this school for the past nine years. His last inspection was on September 19th, last.

I understand that you have also received a copy of Mr. Shinner's letter dated the 2nd instant. Please let me know whether Mr. Benoit or yourself will inspect the Whyceosagh School in future.

This Department allows $7.50 for each inspection, plus travelling expenses, from the nearest point on your regular inspection trip. Accounts, covering the cost of the inspection and expenses, should be forwarded in triplicate. One inspection should be made during the Fall and the other in the Spring.

Yours truly,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Rev. Father,

We, the undersigned teachers of the Indian Day Schools of Inverness County, Nova Scotia, beg to ask if it is possible to have our schools visited and inspected by the newly appointed Inspector D.C. Fraser instead of Inspector J.A. Benoit. In asking this we assure you that we have no feelings of any kind against Inspector Benoit and give the following reasons for our request;

Inspector Fraser lives in Inverness County and much nearer to us than Inspector Benoit who lives in Richmond County. On his regular inspection tours of "white" schools he is often in the near vicinity of our schools and we feel that frequent and easy communication with him would be of much assistance to us and our school work. It is about impossible for us to have Inspector Benoit visit our schools oftener than twice a year on account of his regular district of inspection being in another county. Since his appointment a few years ago, Inspector Fraser has organized many new clubs, teachers' meetings etc., and we do not feel like taking part as we are not of "his flock". Last year he visited our schools and asked if we would wish to contribute to the school exhibits we were sending to the Provincial Exhibition at Halifax. We agreed and the result was that the exhibits of basketry and school work sent by your pupils were awarded First and Second prizes and that from ALL schools in the county who took part. We think Fraser to direct and instruct us we can take a still more active part this year and we would feel bolder in asking for his assistance and taking part in the many new and beneficial undertakings he is so successfully carrying out in the schools he supervises.

As previously stated, we have no ill feelings against Inspector Benoit and know that he is equally active in his own county but it is impossible for either he or us to carry out matters as above on account of the distance which separates us.

Yours truly,

Alexander MacDonald, Teacher,
Whydooomagh Indian Day School.

Colin Kennedy, Teacher,
Malagawatch Indian Day School.

Dear Doctor Munro:

The records here indicate that by an agreement reached between the Department of Indian Affairs and the Department of Education of Nova Scotia, the Indian schools of Nova Scotia have been inspected twice annually by our inspectors from year to year. This arrangement has always been satisfactory to the officials charged with the administration of Indian day and residential schools.

I regret to state, however, that in the preparation of our estimates this year it was not possible to include an appropriation greater than the amount necessary to provide for one inspection per classroom per annum of our Indian schools throughout the Dominion. This decision was reached in an attempt to conserve public funds in this period of national crisis and to keep our expenditures down to the lowest possible figure. The amount involved in the inspection of our schools in the province of Nova Scotia, of course, is comparatively small and I am hoping that you can make the necessary adjustment without inconvenience to your inspectors. It is very desirable, in my judgment, that our policy should be uniform throughout the Dominion.

Yours very sincerely,

R. A. Hosy,

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 4th instant in which you advise that you are acting in place of Inspector Macdonald.

The only Indian day school in your County is known as the Afton Day School. All Inspectors were notified last May that the Department would only have funds available for one inspection of Indian day schools during the academic year 1940-41. Consequently there will be no funds available for the inspection of the Afton School between September 1, 1940, and March 31, 1941. However, the Department would appreciate your inspecting this school between April 1 and June 30, 1941, and following your inspection you should forward your report on the form provided for that purpose. A supply of these is enclosed.

By arrangement with the Provincial Department of Education we allow $7.50 for each inspection plus actual travelling expenses from the nearest point on your regular inspection trip to the Indian school visited. When forwarding the report you should enclose an account in triplicate covering your inspection fee and your expenses. Receipts should be attached for the latter.

When visiting the school you should pay particular attention to the academic qualifications of the teacher and the progress of the pupils and offer recommendations with a view to making the instruction more attractive and efficient. Special attention should be given to vocational training as we wish to make the instruction in Indian schools as practical as possible.

Mr. Alexander Laidlaw,
Inspector of Schools,
Antigonish, N. S.
It should be remembered that the teacher of an Indian day school is not directly responsible to the Public School Inspector as Indian day schools are controlled and managed solely by this Department. However, a teacher is expected to carry out the instructions of the Inspector in regard to the work and the general management of the school. You should feel at liberty to report any failure on the part of the teacher to carry out any reasonable suggestion made by you. The appointment and dismissal of teachers rests solely with the Indian Affairs Branch. Recommendations from you in this connection will, however, receive consideration.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Mr. Neary:

This is to acknowledge your letter of December 9th, with respect to the remuneration of our Inspectors for carrying out inspection of Indian schools in this province.

I suppose that one should not be too critical, but it seems to me that the amount of $7.50 that you propose for each inspection report is an exceedingly low sum for professional work of this type. I would say that the amount should be at least double the $7.50. Ordinarily, it would take one of our Inspectors one full day to inspect the Indian School and prepare a report. You surely do not think that our Inspectors work for $7.50 a day. It is quite true they will be paid by us for this time, but as a matter of principle I think the professional fee should at least approximate the salary of the person doing the work for the time spent.

I appreciate your difficulties and I am not asking for a revision, but simply I am expressing my personal view.

Very truly yours,

H.P. Morissette

SCHOOL YEAR 1916-1917
COWANNSVILLE, Que., 30th June, 1917.

Sir,

I have the honor to submit my annual report for the year just closed, 1916-17.

Territory.—My district of inspection extends over the counties of Huntingdon, Beauharnois, Chateauguay, Soulanges, Vaudreuil, Napierville, Laprairie, Richelieu, Chambly and part of St. Johns and Missisquoi.

Buildings.—The buildings and outhouses are good and in a good state of repair.

The schoolhouses are all equipped with modern furniture. The school grounds are fairly well kept but more should be done to make them more attractive and the walks and approaches more like those of our homes. Generally, school grounds in this province are neglected. Not alone in my district but in every district.

Visits and examinations.—All the schools of my district were visited during the autumn months and again during the second half year.

Oral and written examinations were conducted and the standing of each school noted and reported to this school board.

Some of the school boards met at the time of my visits and matters of importance were discussed and settled.

Nature study.—Nature study now forms part of the authorized course and is not being neglected by the teachers. In fact it is becoming quite popular in all the schools.

Agriculture is also taught in all the schools of my district; owing to a crowded curriculum, time does not permit of more than two or three
lessons per week in this important subject. However progress is being made and very careful work is being done and especially by the recent graduates of Macdonald college.

The salaries.—No very marked change has taken place during the year in the salaries paid to teachers, as last year, they range from $30 to $50 per month.

French in schools.—Special attention is being given to the teaching of French, about half of the teachers are employing the natural method and much better progress is manifest in such schools.—Recent graduates find no difficulty in teaching by this method, but such teachers as have not had the opportunity of Normal training find it difficult and pursue the old method. Consequently theory and not practice follows; pupils do not speak any French in such schools.

Classification.—I have followed closely the regulations, in making the following classification.

Excellent.—Howick, St. Malachie d'Ornstown, Beauharnois, Godmanchester, Hinchinbrooke, Nelson Junction, Franklin, Greenfield Park, Montreal South, Elgin, St. Lazare, Dundee, Havelock, and the Indian Schools at St. Régis Reserve.

Good.—Henningford, St. Louis de Gonzague, Lacolle, St. George, St. Thomas, St. Hubert, St. Regis, Como, St. Anleet.

Medium.—St. Justine de Newton, Richelieu, St. Chrysostome, Chamby Canton, Laprairie, St. Margaret de Blairfindie, St. Téléphore, Pinehurst, Coteau Junction.

Unsatisfactory.—St. Constant, St. Urbain.

Conferences.—The regular annual conferences were held during the month of September. Inspector General Sutherland assisted me at Huntingdon, forty-three teachers were present at this meeting; all the
teachers of my district attend the conferences. Some of the local clergymen also attend and a few of the commissioners make an effort to do so. Usually the principals of the academies and model schools take part in the meetings.

The course of study is closely followed in all the schools of my districts. Drawing is fairly well taught but only one lesson a week is all we find time to devote to the subject. During the second half year, two lessons per week are allowed. Some model work and a little sand moulding and relief work are attempted.

Music is neglected in nearly all the elementary rural schools. Singing hymns and national songs form part of our opening exercises, but the theory of elementary music is not generally taught.

Loyalty.—Before I close my annual report I desire to call your attention to the fact that the elementary schools of this district, from the teachers to oldest and youngest pupils, from the sturdy youth, longing to reach the required military age to the little tots, just able to wave the Union Jack, are at war with the Empire against Prussianism and frightfulness. Every school has contributed to the Red Cross fund; teachers and pupils are knitting for the soldiers, the girls and boys are sending boxes to their brothers at the front, nearly every teacher and pupil is directly interested. We were never more loyal to our King and Empire.
This report, together with the bulletins of inspection, pensioners, lists, and special reports previously forwarded to your office, is respectfully submitted.

ADDITIONAL REPORT.

In addition to my regular duties I visited and reported to the Department during the year, the schools of the following municipalities: St. Paul de Chester West and Tingwick, of the county of Arthabaska; Drummondville, Durham Township, South Durham, Kingsey Falls and St. Pierre de Durham, of the county of Drummond; Shipton and Asbestos county of Richmond.

During the time of my visits and since, I have sent complete reports of my visits of inspection to the commissioners and trustees of the several municipalities, bulletins and statistical reports to the Department of Public Instruction and reports of the standing of the several schools to the teachers. I was pleased with the cooperation of the commissioners and secretaries of the different municipalities, all of whom received my recommendations in the most friendly manner. The chairman, secretary and some of the commissioners of the municipality of Shipton, accompanied me to the several schools of the municipality, besides furnishing prizes for the leaders of the different classes. They manifested a lively interest in the competition which the pupils offered in the several subjects of the course of study. Although the English schools are gradually becoming more and more sparsely attended in this inspectorate, it is apparent that the interest is not diminishing. The pupils and teachers are healthy and strong, physically and mentally. I noticed that excellent progress is being made in the different grades and especially in mental arithmetic. Other school boards should follow the example of the commissioners of Shipton and make the annual visit and examination of the inspector more prominent. It would pay.

The buildings of this inspectorate as far as I saw them are only medium in comparison with those of other inspectorates which I have visited, but they are neatly kept and are fairly warmed and lighted. But they are not modern in appearance. The course of study is followed rigidly in all the schools.
There is no change in the ranking of the municipalities since last year. In my quarter of the inspectorate there is only one modern school house, viz Drummondville, which may be ranked as excellent.

My dear Mr. Deputy,

It gives me pleasure to inform you that the Schools, which had been closed since October 10th on account of Spanish Influenza, reopened on November 12th with a fairly good attendance, considering the conditions which exist here at this season. A number of families have moved to Lachine, others have gone to Toronto, and some children are still at home on account of illness. It is, however, impossible to state just yet how many children will remain on the Reserve during the winter.

Early in September we were informed that a change had been under consideration regarding the inspection of the Reserve Schools, and we subsequently learned that an English speaking Inspector had been appointed. Judging from a conversation with Mr. Benson, as well as from other information, I am inclined to think the Inspector in question, while meeting all the educational requirements, is not a Roman Catholic, and I am told that it is the policy of the Department to give to each denomination, Teachers and Inspectors of their own faith. Not being familiar with the system of education in this country, I consulted His Grace, the Archbishop of Montreal, on this matter, and he advised me to call your kind attention to the fact, stating that the selection had probably been made without taking this point into consideration. It may be too, that the scarcity of English speaking Inspectors in the Province of Quebec, would have also been a determining factor, but if you would allow me to suggest the name of Mr. Thomas Gudhiy of 1850 Delormier Ave., Montreal, Inspector of the Montreal Schools, you would secure the service of a gentleman

Dear Madam,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 15th instant, in reference to the inspection of the Caughnawaga schools.

In reply I would state that Mr. Gilman was appointed to undertake this work by the Department of Public Instruction for the Province of Quebec within whose present district the reserve is situated. MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

Several of the Public School Inspectors in Quebec and the Eastern Provinces have recently made protests against the amount of fees allowed them for their inspection of the Indian day schools.

In the Province of Nova Scotia by Order in Council dated the 23rd of November, 1882, the remuneration allowed the inspectors for this work was fixed at $5.00 per visit, with actual travelling expenses from the nearest point of their regular route of inspection.

In Quebec an agreement was entered into about thirty-five years ago with the government of the province with reference to the subject of securing to the Indian schools of that province the same system of inspection at the hands of the government officers as the public schools there enjoyed and this arrangement is still in existence. The fee allowed is $5.00 for each classroom visited, together with the actual travelling expenses from the nearest point on their regular route of inspection.

In Prince Edward Island the same fee is allowed the public school inspector as in the case of the two above named provinces. I have been unable to find the agreement made with the Department of Education for that province for the utilization of the services of its inspectors in the inspection of the Indian school at Lennox Island.

In the Province of New Brunswick we have our own inspector.

As the fees allowed the inspectors have remained at the same rate for the past thirty-five years and the inspectors receive a higher rate for the inspection of the white schools in their
their inspectorates, I consider that the time has arrived when we should increase the fees which pay them. I, therefore, beg to recommend that a 50% increase, at least, be granted from the first of the new year, namely, January 1st, 1921. This would allow a fee of $7.50 for the inspection of each class-room and the expenses of the inspectors should also be paid, as at present. The cost of this increase, taking into account that two inspections are made each year, would be as follows:

Nova Scotia, 11 schools, increase for 2 inspections at $2.50 each would be $55.00
Prince Edward Island, 2 schools, increase for 2 inspections at $2.50 each would be $10.00
Quebec, 24 schools with a total of 32 class-rooms, increase for 2 inspections at $2.50 each would be $160.00

This would make a total increase for the three provinces of $225.00 per annum.

I consider that we receive good value from these inspections and from the reports received from the inspectors and I would beg to place before you for your consideration the granting of an increase in the fees allowed.

MEMORANDUM FOR FILE

About 1885 an arrangement was made with the Ontario Department of Education for the inspection of the Indian schools. It was agreed that the remuneration paid to the inspectors would be at the rate of $6.00 per room, plus the actual travelling expenses from the nearest point on their regular route. This arrangement obtains today. Inspections are made semi-annually.

In Quebec and the Maritime Provinces an arrangement was made in 1888 with the Departments of Education on similar lines as for Ontario. The rate of remuneration was $6.00 per room plus expenses. Since January 1, 1921, in Quebec and the Maritime Provinces the inspectors have received $7.50 per room plus expenses. Inspections are made semi-annually.

Arrangements have been concluded this year with the Prairie Provinces. In Manitoba we have agreed to pay the inspectors at the rate of $15.00 per classroom plus expenses. In Saskatchewan and Alberta a flat rate of $20.00 per school is being charged for one inspection per year. In the case of the last two provinces, no allowances are made in connection with expenses.

When an inspector visits an Indian school, he should pay particular attention to the academic qualifications of the teacher and the progress of the pupils and should offer recommendations as to how the service can be improved. May I add, some four years ago while inspecting the Caughnawaga schools with the late Superintendent Mr. Ferrier, I spoke to him of my intention of resigning and he asked me not to think of it. During the two days he spent with me he found I gave ample time owing to my methods and system.

DOCTOR MCGILL.

It is my intention, subject to your approval, to complete arrangements with Mr. Doucet whereby he will visit the Maria, Restigouche, Pierreville and Caughnawaga Indian Day Schools during the last week in November and the first two weeks in December.

We have, as you know, new Indian day schools at Restigouche and Maria, and in these schools provision has been made for the space necessary to provide instruction in manual training, native crafts and elementary domestic science. It is my hope that Mr. Doucet, at the time of his visit, will be able to work out a worthwhile practical course with the teachers in charge of these schools.

Mr. Doucet, you may remember, visited Caughnawaga about a month or 6 weeks ago. At that time he outlined a practical course to be followed at the Caughnawaga schools. The purpose of the second visit is to make a close check on the extent to which the teachers have followed his advice and also on the progress that has been made by the pupils.

I have also asked Mr. Doucet to visit the Quebec Department of Education at Quebec City. It is my hope that he will be able to discuss with the officials there the courses of study that we are seeking to provide at Indian day schools and in this way avoid any misunderstanding that might arise between the educational policy that has been promoted by this Branch and the educational policy usually insisted upon by the provincial inspectors.

Mr. Doucet will leave Ottawa on Tuesday November 25.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

I am pleased to learn from your letter of the 26th instant, that arrangements are being made to provide assistance for Mrs. White so that she might give greater time than was available previously to the Sr. Grades, in particular.

While I am on the Cornwall High School Entrance Board and while I shall be pleased to champion the cause of the High School Entrance Candidates from the Cornwall Island (West) Indian School, you will understand that a reasonable foundation is expected if the student is to succeed later in High School.

While I have suggested previously, as temporary measures, the engagement of an assistant in the same classroom with Mrs. White, or the transportation of the Senior pupils to the East End School where teaching time is more adequate; I note from your letter that a study by an official of the Indian Affairs Branch has revealed that the overcrowding is likely to be of a permanent nature.

In such a case, I beg leave to suggest that a new one-room school be erected, approximately mid-way between the present two schools. If a suitable site can be secured with at least 5 acres of good soil for agricultural purposes. I would suggest that the Senior pupils, and preferably Grades IX and X as well from the whole Island should attend this Central School, where Shop Work and Agriculture might form a more vital place in the education of many children. At the present time, comparatively few pupils reach the Sr. Grades and even fewer are interested in proceeding to High School at the Cornwall Collegiate.

I shall be glad to be of any further assistance.

Yours sincerely,

Sir:

I have the honour to submit the report of my annual inspection visit to the schools of the Caughnawaga Reserve.

As you may see by the accompanying reports on the individual classes, I found the general progress very satisfactory.

The Principal, Sister M. Albertus, seems to be very active in the administration of the schools and in the supervision of the classes. She spends half of each school day in the Eastern School and the other half in the Kateri School. That her supervision of the teaching is constant and vigilant is evident from her knowledge of the progress of the classes and of the individual pupils.

The general behaviour of the pupils seems to be very good. I believe that there are few cases of bad conduct. The pupils are polite and friendly in their attitude towards a visitor. Their oral language shows constant improvement.

The schoolrooms are clean and orderly. They have been made as attractive and as comfortable as possible. There is no point in mentioning the lack of blackboard space in some of the temporary rooms, or the lack of light in some of the others. This will be remedied by the building of a new schoolhouse, which, I understand, will be undertaken in the near future.

During my visit, I inspected the woodworking shop and the household science room. Some interesting and useful articles have been made. The pupils' interest in the activities of these departments is even greater than in previous years.

Inspector of schools.

Sir:

I have the honour to submit the report of my annual inspection visit to the schools of the St. Regis Reserve.

The accompanying reports on the individual classes will show that generally the general progress is good. I regret to say, however, that there is not sufficient progress in the Chetlain School.

It was very gratifying to learn that the boys of the Village School are being initiated into the art of woodworking and the girls, into elementary household science. It was also a pleasure to see that a piano has been added to the equipment of this same school. This instrument has been used to advantage. The pupils sing very well to the accompaniment of one of the teachers.

I was greatly impressed by the improved attendance. The officers of the Welfare and Training Division, the local Indian Agent, and the teachers all deserve praise for their share in this improvement.

I was very pleased to learn that four of the girls who graduated from the Village School last year were successful in obtaining high school entrance. This and the fact that some of these girls are now studying in high school with a grant from your Division may be responsible for the revived interest in the Senior Class of the Village School.

The Indian Agent, Mr. T. L. Bonnah, takes an active interest in the welfare of the pupils. His help is greatly appreciated by the teachers.

I wish to thank Mr. Bonnah, the teachers, as well as the R.C.M.P. constables for their kindness and courtesy to me during my inspection visit.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I have the honour to submit my report on my visit to the schools of the St. Regis Agency.

As will be seen by the individual reports, the general progress is satisfactory.

I made two visits to the St. Regis schools in the school year 1947-48. My first visit took place on November 13th. My principal purpose was to visit the Chetlain School, in order to stimulate and encourage the teacher and pupils. It will be remembered that the progress of the pupils of the Chetlain School was unsatisfactory in the year 1946-47. I also made short visits to the Chenail and Village schools. I did not visit the St. Regis Island School at this time.

General Remarks:

Village School: The progress of the two rooms of this school is worthy of special mention. The teachers' lessons are well planned. The pupils are active and orderly. The pupils' progress is particularly noticeable in oral English.

St. Regis Island School: Good work is being done by the teachers of this school. Her pupils are making progress in all subjects.

Chenail School: The teacher of this school deserves praise for her earnestness and enthusiasm. She is doing good work and her pupils are making progress. If she had the opportunity of teaching side by side with an experienced and sympathetic teacher, she would, I believe, become a very skilful teacher.

Chetlain School: I must regretfully state that the pupils of this school have not made satisfactory progress.
The teacher seems to lack enthusiasm and she has not been able to gain the interest and attention of her pupils.

The new schoolhouse which has been built to replace the Chatelain and Chenail schools is, if I may judge by the exterior, a model rural school. It should be a great boon to the people of this district.

It may be presumed that you are already considering the building of a new schoolhouse to replace the present village school. The present building is not adequate for the excellent school program, including the manual arts, which you are trying to implement in your schools.

I respectfully suggest that, when you plan a new building for St. Regis Village, you study the possibility of transporting the children of St. Regis Island to and from the future Village School. The children of the Island could be transported by boat in the autumn and in the spring, by sleigh in winter. There would be only a few days at the beginning and at the end of winter when one or the other of these means of transportation could not be used.

This suggestion, of course, is based on my own opinion. The feasibility of such a project would have to be studied by the local superintendent and others who know the situation at first hand.

The cost of transporting the pupils would be offset by many advantages, both educational and financial. The pupils would have all the benefits of the educational activities that you are endeavouring to provide for the Indian children. It would no longer be necessary to provide a teacher and a teacher's living quarters and a schoolhouse for an average enrolment of twelve pupils. It may be noted that the present schoolhouse on the Island is in need of repair or replacement.

During my visit to St. Regis Village, I examined the woodwork done by the boys under the direction of Mr. Chisholm. I was very favourably impressed. The boys were proud to show me their work, which gave evidence of ingenuity and originality. Mr. Chisholm deserves praise for his initiative and for his enthusiastic guidance.

Sir:

I have the honour to submit the report on my visit to the schools of the Saint Regis Agency.

As may be seen by the reports on the individual classroom teachers, the good work reported last year has been continued and improved.

General Remarks:

Village School
The progress of the pupils in this school continues to be very satisfactory. I noted even greater improvement in the Senior Room during the current year.

The pupils of this school have broadened much during the past few years. They are much freer and much more friendly. They are eager to answer and they express themselves in good, simple English. It is a pleasure, not a task, to get them to render an account of what they have learned.

I was particularly pleased to hear the pupils of this school render several songs. Their rendition was very good. Such activities are a very useful part of training.

Saint Regis Island School
In my report of last year, I suggested that, whenever the present village school should be replaced by a new schoolhouse, a study should be made of the feasibility of transporting the children from the Island to the Village School. I need not repeat this suggestion. I only wish to say that the benefits already derived from the central Chenail School seem to show the desirability of further centralization.

Chenail School
I wish to congratulate the Department of Mines and Resources for providing this new schoolhouse for the children.
of this district. The building of this school has already improved the attitude of the pupils. These children no longer appear backward, as they did in previous years. I was particularly pleased to see the spacious playground behind the schoolhouse and to observe the boys playing lacrosse during recess. This school will be of benefit to the entire community.

Mr. Colin Chisholm has continued his good work in initiating the boys in manual training. He has also done much to encourage them in sports.

The Superintendent of the Saint Regis Agency, Mr. T. L. Bonnah, deserves praise for the active interest that he takes in the welfare of the schoolchildren and in the progress of their education. His successful campaign for regular school attendance is worthy of special mention.

MEMORANDUM.

I am of opinion that the time has arrived when the inspection of the Indian schools in the provinces of Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta should, if possible, be placed in the hands of the public school inspectors of these provinces, as it is the aim of the Department to have the teachers in our Indian schools conform with the public school curriculum. I consider that the public school inspectors are better fitted to see that the wishes of the Department in this direction are carried out than our agency inspectors, who have neither the requisite time nor the pedagogical training to properly conduct this work.

I would, therefore, respectfully suggest that I be authorized to open up negotiations with the local governments of these provinces with the object of securing to the Indian schools the same system of inspection by the hands of local officers as the public schools in the provinces undergo, and to make the most economical arrangements possible in regard to the compensation to be made to the local officials for their services in that behalf.
Memorandum - Mr. Scott.

In connection with the memorandum of the 10th instant in regard to the proposed inspection of Indian schools in the provinces of Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta I beg to say that the inspection of the Indian schools in Ontario Quebec and the Maritime Provinces was, by mutual arrangement entered into between the Dominion and provincial governments about thirty-five years ago, placed in the hands of the provincial inspectors, who were authorized to make semi-annual visits of inspection to Indian schools within or near their districts. The inspectors were to furnish a report after every inspection, which should, besides describing the condition of the school and the progress made by the pupils, contain suggestions and recommendations relative to the future management of the school which may seem to the inspector advisable and proper to make.

As the curriculum followed in our Indian schools should, as nearly as possible, conform to the course of studies in the public schools, the provincial inspectors are the proper persons to perform this duty.

As the majority of the Indian schools in the provinces of Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta are denominational the different churches engaged in missionary and educational work have been allowed the privilege of nominating teachers, many of whom have not the required professional qualifications. If the schools are placed under the provincial inspectors, the Department would be in a position to consult them regarding future appointments.

The inspectors in the older provinces are allowed a fixed rate for each inspection of $6.00 in Ontario and $5.00 in the other provinces, with actual travelling expenses from the nearest point on their regular inspection trip. As these fees were fixed so many years ago it may be necessary to increase them. This would be a matter of adjustment with the different provincial educational departments.

Hon. Mr. Meighen,

Some 35 years ago the inspection of the Indian schools, both day and industrial, in Ontario and Quebec and the Maritime Provinces was placed in the hands of the Provincial school inspectors, pursuant to an agreement entered into by the Department of Indian Affairs with the respective local Governments. This arrangement is still in effect, except in the province of New Brunswick, where, as in the case of British Columbia, we have an Inspector appointed by the Department.

In the Western Provinces of Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta the inspection of the schools is made by our departmental inspectors who, as you may be aware, have no pedagogical qualifications, and whose examination of the classroom work is, of necessity, very perfunctory.

I am of opinion, and in this I am supported by some of the more prominent people engaged in the Indian educational work, that the time is opportune to place the inspection in these three provinces also in the hands of the Provincial Inspectors. There have been complaints from many sources that the classroom work in some of our schools is neglected. There are frequent changes of teachers, and a consequent lack of uniformity in teaching methods. Our aim is to have the course in our Indian schools conform as closely as possible to the curriculum in the public schools of the districts in which they are situated, and the only means of attaining this end is by
having the work under the supervision, and, to some extent, the direction of the Provincial Inspectors.

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,-

Re. inspection of Indian schools in the Provinces of Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta.

With a view to utilizing the services of the provincial school inspectors in each of the above provinces the respective Ministers of Education for each was written to in July, last, to obtain their co-operation and in order to ascertain the probable approximate cost, if such an arrangement were put into effect. The object of such a visitation is to have the course of study in our Indian schools conform as closely as possible to the curriculum of the white schools of the districts in which they are situated. Lists of the schools in each province (day, boarding and industrial) showing agency and reserve on which located and nearest post office address and distance from school were requested and sent. Replies have now been received from the Deputy Minister of Education for each province, which, briefly summarized, are as follows,-

MANITOBA

Mr. R. Fletcher, Deputy Minister, states that they will be willing to undertake the inspection of the Indian schools which are readily accessible on the basis of $15.00 for each visit, together with the expenses incurred in travelling to and from the schools, the understanding that the schools will be inspected then their inspectors are in the neighbourhood on their usual visit of inspection. Regarding the schools in the remote districts, he states that they will provide men to make an annual inspection on a basis of salary and expenses for the time taken, the amount to be mutually agreed upon. There are 20 day schools, 5 boarding and 1 industrial which can be classed as accessible. The cost of their inspection, one inspection per year only, which does not include travelling expenses, is approximately...
mately as follows:

20 day schools, 1 class-room each, @ $15.00 = $300.00
6 boarding schools, 2 class-rooms each, @ $15.00 = $180.00
1 industrial school, 2 class-rooms, @ $15.00 = $30.00

This does not provide for two boarding schools (Norway House and Cross Lake) and 16 day schools which are located in northern Manitoba and for which special terms would have to be agreed upon. It is not possible to estimate the travelling expenses that would be required, as until one visit is made in each case the time taken will not be known.

SASKATCHEWAN

Mr. Augustus H. Ball, Deputy Minister, took up the matter of the inspection of our schools with the provincial inspectors in whose inspectorates the schools are located and forwards a memorandum from the replies received by him. There is considerable variation in the method of arriving at the remuneration and travelling allowances by the different inspectors. The majority of the inspectors, however, will do the work at the regular departmental rate allowed for travelling of $6.00 per day and $10.00 per class-room for inspection and report. In the outlying districts, north of Township 55, it will be necessary to arrange with the individual inspectors as to travelling allowances. There are 19 day schools, 15 of which can be termed as accessible, 11 boarding (9 accessible) and 1 industrial in the province. The cost of inspection of the basis of the terms submitted, one inspection each year, would be approximately as follows:

15 day schools, 1 room each, at $10.00 each = $150.00
9 boarding schools, 2 rooms each, at $10.00 each = $180.00
1 industrial school, 4 class-rooms, at $10.00 = $40.00

Besides, the time occupied in travelling, including living expenses, would be $6.00 per day. I do not think it is possible to estimate the time that would be taken nor to make an approximation of the expenditure required for this purpose until after the inspectors have made their first visits.

ALBERTA.

Mr. J. T. Ross, Deputy Minister, states that the inspectors will undertake the inspection of the one-roomed schools once each year for $25.00 each and the two-roomed schools (residential) for $40.00 per year each and furnish reports on the work.
work being done in the class-rooms. This would include travelling expenses. As there is a difference in the amounts asked by the different provinces, I would suggest that a flat rate covering the cost of inspection and travelling expenses be offered by this Department, a larger sum being offered in the case of the residential schools than in that of the day schools. It appears to me that the offer submitted by the Province of Alberta is the most reasonable, namely, $25.00 for each day school and $40.00 for each residential school. One inspection a year should be sufficient and only the schools situated in what is termed accessible localities should be inspected. Later on terms could be arranged for the inspection of the outlying schools. If the provinces would agree to the above terms the cost of the inspection of all the Indian schools therein in the readily accessible class would be approximately $2,500.00 per year. Deputy Supt. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Can.

Dear Sir,

For a number of years it has been evident to those giving close attention to Indian education, that the class rooms of Indian schools did not receive proper inspection. You will agree with me I am sure that this is a very necessary matter in order that the teachers in the schools receive that sympathetic guidance and incentive that they need in order that the best work be done. At present, as you are aware the Indian Agents are instructed to visit the schools once a month and the Inspectors of Schools about once a week. To many of them this is not previous experience or training which fits them to do this work in a way that is of much value. Several of these men have expressed great dislike for this part of their work, simply because they felt they were not qualified to do what should be done. Most of them regard it as a somewhat unimportant side line of their many duties and it is passed over in a merely perfunctory manner. Do not think I am finding any fault with any of these officials, for I regard this condition as a natural result of men being asked to perform duties for which they are not qualified.

The time has come when Indians on many reserves are taking much more interest in the education of their children and will demand better work in the schools. This attitude will be much accentuated by the return of large numbers of the younger men from the battlefields of France. They will come back with new and wider ideas of the world and the schools will have to move forward to meet their ideas of what is fitting.

In view of the foregoing conditions, at the recent meeting of the Presbyterian Synod of Saskatchewan, held in the city of Moose Jaw I introduced and secured the unanimous passing of a resolution asking the Department of Education of Saskatchewan to confer with the Department of Indian Affairs with a view to having the class rooms of our Indian Schools inspected by the Public School Inspectors of the Province, in whose districts these schools happen to be. This would tend to bring the Indian children under the same system as the other children of the Province, and would be a force working for the ultimate good of the Indians. This would be by far the best substitute for the present system but if this could, for any reason not be carried out then I suggested as an alternative that a suitable number of inspectors specially fitted for the work be appointed by the Indian Department. These changes should of course apply to all Indian schools receiving Government support.

Know that you are especially interested in this branch of Indian work I commend this question to your consideration. I should be pleased to hear from you at your convenience as to what you think of the proposition.

I Am,

Yours Respectfully,

[Signature]

Memorandum.

Mr. Scott:

Re: Inspection of Indian Schools in the Provinces of Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta.

With a view to maintaining public school standards in the classrooms of our Indian schools of the Prairie Provinces, this Department has had further correspondence with the Deputy Ministers of Education for Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta. A list of the schools, the inspection of which is desired, was submitted to each Provincial Department and the cost of securing the services of the staffs of inspectors was inquired into. Replies have now been received from the Deputy Ministers of Education, and bases have been prepared, upon which definite arrangements can be made when the necessary authority has been obtained from the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.

In Manitoba we are to make arrangements direct with the staff of inspectors. They have been approached and are willing to inspect 19 day and 7 residential schools for a remuneration of $15.00 and expenses for each visit to a school. My estimate for the Manitoba expenditure is $700.00. I have the addresses of the inspectors and a list of the schools each will inspect.

The Saskatchewan Department of Education have offered to supervise for us the inspection of the Indian schools in that Province. They will add to their present list of public schools, the Indian schools the inspection of which is desired. Inspectors' reports will be made in duplicate and one copy forwarded by the Regina office to Ottawa with the comments of their Chief Inspector. One payment per annum would be made to the Saskatchewan Department of Education, on the basis of a flat rate of $20.00 for day schools and $35.00 for residential schools. The cost for such inspection would be $710.00.

The proposed arrangement with the Alberta Department of Education is identical with that mentioned above for the Province of Saskatchewan, with the exception that we have not been offered any comments on the inspectors' reports. The expenditure involved at the flat rate of $20.00 for each day and $35.00 for each residential school would be $530.00.

- It will be noted -
It will be noted that the total expenditure for the inspection of 46 day and 27 residential schools in the three provinces will be slightly less than $2,000. An item has been placed in the 1922-23 Estimates to cover this expenditure. In each province, certain schools that are remote from the lines of communication have been omitted from the lists offered to the Provincial Departments.

At present, agents and inspectors of agencies visit the Indian schools at more or less regular intervals. There is a real need for an academic supervision that our staff in the field are unable to offer.

The proposed arrangement is that the public school inspectors will visit the Indian schools mentioned once a year when they are in the vicinity, and the expenses for which we are responsible (Manitoba) will be kept at a minimum. Inspectors will be informed that it is our aim to maintain public school standards in the classrooms of Indian schools and we will ask them to supervise classroom activities and related matters only. The confidential report of outside-trained public school inspectors will be of infinite value to this Department in our effort to make successful our educational work among the Prairie Province Indian children.

In June 1920, the Honorable the Superintendent General approved of a similar scheme but requested that you did not commit the Department of Indian Affairs in the matter for the time being.

I beg to recommend that the Superintendent General be approached with a view to having this proposed plan put into effect in the immediate future.

Memorandum:

Hon. Charles Stewart.

Supervision of the classroom activities in Indian schools in Ontario, Quebec and the Maritime Provinces was placed, nearly 40 years ago, in the hands of the provincial public school inspectors, following agreements entered into by this Department with the Provincial Governments. The arrangement still obtains, except in the Province of New Brunswick, where we have a Department inspector possessing the necessary academic qualifications. In British Columbia, also, we have an Inspector of Indian Schools.

In the Provinces of Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta our Indian schools are visited by our agents and by the inspectors of agencies, who are, of course, not specifically qualified to make other than perfunctory inspections of the academic activities. It is desired that the pedagogy of our teachers in the Prairie Provinces be supervised, and only the confidential report of trained inspectors will enable us to maintain public school standards in the classrooms of Indian schools.

To this end, a list of schools, the inspection of which is desired, was submitted to the Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta Departments of Education; and inquiries were made concerning the expense connected with utilizing the services of public school inspectors. Certain schools that are remote from the lines of communication have been omitted. I wish to have the courses of studies in Indian schools conform to the curricula for the public schools in the various provinces. To attain this end, and to ensure uniformity in teaching methods, our schools should be inspected at least once a year by the provincial inspectors.

The cost of this supervision in Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta will be about $2,000.00 per annum, and an item has been placed in the 1922-23 Main Estimates to cover this expenditure. The proposed arrangement with each of the Prairie Provinces is outlined in the attached memorandum to me from the Superintendent of Indian Education.

In June, 1920, the Hon. Mr. Meighen, then Superintendent General, approved of a similar scheme, but requested me not to commit the Department for the time being.

I would respectfully suggest that I be authorized to complete arrangements with the Provincial Departments of Education in Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta, so that our educational work among the Indian children in these provinces will receive the proper supervision without delay.

MEMORANDUM FOR FILE

About 1885 an arrangement was made with the Ontario Department of Education for the inspection of the Indian schools. It was agreed that the remuneration paid to the inspectors would be at the rate of $6.00 per room, plus the actual travelling expenses from the nearest point on their regular route. This arrangement obtains today. Inspections are made semi-annually.

In Quebec and the Maritime Provinces an arrangement was made in 1888 with the Departments of Education on similar lines as for Ontario. The rate of remuneration was $5.00 per room plus expenses. Since January 1, 1921, in Quebec and the Maritime Provinces the inspectors have received $7.50 per room plus expenses. Inspections are made semi-annually.

Arrangements have been concluded this year with the Prairie Provinces. In Manitoba we have agreed to pay the inspectors at the rate of $15.00 per classroom plus expenses. In Saskatchewan and Alberta a flat rate of $20.00 per school is being charged for one inspection per year. In the case of the last two provinces, no allowances are made in connection with expenses.

Sir:

I have to inform you that this Department has completed arrangements with the Manitoba Department of Education for the inspection of the Indian schools that are not remote from the lines of communication. Mr. Fletcher has suggested that we communicate direct with you and offer you information regarding the work to be undertaken and the remuneration.

It is our wish that you inspect the Indian schools in your inspectorate once during the academic year. You should pay particular attention to the academic qualifications and the pedagogy of our teachers; the progress of the pupils; and offer recommendations concerning buildings or equipment, with a view to making the instruction more attractive and efficient. It should be remembered that the teachers of Indian schools are not directly responsible to the public school inspectors, as these schools are controlled and managed solely by this Department; however, teachers are expected to carry out the instructions of the inspectors in regard to their work and the general management of the school. You should feel at liberty to report to this Department any failure on the part of a teacher, or principal, to carry out any reasonable suggestions made by yourself.

With regard to the appointment and dismissal of teachers, I may say that these are matters which rest solely with the Department of Indian Affairs. Recommendations from you in this connection, however, will be welcomed by us—but the final decision rests with Ottawa.

The course of studies prescribed by the Manitoba Department of Education should be followed by the classes in Indian schools, but it is desirable to find teachers following a curriculum printed on the back of our school register; but this practice should be discontinued, as all teachers have been instructed that the principal course is to be followed. The registers for Indian schools that have lately come from the press contain more up-to-date instructions. Generally speaking, Indian day schools are closed during the months of July and August.

The remuneration is at the rate of $15.00 per school, plus your expenses from the nearest point on your regular route of inspection. Your account should be sent in duplicate and should embody not only your fee for the inspection but the travelling expenses. This account, in duplicate, should be supported by receipts for disbursements. These receipts should be taken for all payments over $1.00, whenever possible, except for railway fares, meals—on trains—
on trains, cabs to and from railway stations and other payments at tariff rates.

Enclosed you will find forms for the returns and for your accounts. When these are completed, they should be mailed to W. M. Graham, Esq., Indian Commissioner, Regina, Sask.

I am of the opinion that you will find the work in our Indian day schools not yet up to the standard as set by the public schools of the province. It is our wish to remedy this condition as soon as possible. It may be necessary, in many instances, to hire teachers with better qualifications. This will, of necessity, mean an increased salary item, and the change will have to be made slowly with the consent of Parliament, which votes the funds for Indian education.

Your inspection reports and expense accounts should be, as stated above, directed to Regina, but any questions concerning duties or policy should be addressed to the Secretary, Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa.

Yours very truly,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Maguire and Herrriot, respectively, and I shall be pleased if you will take over the duties which they performed at these schools for the Department of Indian Affairs.

It is our wish that you inspect these residential schools once during each school year. You should pay particular attention to the academic qualifications and the pedagogy of our teachers; the progress of the pupils; and offer recommendations concerning buildings or equipment with a view to making the institutions more attractive and efficient. It should be remembered that the teachers of Indian schools are not directly responsible to the public school inspectors, as these schools are controlled and managed solely by this Department; however, teachers are expected to carry out the instructions of the inspectors in regard to their work and the general management of the school. You should feel at liberty to report to this Department any failure on the part of a teacher, or principal, to carry out any reasonable suggestions made by yourself.

With regard to the appointment and dismissal of teachers, I may say that these are matters which rest solely with the Department of Indian Affairs and the Church Authorities. Recommendations from you in this connection, however, will be welcomed.

The course of studies prescribed by the Manitoba Department of Education should be followed by the classes in Indian schools. You may find teachers following a curriculum printed on the back of our old school register; but this practice should be discontinued, as all teachers have been instructed that the Provincial course is to be followed. To Principals of Indian Residential Schools:

The Department wishes to arrange for a careful and accurate keeping of classroom daily registers. It has been found that many Indian residential schools do not observe this practice; and still others, in the classrooms of which the registers are carefully kept, make no reference to them when the quarterly return is being compiled. In this return there is a column for the purpose of showing the total number of days the pupils attended the classroom during the quarter, and this should be carefully filled in, after reference to the classroom daily register.

The Department considers that every pupil in a residential school should attend classroom, no matter how pressing the work may be in other departments, at least five half days per week, except in the case of illness or absence from the school. In a quarter of, say 91 days there are approximately 65 school days. Junior pupils, who may be in the classroom both morning and afternoon, will attend a total of 65 days during the quarter; older boys and girls, who have regular duties on the farm or in one of the departments, will attend classroom perhaps only 32½ days; other pupils will show 35, 38½, 43, 49½, etc. A separate register must be kept for each classroom and both morning and afternoon an accurate tally should be made.

It is extremely desirable that the Department have this record; and the column in the quarterly report, showing classroom attendance, should receive meticulous care in the preparation thereof, after careful reference to the classroom registers.

The column, showing the total number of days pupils were in residence during the quarter, should be made out as heretofore, and the per capita earnings will be determined solely by the figures shown. The classroom attendance column should be prepared just as carefully, so that a discontented parent, or any other interested correspondent can be given correct information without delay.

If you have not on hand a daily register for each classroom, please make immediate application to the Secretary for copies.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Forrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Sir:

Dr. Fletcher has informed this Department that the Indian Residential School at Marius is now in your inspectorial division. This school was formerly inspected by Mr. A. A. Harriott, and I shall be pleased if you will take over the duties which he performed at this school for the department of Indian Affairs.

It is our wish that you inspect these residential schools once during each school year. You should pay particular attention to the academic qualifications and the pedagogy of our teachers; the progress of the pupils; and offer recommendations concerning buildings or equipment, with a view to making the instruction more attractive and efficient. It should be remembered that the teachers of Indian schools are not directly responsible to the public school inspectors, as these schools are controlled and managed solely by this Department. However, teachers are expected to carry out the instructions of the inspectors in regard to their work and the general management of the school. You should feel at liberty to report to this Department any failure on the part of a teacher, or principal, to carry out any reasonable suggestions made by yourself.

With regard to the appointment and dismissal of teachers, I may say that these are matters which rest solely with the Department of Indian Affairs and the Church Authorities. Recommendations from you in this connection, however, will be welcomed.

The course of studies prescribed by the Manitoba Department of Education should be followed by the classes in Indian schools.

The remuneration is at the rate of $15.00 per school, plus your expenses from the nearest point on your regular route of inspection. Your account should be sent in duplicate and should embody not only your fee for the inspection but the travelling expenses. This account, in duplicate, should be supported by receipts for disbursements. These receipts should be taken for all payments over $1.00, whenever possible, except for railway fares, meals on trains, cabs to and from railway stations and other payments at tariff rates.

Enclosed you will find forms for the returns and for your accounts. When these are completed, they should be mailed to W. M. Graham, Esq., Indian Commissioner, Regina, Sask.

Your inspection reports and expense accounts should be, as stated above, directed to Regina, but any questions concerning duties or policy should be addressed to the Secretary, Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa.

Yours very truly,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Sir,

The Fairford, Lake Manitoba, Lake St. Martin and Little Saskatchewan Indian Day Schools have been regularly visited by Inspector Jas. H. Plews, B. A., who has recently advised us that, from the first of the current year, you are taking charge of the district in which these schools are located.

In visiting these schools, you should pay particular attention to the academic qualifications and methods of the teacher; the progress of the pupils and offer recommendations concerning buildings or equipment, with a view to making the instruction more attractive and efficient. It should be remembered that the teachers of Indian day schools are not directly responsible to the public school inspector, as Indian schools are controlled and managed solely by this Department. However, a teacher is expected to carry out the instructions of the inspector in regard to the work and the general management of the school. You should feel at liberty to report to this Department any failure on the part of any teacher to carry out your suggestions.

The appointment and dismissal of teachers rests solely with the Department of Indian Affairs and the church authorities. However, recommendations from you in this connection will receive consideration.

The Department allows the sum of $15.00 a classroom for inspection once a year, plus expenses from the nearest point on your regular inspection trip. Your account should be forwarded in triplicate and should include, not only your fee for the inspection, but a statement of your travelling expenses, together with receipts for all disbursements over $1.00. If you use your own car, you should show the mileage travelled and request payment at the rate of eight cents (8¢) a mile, which is the amount allowed by the Government.

Enclosed are copies of the report form which you should use when visiting the schools mentioned. Following each inspection, one copy of this form should be forwarded direct to this office.

Any questions concerning duties or policy should be addressed to The Secretary, Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Re Provincial Inspector's Reports

About a year ago I was favoured with a copy of the report which the Manitoba Provincial Inspector supplied to the Department after his inspection of the Elkhorn School. It was very encouraging for us to note his commendation of the work being done by the three teachers, and I was glad to be able to pass on some of his comments for their encouragement.

This is the only occasion on which I seem to have seen anything of the kind in this office, and I wonder if it would not be a good thing if a copy of all such reports could be supplied to us. We are most anxious to maintain the educational standards of the schools administered by this Commission at the highest possible point and we have been very much encouraged by the type of teacher we have been able to secure. It would assist us greatly if we had the verdict of a competent inspector in regard to the quality of the work being done in each case. The Principal reports to us as to matters concerning the general spirit of the teacher and the class, but the Inspectors' Reports would be exceedingly valuable.

Is it possible for such an arrangement to be made?

With kind regards, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

H. A. Alderwood
Secretary.

Dear Mr. Doucet:

I acknowledge receipt of your letter of May 22, with forms required in connection with inspection of Indian Schools. It is noted that the list of your schools in my territory does not include Split Lake, Nelson House (Roman Catholic and United Church Schools), Cross Lake (Roman Catholic and United Church Schools), York Factory, Shamattawa, and perhaps some schools in your Norway House Agency. Did you wish me to skip these schools, or is their exclusion from the list an oversight?

Enclosed herewith are reports on two of the schools which you listed, Big Eddy and The Pas Day Schools. It will not be possible for me to visit any others this term, but I will do what I can in the fall.

During the year I made informal inspections of the Boarding School at Norway House, the Day School at Nelson House, the Day School at Cross Lake, and inspection of the property at Cedar Lake (Chemawawin School). Since I did not have your report forms I have not all the required facts, but for your information I can say that all were functioning normally, with signs of overcrowding at Nelson House where the enrollment was 49. At Cedar Lake the building is in poor condition, and though normally locked I believe it is being used for community activities at times, as the seats are all stored in the attic.

Incidentally, if this school at Cedar Lake is not going to be reopened in the near future, it might be advantageous to move the desks away to some place where they are urgently needed. There are 30 of them, of modern design, chairs with arms and drawers, and hardly used. However I have a list of over 40 children in the Chemawawin school constituency who are at present without school facilities; four of these are Half Breeds, the remainder Treaty.

Yours truly,

R. Scott Bateman,
Inspector of Schools.
