Memorandum:

Re: Meeting with Manitoba Provincial School Inspectors.

In a short address, I explained to the Provincial Inspectors our aims of education and briefly outlined the methods by which the Department expects to achieve these aims. This short talk was followed by questions. The Inspectors showed a very keen interest in the welfare of the Indian but were at a loss to know what was required of them in the line of inspection.

The question of the metis was discussed. Some thought that it was inhuman the way these people were treated. The attention of these gentlemen was drawn to the fact that these people were the responsibility of the Province and not the responsibility of the Federal Government.

Certain questions were asked about Treaty Indians. This question was answered by Inspector Hamilton who had accompanied me at this meeting.

Questions were asked about Indians who were attending white schools. I presumed that reference was made to the Indians working off the Reserves. I explained that the Department was prepared to pay the Per Capita Cost for these students. Explanation of the manner of establishing the amount of Per Capita Cost followed. The method as well as the system seemed to meet their approval.

I further explained that in cases where schools for the Metis were established the Department was ready to follow the same system of payment for the Indians attending, were there no Indian school available.

I returned the following day to meet the Inspectors who inspect our schools. The questions were mostly on what schools they should visit and what kind of reports they should make. I outlined that these schools should be treated as any other schools in their Inspectorate. Reference was made to conventions; would the Department allow some of our teachers to illustrate the work they were doing and demonstrate their methods of teaching. I informed the Inspectors that the Department did not object to this, on the contrary, we were anxious to have our teachers attend teacher meetings whenever possible.
PORTAGE LA PRAIRIE.

I found the school neat and well-ordered; the children showed evidence of good spirit. I believe that Mr. Huston has tackled his work in an intelligent and progressive manner. My special aim was to study the conditions that would facilitate the introduction of Manual Training and have it integrated with the academic work. They have near the school a well-finished garage. It was decided that a few changes should be undertaken before September. The Principal is to submit an estimate of the cost of these changes, at his earliest convenience. I have sent a special form for the Manual Training teacher to complete and to be returned to this office for consideration.

COWESSESS.

I have already reported last year on the crowded condition and the machinery at this school. They have no work-shop suitable for Manual Training instruction. The appointed Instructor is carrying on as best as he can under the present circumstances. It is, therefore, imperative that a small shop be provided to carry on the work. I suggested that it would be advantageous for the Instructor to follow the general shop course given this summer in Brandon or Winnipeg. I doubt, however, that this man will prove unsatisfactory. The fact that he is an Indian should possibly be given consideration, but the welfare of the class should not be sacrificed. His case should be carefully reviewed.

QU'APPELLE.

It will be recalled that the Qu'Appelle School was authorized to make improvements to the shop. I wish to state here that they have at present a splendid shop. It will, however, require interior decorating which they hope to be able to do before the opening of the school next September. There are three Manual Training Instructors at this school. The problem of integration is rather different when the Instructors have not been trained for this work, (one of the Instructors followed the course given by the Department last November).

This school has a good start and I hope that by my next visit the improvements will be more prominent. It must be kept in mind that the shop was repaired by the pupils themselves. Greater benefits would have been obtained from this work if the mathematics, etc., had been integrated to a greater extent. It was, however, as far as it went very good training for the young people and I wish to state again that they have made a good job of their shop. I have encouraged a qualified teacher at this school to attend the general shop course to be given in Brandon or Winnipeg this summer.
The Manual Training students deserve commendation for the work done on their shop. This was good training for them. More planning, however, should have been done by the pupils themselves. In fact, a class discussion followed by a sketch competition would have brought into play many educational factors. The pupils plan to paint the interior of their shop this fall.

There are three Instructors employed at this school. One of these assisted at the short course given by the Department last November. The problem of integration is rather difficult when the Instructors have no training for this work.

MUSCOGEEUAN.

The Instructor, Mr. Lefleur, was sick in the hospital at the time of my visit. The Assistant Principal was in charge of the Manual Training, in the meantime.

The shop, which is in an old building is not satisfactory. A shop will have to be built, if this work is to receive satisfactory attention.

It will be recalled that this school has been connected with the Saskatchewan Power Commission for electric service. It is a one phase. The extractor sent by the Beaver Company is run by a three phase motor. After studying local conditions, I believe that the best method is to have the three phase motor changed to a single phase, as all the other motors are single phase.

SANDY BAY.

The remodeling of the shop has been carried out according to instructions given last November. The work has been done by the pupils and they have done a good job.

The pupils have done splendid work. Ship ladders, wash stands, etc., were very well done. The pupils show a great deal of interest and enthusiasm for their work.
KENORA.

A very small attempt has been made at teaching Manual Training at this school. The pupils are endeavouring to make space in the basement which might prove satisfactory as a temporary arrangement. A shop, preferably separated from the school, will have to be provided if satisfactory progress is to be expected in the teaching of Manual Training. The instructor, Mr. Potvin was absent in Winnipeg when I visited this school. I have since been informed that he has left the Indian service to take a position in Winnipeg.

CECILIA JEFFREY.

Manual Training is being taught at this school in the Senior class. This arrangement is very unsatisfactory. Here again a shop will have to be provided if satisfactory progress is to be expected in teaching Manual Training. The Principal informed me that that he has put an advertisement in the paper for a Manual Training teacher, which reads as follows:

"Presbyterian Indian Residential School requires for September last a Manual Training Teacher. Emphasis on practical application. Some extra-curricular activities. Strong character, good health and interest in boys essential. Salary $1,000 per year and board, room, laundry, etc. Also, one Lady Teacher for Primary Classroom (emphasis on teaching English). Good character, health, etc. Certificate desirable but not essential. Salary $650.00 per year plus room, board, laundry etc. A married couple (without children) would be considered for above two positions."

I doubt that under the conditions of the advertisement a satisfactory Instructor will be obtained.

FORT FRANCES.

Manual Training activities are carried on in the boy's playroom, as they have no adequate shop. I would make the same remark as I made for Cecilia Jeffrey and Kenora. Some work has been done such as cut-outs, etc., They kept the pupils usefully occupied and interested. However, very little organized training is taking place. It will be recalled that Mr. Allard was obtained temporarily as Instructor and I feel that unless he takes some training in this line he will prove unsatisfactory. I intend to take this up again with Reverend Provincial Father Lavigne, the question of Instructors, when I meet him at the beginning of August.

Respectfully submitted,

[A.J. Boucet]

Ottawa, July 3, 1946.

Dear Mr. Bateman:

I have received and carefully read your reports on school inspections at Oxford House and Split Lake. I hope to be writing to you in the near future concerning the new schools we intend building in your inspectorate this year.

By now the school supplies ordered for Oxford House should have reached there. We arranged for the books to reach Ilford by January first. The Northern Transportation Company was requested to handle them by tractor train from there. The Basic Readers of the Curriculum Foundation Series were being supplied to these schools. Thirty-six books were ordered from Moyer's in Winnipeg and our records show that these were delivered to Inspector Hamilton in Winnipeg on January 4 and that they too were shipped to Ilford for onward routing by tractor train. It is unfortunate that all these supplies have not yet arrived to alleviate conditions at these schools.

We are writing to Dr. Dorey of the United Church concerning Mr. Loesen and to Bishop Lorthouse about Reverend Mr. Cowley. You will be receiving notification in the near future of the new teachers' salary scales which we intend taking into effect on the first of September, 1947, and which it is hoped will attract a better class of teacher into our day schools.

I appreciate your frankness in submitting these reports and feel that they will do much to bring about a needed improvement in the education of the Indians of your inspectorate.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

You will recall our discussion in October of 1946 in connection with the operation of the Big Eddy School near The Pas. The understanding which we reached on that occasion was to combine the educational work for the Indian and Half-Breed children in the one unit. Progress along this line appeared to be satisfactory and while we chose to regard this move at Big Eddy as being experimental, the practical advantage of following this plan at other points is evident.

The case of South Indian Lake, a settlement about 150 miles North of Wabodeen, is being brought to our attention quite frequently. The school population within a mile and a half radius of the central point is reported as being 61 Indian children and 25 Half-Breed children.

It is an isolated community and if a building is to be erected, supplies would have to go in by winter freight within the next six weeks.

I would be pleased to have the views of your Department on the advisability of providing the people there with a school. We are ready to co-operate in sharing in the costs of operating the school and to render such assistance as we can in its administration.

Trusting you will let us have the benefit of the opinion of your officials on this proposal at an early date, I am,

Yours very sincerely,

INSPECTOR'S REPORT TO THE TRUSTEES
ON HIS OFFICIAL VISIT TO
The School District of Berens River Roman Catholic Mission School.

Date of Visit: June 18, 1947.

Department of Indian Affairs

Sir:
You are requested to communicate to the Trustees the following remarks respecting the result of my official visit to your school on the above date:

Your attention is directed to the accompanying report.

The building and equipment is in satisfactory condition. I was particularly with the equipment for the playground, which is a very important phase of school activity.

Sr. Vigoureux is in charge of this room; there are 25 children enrolled and there were 6 present. This poor attendance was due to parents away fishing and to an outbreak of chicken pox (three families). The children do very fine work in printing, drawing and writing. Their reading lacks expression and this is one part of their training that is so valuable; the sisters have used school concerts as a means of stimulating pupil interest in reading. There has been some improvement in this but much still remains to be done.

I was impressed by the work these Sisters are doing, not only for the children but also for the adults. Sewing is taught to the girls and some fine exhibits are to be seen. The women are taught to use the loom and some of them are making their own patterns; they have been taught to re-model clothing and have a good supply of Army clothing on hand.

There is a school garden, and the basic idea is to interest the children in this activity. The Mission has as well a few cows, tractor equipment for their small farm, sawing mill and icehouse.

Sr. Vigoureux aided by the Sisters and Fathers of this Mission have worked very hard to improve the lot of these people, and also in getting these people to send the children to school. A sound projector has been obtained and films both sound and silent can be shown.

[Signature]

Lee Owen
I have no doubt that there are many times when the Sisters have been discouraged by the responses that they get, but they have persevered and have done very fine work in their efforts to help these less fortunate people.

Yours very truly,

**Appearance**—Suitability of and taste in dress; neatness of dress and hair; judgment in use of cosmetics; posture; carriage.

**Personality**—Adaptability; courtesy; appreciativeness and understanding; kindness and considerateness; definiteness; co-operation; loyalty; self-control; sincerity; interest; sane optimism; breadth of interest; energy.

**Initiative**—Vision, to conceive with enthusiasm and energy and to carry out a plan; imagination and courage to do something different and new; leadership, administrative ability.

**Health**—Physical fitness, vigour, with reserves of physical power; good sight and hearing; organically sound; mental fitness; well balanced mind, breadth of vision.

**English**—Ability to speak and write in correct English; ability to convey ideas clearly; power to discriminate between the good and the bad in written material.

**Voice**—Tone quality; modulation; distinctness; enunciation.

**Knowledge of Subject Content**—Thorough acquaintance with the matter that is to be taught, together with a grasp of the subject well beyond the requirements of the school which will make possible supplementing and enriching of study outlines.

**Organization**—Clear understanding of objectives; a programme to achieve these objectives; a complete and well-balanced time-table to control the programme; adaptation of their physical and mental development; inculcation of instruction of the needs of the pupils; promotion of good habits and attitudes.

**Management**—General direction of the whole school programme; care of buildings, grounds, library and equipment with special attention to cleanliness and sanitation; close co-operation with trustees.

**Teacher-Pupil Relations**—Pleasant and harmonious classroom atmosphere; co-operation on part of pupils; sharing of work and responsibilities; respect of teacher and pupils each for the other.

**Discipline**—Intelligent direction of school activities; orderly conduct of the work of the school; development of pupil responsibility; delegation of authority.

**Care of Register and Records**—Neat and complete register; well kept library catalogue and lending record; good records of pupils' conduct and achievement; reports to parents.

**Progress of Pupils**—Achievement of pupils in comparison with standards set out in the Programme of Studies with recognition of difference of ability in individual pupils; physical and mental development of pupils.

**Music, Art, Handicrafts, Health Education**—(See Pupil Progress, Management, etc.) These are often considered as extra curricular and consequently neglected. They are included for special rating in order that they may receive due emphasis.

The School District of United Church Mission Day School Berens River
Date of Visit June 18, 1947

Department of Indian Affairs
Secretary-Treas.

Sir:
You are requested to communicate to the Trustees the following remarks respecting the result of my official visit to your school on the above date:

Kindly note the accompanying report. I was more than surprised with the very fine school at this point; it is one of the best schools I have visited during the past winter.

The toilets are too far from the school building. Would it be possible to consider installing indoor toilets? The rock and soil formation would have to be examined carefully to use a Field System; and the same is true for the Flush Type System, the river is quite close and could be utilized in this connection.

Mr. Street has just completed his eighteenth year in this school district. He is very sincere in his work and is also a very good organizer. The work in Nature Study is definitely good, and the pupils have made their own designs. The children were able to draw a map free-hand very quickly and accurately. Generally the drawing, printing and writing are exceptionally good.

I was able to hear Mr. Street conduct lessons in all the Grades during my visit. The children are very shy, and they read in such a low voice that it is very hard to follow them. Their reading generally does lack expression.

Two children in this school—Wilson Goosehead and Harriet Berens—have only one good eye. Would it not be possible for these two children to have a thorough medical examination and ascertain, if possible what the trouble is? There appears to be a film over the eye of one of these children, and they may also suffer to some extent from malnutrition.

The work that is being done here is exceptionally good. Since there is such a fine basement would it be possible to use it for instructional

See over
work in manual training and elementary wood work? These children are very adept in using their hands, and Mr. Street and I discussed this feature and think it might be well to place considerable emphasis on work of this type.

Yours truly,

Dear Mr. Neary:

Re: Indian Schools in the Fisher River Agency

I have your letter of June 24 in which reference is made to proposed administrative changes in the above schools.

It is gratifying to learn that the matter of the education of Indian children is receiving careful consideration, and that plans for improvement are being formulated.

The suggestion regarding a supervising principal would appear to be a forward step. Such a plan would provide advice and guidance of a professional nature to teachers, and would be of special benefit to those teachers who lack experience, or who, having teaching experience, are unfamiliar with conditions in Indian Schools. It would have the effect of giving direction to the teachers regarding courses of study, thus eliminating much of the wasted effort that is now prevalent. As outlined in your letter, the plan, presumably would give to the supervising principal some authority in the matter of ordering supplies and would expedite their delivery to the classrooms. This would result in increased efficiency.

I believe that Mr. T. W. Emerson would do good work in the position mentioned. He has had considerable experience in school administration and is familiar with classroom problems. His limited experience in Indian Schools would be a disadvantage in his dealings with teachers who have had considerable experience in Indian Schools. However, his genial nature would enable him
to secure effective co-operation without antagonizing these teachers. His interest and enthusiasm would have a salutary effect on all teachers.

Under separate cover, I am forwarding reports on Indian Schools visited during the month of June. I am of the opinion that the appointment of a supervising principal would eliminate many of the weaknesses referred to in these reports.

Yours very truly,

Inspector of Schools.

Dear Mr. Neary:

In August, 1949, I succeeded Mr. W.S. Patterson as inspector of schools in Inspectorial Division No. 27, with headquarters at Erickdale. Mr. Patterson informed me that in addition to inspecting the public schools of this division I would also be expected to inspect the Indian schools adjacent to the area included in my division. He further informed me that this inspection was carried out in spring and once a year only. I note from Mr. Patterson's records that most of the Indian school were inspected in May and June.

I am writing to find out what would be the earliest date that you would want the inspection of Indian schools started. Because of the poor condition of the roads through the Reserves in spring it is possible that some of the schools could be reached more easily in January and February than in May or June. We had a very wet fall this year and the road through the Peguis Reserve will probably take long time to dry next spring. Of course it is also possible that the roads to these schools could become completely blocked and remain so throughout the winter.

Is there any information that you think I should have regarding the Indian schools, or are there any special instructions that you would like to give? I have, naturally, had access to the inspection files left by Mr. Patterson and from them have obtained some understanding of what is expected.

Hoping to hear from you shortly, I am

Yours very truly,

Dear Mr. Friesen:

I have for answer your letter of December 29 and was pleased to note that you will be prepared to inspect our Indian schools in your superintendency.

It is quite acceptable if you inspect our schools in January and February as I am only too well aware of the condition of the roads at other times.

I am sending a copy of this letter to our Indian Superintendent of the Fisher River agency at Hodgson, Manitoba, so that he can expect you to be doing these schools at some date within the next two months.

You will find the new schools at Peguis to provide a good classroom but to be deficient in the matter of running water for the toilets. I would have preferred a furnace-heated school also but we had to go in for quantity rather than quality this year.

You will find that with the concurrence of Mr. Patterson we appointed Mr. T. W. Emerson as supervising principal. He will, I hope, be of help to you in getting around the reserve. He is at the Peguis No. 2 School. Our library stock has been rather poor and I know you will be disappointed in the quantity and quality of the books made available. However, we
have been fortunate in securing a much better type of book this winter and these should be in the schools by April and May. Other than that, I want you to report on the schools as you would for provincial schools - do not hesitate to be frank in your expression of opinions either about the teacher, the school or conditions generally.

We are anxious to improve our Indian schools and this goal can only be achieved by the co-operation of all concerned - and you can best help us by comparing our schools with the provincial ones you inspect.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Henry,
Superintendent of Education.

Some 35 years ago the inspection of the Indian schools, both day and industrial, in Ontario and Quebec and the Maritime Provinces was placed in the hands of the Provincial school inspectors, pursuant to an agreement entered into by the Department of Indian Affairs with the respective local Governments. This arrangement is still in effect, except in the province of New Brunswick, where, as in the case of British Columbia, we have a special Inspector of Indian Schools appointed by the Department.

In the Western Provinces our inspection of Indian schools is made by our Inspectors of Indian Agencies. It is the aim of the Department to have the courses in our Indian schools conform as closely as possible to the curriculum of the public schools of the districts in which they are situated, and it is considered that possibly that end might be more completely attained, were the class-room work under the inspection of the Provincial Inspectors.

I should be glad if you would give this suggestion your consideration. I may add that in the Eastern Provinces we have paid a fee for inspection and travelling expenses. Would it be possible for you to let me know what the probable approximate costs would be to this Department, if such an arrangement were put into effect in the Province of Saskatchewan.

Yours truly,

Dear Mr. Ferrier:

Re: 24,949-3, Feb. 13'22.

Mr. Bali and I have been discussing the inspection of the Indian schools and we are not sure what plan would result in the best service to your department and to our young Indian friends.

At first thought it would seem that for your department to deal directly with each inspector would be the simplest plan and the one which would relieve our department of any responsibility. It is just possible however that this department could be of some service without in any way interfering with your jurisdiction, more in the capacity of offering suggestions to you which would result in maintaining the same standards in your schools as we have in our own. After all, the Indian boys and girls are just boys and girls and naturally our interest in their welfare is not less than in the white children under our care.

With this in mind, would it be better for you to deal directly with this department? Our department could add the Indian schools to the present lists of schools given our inspectors, with instructions to inspect and report to you along whatever lines you may wish. These reports might first be sent to Regina for our perusal and afterwards sent on to you. By keeping a small file here we could record any information from these reports which might be of interest later. Or the inspectors might make the reports in duplicate, one copy to be retained here.

You probably are aware that the boundaries of the inspectorates may change from time to time, owing to organization of new school districts. This circumstance
might have its disadvantages in case you were dealing direct with field men.

As to remuneration, your department could pay this department one lump sum on the basis of the letter to you of March 17 with memorandum attached.

I am writing you with the concurrence of Mr. Hall and I shall be glad to refer your views on the matter to him, upon receipt of your reply.

Mr. Scott:

Re: Inspection of Indian Schools in the Provinces of Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta.

With a view to maintaining public school standards in the classrooms of our Indian schools of the Prairie Provinces, this Department has had further correspondence with the Deputy Ministers of Education for Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta. A list of the schools, the inspection of which is desired, was submitted to each Provincial Department and the cost of securing the services of the staffs of inspectors was discussed. Replies have now been received from the Deputy Ministers of Education and bases have been prepared upon which definite arrangements can be made when the necessary authority has been obtained from the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.

In Manitoba we are to make arrangements direct with the staff of inspectors. They have been approached and are willing to inspect 19 day and 7 residential schools for a remuneration of $15.00 and expenses for each visit to a school. My estimate for the Manitoba expenditure is $700.00. I have the addresses of the inspectors and a list of the schools each will inspect.

The Saskatchewan Department of Education have offered to supervise for us the inspection of the Indian schools in that Province. They will add to their present list of public schools, the Indian schools the inspection of which is desired. Inspectors' reports will be made in duplicate and one copy forwarded by the Regina office to Ottawa with the comments of their Chief Inspector. One payment per annum would be made to the Saskatchewan Department of Education, on the basis of a flat rate of $20.00 for day schools and $35.00 for residential schools. The cost for such inspection would be $710.00.

The proposed arrangement with the Alberta Department of Education is identical with that mentioned above for the Province of Saskatchewan, with the exception that we have not been offered any comments on the inspectors' reports. The expenditure involved at the flat rate of $20.00 for each day and $35.00 for each residential school would be $530.00.

It will be noted that the total expenditure for the inspection of the 46 day and 27 residential schools in the three provinces will be slightly less than $2,000.00. An item has been placed in the 1922-23 Estimates to cover this expenditure.

- In each -
In each province, certain schools that are remote from the lines of communication have been omitted from the lists offered to the Provincial Departments.

At present, agents and inspectors of the agencies visit the Indian schools at more or less regular intervals. There is a real need for an academic supervision that our staff in the field are unable to offer.

The proposed arrangement is that the public school inspectors will visit the Indian schools mentioned once a year when they are in the vicinity, and the expenses for which we are responsible (Manitoba) will be kept at a minimum. Inspectors will be informed that it is our aim to maintain public school standards in the classrooms of Indian schools and we will ask them to supervise class-room activities and related matters only. The confidential report of outside trained public school inspectors will be of infinite value to this Department in our effort to make successful our educational work among the Prairie Province Indian children.

In June 1920, the Honorable the Superintendent General approved of a similar scheme but requested that you did not commit the Department of Indian affairs in the matter for the time being.

I beg to recommend that the Superintendent General be approached with a view to having this proposed plan put into effect in the immediate future.

Memorandum:-

Hon. Charles Stewart.

Supervision of the classroom activities in Indian schools in Ontario, Quebec and the Maritime provinces was placed, nearly 40 years ago, in the hands of the provincial public school inspectors, following agreements entered into by this Department with the Provincial Governments. This arrangement still obtains, except in the Province of New Brunswick, where we have a department inspector possessing the necessary academic qualifications. In British Columbia, also, we have an Inspector of Indian schools.

In the Provinces of Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta our Indian schools are visited by our agents and by the inspectors of agencies, who are, of course, not specifically qualified to make other than perfunctory inspections of the academic activities. It is desired that the pedagogy of our teachers in the Prairie Provinces be supervised, and only the confidential report of trained inspectors will enable us to maintain public school standards in the classrooms of Indian schools.

To this end, a list of schools the inspection of which is desired, was submitted to the Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta Departments of Education; and inquiries were made concerning the expense connected with utilizing the services of public school inspectors. Certain schools that are remote from the lines of communication have been omitted. I wish to have the courses of studies in Indian schools conform to the curricula for the public schools in the various provinces. To attain this end, and to ensure uniformity in teaching methods, our schools should be inspected at least once a year by the provincial inspectors.

The cost of this supervision in Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta will be about $2,000.00 per annum, and an item has been placed in the 1922-23 Main Estimates to cover this expenditure. The proposed arrangement with each of the Prairie Provinces is outlined in the attached memorandum to me from the Superintendent of Indian Education.

In June, 1920, the Hon. Mr. Meighen, then Superintendent General, approved of a similar scheme, but requested that we not commit the Department for the time being.

I would respectfully suggest that I be authorized to complete arrangements with the provincial Departments of Education in Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta, so that our educational work among the Indian children in these provinces will receive the proper supervision without delay.

Duncan C. Scott

MEMORANDUM FOR FILE

About 1885 an arrangement was made with the Ontario Department of Education for the inspection of the Indian schools. It was agreed that the remuneration paid to the inspectors would be at the rate of $6.00 per room, plus the actual travelling expenses from the nearest point on their regular route. This arrangement obtains today. Inspections are made semi-annually.

In Quebec and the Maritime Provinces an arrangement was made in 1888 with the Departments of Education on similar lines as for Ontario. The rate of remuneration was $5.00 per room plus expenses. Since January 1, 1921, in Quebec and the Maritime Provinces the inspectors have received $7.50 per room plus expenses. Inspections are made semi-annually.

Arrangements have been concluded this year with the Prairie Provinces. In Manitoba we have agreed to pay the inspectors at the rate of $15.00 per classroom plus expenses. In Saskatchewan and Alberta a flat rate of $20.00 per school is being charged for one inspection per year. In the case of the last two provinces, no allowances are made in connection with expenses.

Russell T. Ferrier,

Dear Mr. Macleod:

I have to inform you that the minister has authorized the inspection of the Indian schools in Saskatchewan by the staff of public school inspectors and a payment to your Department at the flat rate of $20.00 per day and $35.00 per residential school.

This Department would be grateful if you would add the Indian schools to the present lists given your inspectors. Their reports on our forms - copies of which are enclosed - should be forwarded from your office to W. M. Graham, Esq., Indian Commissioner, of your city.

The Department of Indian Affairs would prefer to send you one cheque per annum for the services of your inspectors. When requisition is made for this payment, it might be well to attach a memorandum showing the schools that have been inspected during the calendar, fiscal or academic year, whichever you prefer. The month for this payment may be selected by your Department.

It is our wish that the schools on the list forwarded to your Department under cover of February 13th, last, (with the exception of the little Pines and Roundmaker's Bay schools which are at present closed) be inspected once during the academic year. From time to time we will keep you informed concerning the opening or closing of the Indian schools in the province. The inspectors of your Department should pay particular attention to the academic qualifications and the pedagogy of our teachers; the progress of the pupils; and offer recommendations concerning buildings or equipment, with a view to making the instruction more attractive and efficient.

It should be remembered that the teachers of Indian schools are not directly responsible to the public school inspectors, as these schools are controlled and managed solely by this Department. However, teachers are expected to carry out the instructions of the inspectors in regard to their work and the general management of the school. The inspectors should feel at liberty to report to this Department any failure of a teacher, or principal, to carry out any reasonable suggestions made by them.

With regard to the appointment and dismissal of teachers, I may say that these are matters which rest solely with the Department of Indian Affairs. Recommendations from you in this connection, however, will be welcomed by us; but the final decision rests with Ottawa.

The course of studies prescribed by the Saskatchewan Department of Education should be followed by the classes in Indian schools. Your inspectors will likely find teachers following a curriculum stated on the back of our school register; but this practice should be discontinued, as all teachers have been or should have been instructed that the provincial course is to be followed. The registers for Indian schools that have lately come from the press contain more up-to-date instructions. Generally speaking, Indian day schools are closed during the months of July and August.

I am of the opinion that you will find the work in our Indian day schools not yet up to the standard as set by the public schools of the province. MEMORANDUM FOR INSPECTORS OF SCHOOLS.

Inspectors of schools have been advised that final arrangements have been completed between the Chief Inspector of Schools for Saskatchewan and the Superintendent of Indian Education for the inspection of Indian schools in this province by our inspectors of schools. Fifteen of the inspectorates contain Indian schools and I am taking this opportunity of sending a memorandum to the inspectors concerned to point out a few general considerations for their guidance.

It should be observed that as far as the knowledge of the department goes such schools have not been subjected hitherto to a rigid system of inspection based on a uniform course of study nor have they been governed by such definite provisions as are contained in the school law and regulations. There will, therefore, be found a lack of uniformity and, as compared with the schools organised under The School Act evidences perhaps of inefficiency. Further, considerable retardation may be expected for the reason that the conditions surrounding the rearing and education of the Indian children are generally opposed to satisfactory and uniform progress.

It must be remembered that in general the teachers who have been engaged at the Indian schools are chosen by the various churches and both from the religious and secular point of view their work may be different from the work of
the regular teacher, though not less valuable from the point of view of general education. As a rule these are people of proved devotion to the cause of the Indian races, in fact missionaries, interested alike in education and religion.

In connection with your inspection of these schools it would be advisable to encourage every kind of co-operation and the department would recommend that you notify the teacher or the person in charge of the school and the Indian Agent of the reserve upon which the school is located of the time and date of the inspection. It will probably take several years to bring these schools to a condition of average efficiency as judged by an inspector's usual standards but there is no doubt that with full co-operation and concerted effort the education of the Indian children of this province can advance to a much higher level and perhaps such children, or in any event a substantial number of them, will ultimately be enabled to compete on equal terms in many of the walks of life with the white children of the province.

Sir:

I have your No. 302-11 of the 22nd instant, enclosing Mr. Public School Inspector Veasey's report on the Thunderchild Indian Residential School. I note that the inspector has not confined his remarks solely to classroom activity. His report, however, is so helpful in connection with teaching methods and so comprehensive that I hesitate to send an official letter to the Department of Education in this case, for fear that his criticism and expressions in future could be stifled and curtailed. I have in the past, upon occasion, written such communications, but only when an inspector was evidently putting considerable time on the outside activity at an Indian residential school. This whole problem is about to be solved automatically, as I have already placed an order with the King's Printer for a supply of printed Inspector's Report forms, to be used for residential schools only. The following words are printed in order and with proper spacing on these forms:

"INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL."

Number of pupils in residence. boys girls.
Number of classrooms and number of desks in each.
Number of classes and number of pupils in each class.

STAFF.

Principal's name.
Classroom teachers. (name, age and qualifications of each should be separately stated)
Remarks relative to the methods employed by teachers.
Suggestions regarding teaching methods.

CLASSROOM FURNITURE.

Preservation and arrangement of furniture.
Care of material.
If necessary, indicate what additional classroom material, books, etc., should be supplied.

CLASSROOM.

Condition of classrooms, ventilation, lighting, etc.
Classroom registers. (is a careful tally made morning and afternoon?)
Under this heading, the Inspector should report upon the classroom activity generally and offer any suggestions for improvement.

Date of Inspection. Signature of Inspector.
This form to be used for Indian residential schools only."

I find that all these schools were visited last year, but I am sending the list for the purpose of keeping our files up to date.

I have to thank you for your co-operation.

Dear Sir,

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 14th instant.

I find that the Indian Residential School at Lebret was visited by our inspector on February 25th and March 1st and the Pine Hills Residential School on March 2nd.

Relative to the Kinoomotaya Indian School, our inspector, Mr. W. J. Brimmie of Radisson, in whose territory this school is situated, writes as follows under date of February 25th:

"I may say that I could inspect this school almost any time by rail but that would involve considerable expense to the Department as I would have to go to Big River by rail and then drive out. It would take a full week's time to make the round trip so that I think it might be well to postpone the trip for a time."

Mr. Brimmie's idea is to reach this school just as soon as roads are fit for motor.

In reference to the Little Pine Indian School, our inspector in January wrote as follows:

"I had made up my mind to visit this school early in the fall but on calling up the Indian Agent I found that the date was not suitable for him for that week. Latter I found it necessary to visit the North. The visit was finally put off so long that the cold weather set in and the school was not reached."

Under March 10th, 1928, the inspector writes as follows:

"The road between North Battleford and Paynton has not been used by cars this winter. The only way to reach Little Pine at present would be from Paynton with a team. I have been in touch with the Indian Agent and the local authorities at Little Pine and they quite understand the situation. Unless there is a special call from Ottawa the expense of the trip might not be justified at present. I will take the school on just as soon as opportunity and conditions allow."

I have written Mr. Veazey suggesting that he engage livery from Paynton so as to arrange for an early inspection of this school.

Yours faithfully,

Sir:

I forward for your information the report by Provincial School Inspector Mr. J. T. Tomlinson of his visit to the John Smith's Indian Day School on the 10th ultimo. You will note his comment under "General Remarks" that he finds it "difficult to examine the pupils and to observe the work of the teacher both in one half day." I wrote to the Chief Inspector asking him if there was any reason why Mr. Tomlinson should not have spent a full day observing the work at this school; and I am informed in reply that "instructions to inspectors are that they should spend one half day during each visit to a school." If this is so the inspection of a school cannot be properly completed in one half day. I cannot understand why the inspectors should be arbitrarily limited to that time. We are paying the province $20.00 for each visit to a day school and it seems to me that this payment is not earned when we do not get the benefit of a complete inspection. Mr. Tomlinson clearly states that a half day is not sufficient and if more time should have been devoted on the occasion of his visit, he should have expended it. In a previous letter the Chief Inspector states that, if it was our wish, arrangements could be made to have this school visited again during the fall term. It is not a question of having the school visited twice, but a proper and complete inspection being made once, and we should not find it necessary to ask for a second visit and have to pay a further fee of $20.00.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,

Ottawa, June 14, 1930.

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of the account for the inspection of the Indian schools in the Province of Saskatchewan for the calendar year 1929. A cheque in payment will go forward under separate cover.

There is included a fee for the inspection of the Round Plain School. This is not being deducted, but I should be grateful if you would consider the Department's responsibility for this school. I understand that the school is conducted by a local Board and, no doubt, the inspection reports are forwarded to some local official. Last year your office did not send us a copy of the Inspector's report. The Department pays a grant towards the teacher's salary because there are Indian children attending the Round Plain School, but it is my opinion that it can hardly be classed as an Indian school. We do not appoint the teacher. I may say that, elsewhere in Canada, this Department does not pay inspection fees to provincial officers in the case of combined white and Indian schools.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:-

I beg to forward herewith Provincial School Inspector R. E. Sparkes' report on the St. Andrews Indian Day School which is situated on the Key Reserve in the Pelly Agency.

The Teacher at this school is apparently well qualified and is doing good work. The Inspector states that the attendance has shown some improvement, but it would appear that it is not what it should be yet. I may say that last December I took up the question of the irregularity of attendance at the Day Schools in the Pelly Agency with the Agent and asked him to press upon the parents the necessity of having their children attend schools regularly and particularly as the continuance of the school in operation would depend upon the showing in attendance. This has apparently had the effect of improving the attendance to some extent. The report shows that only seven children were in attendance, five boys and two girls. The cost of the upkeep of this school is quite high when one takes into consideration the number in attendance. This is a matter which I will take up with the parents when I next visit them.

REGINA, SASK., 11th January, 1937.

Sir:-

I have been approached by the Department of Education, Province of Saskatchewan, with reference to reports submitted by their Inspectors on Indian Day and Residential Schools. These at the present time are being furnished our Department in duplicate, but I consider that we should have a third copy to pass on to the Indian Agent concerned in order to obtain the best results from these inspections. The Department of Education have consented to do this, but make the representation that, as most of their men use portable typewriters, it would avoid the necessity of typing a report twice if the forms were supplied on thinner paper, in single sheets, instead of the folded sheet hitherto used.

I think this a very good suggestion, as these folded sheets are found in this office to be inconvenient for filing. My suggestion would be that these forms be printed on thin paper, single sheets, using only one side of the paper, each sheet to be numbered and space provided at the top of each for the name of the school to be inserted. I shall be glad if you would give this your favorable consideration.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. Hoey:

The two teachers at our Lac la Ronge School, namely, Mr. Donald J. Greene, who holds a Saskatchewan certificate, and Miss May Titley, who holds a Manitoba certificate, have written to me, pointing out that unless their classroom work is inspected by a Public School Inspector there is a strong probability that they may have difficulty in securing permanent certificates in their respective Provinces. They informed me that they have written to the School Inspector for the Prince Albert district in the matter, and in his reply he expressed regret that arrangements had not been made for the inspection of the Lac la Ronge School, and that he had several other Indian Schools on his visiting list.

I have spoken this morning to Dr. Fletcher, Deputy Minister of Education of the Province of Manitoba, about the situation, and he informed me that, so far as the Manitoba teacher was concerned, the time she taught at this school would be recognized in connection with her application for a permanent certificate, but that the certificate could not be issued without a School Inspector's recommendation. He suggested that I write to your Department, and ascertain if you could arrange for our Lac la Ronge School to be inspected, and it will be very much appreciated by these teachers, and also by our Commission if you can do this.

Yours very truly,

December 16, 1940.

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of December 11, in which you state you have been informed by Dr. G. B. Stillwell, Director of Teacher Training and Supervision for the province of Saskatchewan, that the reports prepared by the public school inspectors on Indian day and residential schools should be forwarded direct to the Department.

The decision to have these reports forwarded direct to Ottawa was reached several months ago. It represents an attempt to avoid, if we can, the delay that must of necessity occur when such reports are sent through the offices of the Provincial Inspectors. With Indian day schools operating on a 9 month rather than a 10 month basis, it is highly desirable that Inspectors' reports, drawing our attention to the necessity for minor repairs at the school, additional supplies such as textbooks, etc., should be promptly dealt with. It is exceedingly difficult for the average pupil to complete his year's work in a 9 month period and simply impossible to do so unless supplies are on hand either at the date of the school opening or immediately afterwards.

It is noted that the Inspector's report on the Ahtahkakoops School is dated October 25, 1940, and was forwarded by you in a letter dated November 18, 1940. The report on the Mistawasis School is dated October 15, 1940, and was forwarded by you also on November 18. The report on the Gordon School is dated October 25, 1940, and was forwarded by you on November 27, 1940. It is not suggested that the delay necessarily occurred at your office, but I feel you will agree with us that it should

M. Christianson, Esq.,

be possible to secure these reports more promptly.

In asking that reports on the Saskatchewan schools be forwarded direct to Ottawa, we are simply bringing the practice in Saskatchewan into conformity with the practice in force in the other provinces, with the exception of British Columbia, where the inspection of our schools is undertaken by an inspector who is a regular employee of this Department.

Yours very truly,

T. R. L. MacInnes,

Memorandum:

DOCTOR McGILL

I am sending forward herewith, for the signature of the Secretary, a letter addressed to Mr. M. Christianson, General Superintendent of Indian Agencies, Regina, Sask.

This letter, you will note, relates to the inspection of Indian day and residential schools in the province of Saskatchewan and to the necessity for having the public school inspectors forward their reports direct to Ottawa. This letter is written in reply to Mr. Christianson's communication dated December 11, 1940.

There is little that I need add to the information contained in the letter addressed to Mr. Christianson. I should point out, however, that the clerical work at the offices of our inspectors and Indian agents is steadily increasing. Mr. Willis, in his audit report on the Alberta Inspectorate, dated Calgary, December 3, 1940, states:

"The clerical work in this office appears to be increasing. The letter register shows 6,020 letters received for the period."

In view of this fact, I can see very little purpose in having the reports on Indian day and residential schools passed through the inspector's office. The inspectors themselves are, as you know, responsible for the supervision of our schools. It seems to me that it would be an advantage rather than a disadvantage to have the school inspectors' reports and the reports of our own inspectors sent in independently. In this way we could feel sure from time to time that our own inspectors were not influenced in any way either for or against a teacher, by the reports already sent in by the public school inspector.

R. A. Hey
Supt. of Welfare and Training.
Ottawa, December 16, 1940.

Dear Sir:

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 1-1-6 Sask. of the 16th instant.

In this connection I wish to say that all I could do when I read the reason given for the change in forwarding the School Inspector's reports, was smile. I will admit that when I wrote the Department my letter No. 300-11 of the 11th instant my blood pressure was up and I do not blame Dr. Stillwell for laughing when I informed him that I had not been advised by the Department. Is it any wonder?

In the past, as well as at the present time, I have always taken a great interest in the schools and have accomplished, I believe, a lot of good work in this connection both in Manitoba, Saskatchewan, and Alberta in bringing about better business administration at these institutions. I have already inspected several schools in this Province and reported on them, and in due course I hope to visit them all. Therefore the reports on these schools are of great assistance to me when I make my inspections. I do not want to be in variance with members of the Branch at Ottawa. You state that some of the reports have been held up. If they were, it was to obtain more information from Dr. Stillwell, as some of his men are new on the job and the information they gave in the reports was vague. For instance, we have a school report here now on the Cowessess Residential School which was forwarded on Day School forms. We were forced to return this to Dr. Stillwell and I might say here that this is the second time this has happened.

Without any more writing I would ask you again to rescind your instructions to Dr. Stillwell and ask him to continue sending the reports . . . .

Dear Sir,

By an arrangement between the Dominion and Provincial Governments, the superintendents of schools of this Department make an inspection annually of the classrooms in the Indian Schools located in Saskatchewan. SASK. SCHOOL TRUSTEES SEEK FINANCIAL AID FOR EDUCATION

The three-day annual convention of the Saskatchewan School Trustees' Association held in Saskatoon last week and attended by more than 250 delegates, heard considerable evidence that in the main the problems affecting education in the province have been accurately diagnosed by the administration and have no serious threat to the educational welfare of the school districts.

A resolution calling for a program of education, the equalization of educational opportunity, and the problem of securing better teachers for rural areas was adopted by the convention. There was general agreement among the delegates that land taxation was hindered far too much by the system of levying for education.

Financial Aid

Delegates gave unanimous approval to a resolution assuring the government that at least 80 per cent of the total cost of education should be covered by equalization and per capita grants to the school districts.

Another resolution, compared with the one just mentioned, was passed unanimously, supporting the proposal to raise the salary of primary school teachers from $160 per year to $180 per year, primary school teachers from $140 per year to $160 per year, and secondary school teachers from $190 per year to $200 per year.

The convention, in connection with the question of finance, once more reaffirmed its confidence in the association to continue pressing for a fairer distribution of resources.

During the debate on financing, delegates noted that education bills in the past have been introduced in the province when the economy was weak and the situation has been made worse by the fact that the government has not been able to meet the demands of the schools.

Another resolution, compared with the one just mentioned, was passed unanimously, supporting the proposal to raise the salary of primary school teachers from $160 per year to $180 per year, primary school teachers from $140 per year to $160 per year, and secondary school teachers from $190 per year to $200 per year.

The convention went on record as supporting the proposal to provide lands in the Province for school tax purposes, and to provide funds for the purchase of land for school purposes.

Another resolution urged that instead of the present system of the P.F.A.A., the school board be used as a factor in estimating the equalization grants paid to school districts.

Representation

In a convention that was marked by a spirit of cooperation and understanding, the delegates discussed the problem of financing education in Saskatchewan.

I hereby submit my quarterly report covering the
Carlton Agency for the quarter ending September 30, 1949.

ADMINISTRATION:

Field work on the Southern Reserves in the Agency
has consisted of Haying and Harvesting operations, follow-up
work on summer-fallow and new land broken.

On the Northern Reserves supervision has been
given to construction of bridges and docks. In the case of Lac
La Ronge, supervision was given to the sawing of some eighty
thousand feet of lumber taken out by the Indians for their own
use.

In addition to the above, supervision was given to
the lumbering operations carried out by Mr. James L. McLean
on the Montreal Lake Reserve. During the quarter Mr. McLean
sawed 83,500 feet of lumber. Timber dues are paid up to date.

Commercial fishing was not carried out by Indians
at any points covered by this Agency during the past quarter.

Sale of fur has now been completed for last
winter's and spring's catch. It may be recalled in my last
March 31st quarterly report I estimated the overall returns
from fur sales in the Carlton Agency would be in the neighbor-
hood of $325,841.00. To date the figures in connection with the
Sipapu Project have not been made available to this office,
but I find an estimate made over the balance of the area was
ten percent too high. In analyzing the returns it was found
the drop in the market was the chief factor. That, of course,
is beyond our control. It is somewhat appalling when one
realizes the loss in returns brought about by improperly
prepared pelts, both rat and beaver.

Through the cooperation of the Provincial Field
men, I am making arrangements to have as much fur as possible
pass through the hands of our own men next Spring before it is
shipped, this is intended as an educational program. In this
way I hope the Indians will be made to realize why some receive
poorer grades than others and the loss in revenue which
results from improperly prepared pelts.

Miles travelled by Departmental car No. 1412
operated by the writer, 5977 miles, cost of operating $249.59.
Miles travelled by Departmental truck No. 1425 operated by
Assistant, Indian Agency, A. N. Wark, 4385 miles, cost of
operating $245.01. Truck No. 1135 operated by Assistant,
Indian Agency, P. A. Pederson, 3660 miles cost of operating
$144.45.
Cost of air transportation for self and field men will amount to approximately $100.00.

RESERVES AND TRUSTS:

Collections made during the quarter were as follows: Timber dues received from Mr. James L. McLean for timber cut on the Montreal Lake Reserve amounted to $698.72. Proceeds from sales to date of grain produced on the Sturgeon Lake Community Farm amount to $1,693.84.

MEDICAL:

The general health of the Indians during the past quarter has been good. Cost of hospitalization for the quarter will amount to approximately $14,907.00.

EDUCATION:

The five day schools in the Agency were visited during the quarter. One visit was also made to the Seasonal Day School at Stanley. The St. Alban's and All Saints Residential Schools were visited on numerous occasions during the quarter.

GENERAL:

Crop returns covering the farming reserves in the Agency have not been prepared, however, the yields are the best in years.

Most of the trappers have left for their trapping grounds. Before they left they were interviewed in a general way and it is my understanding they were sufficiently well equipped to start out.

E. S. Jones,
Superintendent, Indian Agency.

THE DIRECTOR

Inspection of Indian Schools in British Columbia and Saskatchewan.

As you are aware, I have yet to inspect any of the Indian schools situated in British Columbia since my appointment as Superintendent of Education. I have never yet inspected an Indian school situated in Saskatchewan.

Therefore, I have noted with interest the comments in Hansard made with regard to more travelling by officials in Ottawa to the various Indian reserves and institutions. Please find attached the pamphlet describing the next meeting of the Canadian Education Association to be held in Victoria, October 2, 3 and 4. I regard this as an ideal opportunity to inspect some of the Indian schools in Western Canada. I would recommend that an itinerary be planned to permit my leaving Ottawa about September 6 to travel to Saskatchewan, do certain of the schools there and then proceed to British Columbia, where I could inspect schools up to October 2.

I could return through the Kettle Valley and do some of the schools in Southern Alberta.

Edmonton, September 11th, 1920.

Sir:

The Minister of Education, upon his departure for Eastern Canada, directed me to reply to your communication of July 7th, with respect to the Provincial government inspecting the Indian schools in the Province of Alberta. I have discussed this question with the Minister, and also with some of your officials who are connected with the Indian schools, and have come to the conclusion that it would be in the interests of education to have these schools inspected by the local Inspectors.

It is impossible for me to advise you with regard to the expense in connection with the inspection, as it will be necessary for me to know the number of schools, and the location of each, together with the number of rooms in each school which will have to be inspected. MEMORANDUM FOR FILE

About 1885 an arrangement was made with the Ontario Department of Education for the inspection of the Indian schools. It was agreed that the remuneration paid to the inspectors would be at the rate of $6.00 per room, plus the actual travelling expenses from the nearest point on their regular route. This arrangement obtains today. Inspections are made semi-annually.

In Quebec and the Maritime Provinces an arrangement was made in 1888 with the Departments of Education on similar lines as for Ontario. The rate of remuneration was $5.00 per room plus expenses. Since January 1, 1921, in Quebec and the Maritime Provinces the inspectors have received $7.50 per room plus expenses. Inspections are made semi-annually.

Arrangements have been concluded this year with the Prairie Provinces. In Manitoba we have agreed to pay the inspectors at the rate of $15.00 per classroom plus expenses. In Saskatchewan and Alberta a flat rate of $20.00 per school is being charged for one inspection per year. In the case of the last two provinces, no allowances are made in connection with expenses.

I have to inform you that arrangements have been completed with the Department of Education for your Province for the inspection of Indian schools by the staff of public school inspectors. Dear Mr. Ross:

I have to inform you that the Minister has authorized the inspection of the Indian schools in Alberta by the staff of public school inspectors and a payment to your Department at the flat rate of $20.00 per day and $35.00 per residential school.

This Department would be grateful if you would add the Indian schools to the present lists given your inspectors. Their reports on our forms - copies of which are enclosed - should be forwarded from your office to W. M. Graham, Esq., Indian Commissioner, Regina, Sask.

The Department of Indian Affairs would prefer to send you one cheque per annum for the services of your inspectors. When requisition is made for this payment, it might be well to attach a memorandum showing the schools that have been inspected during the calendar, fiscal or academic year, whichever you prefer. The month for this payment may be selected by your Department.

It is our wish that the schools on the list forwarded to your Department under cover of February 16th, last, be inspected once during the academic year. From time to time, we will keep you informed concerning the opening or closing of any Indian schools in the province. The inspectors of your Department should pay particular attention to the academic qualifications and the pedagogy of our teachers; the progress of the pupils; and offer recommendations concerning buildings or equipment, with a view to making the instruction more attractive and efficient. It should be remembered that the teachers of Indian schools are not directly responsible to the public school inspectors, as these schools are controlled and managed solely by this Department; however, teachers are expected to carry out the instructions of the inspectors in regard to their work and the general management of the school. The inspectors should feel at liberty to report to this Department any failure of a teacher, or principal, to carry out any reasonable suggestions made by them.

With regard to the appointment and dismissal of teachers, I may say that these are matters which rest solely with the Department of Indian Affairs. Recommendations from you in this connection, however, will be welcomed by us; but the final decision rests with Ottawa.

The aim has been to afford at least two inspections to each school department each year, and thus make it possible for the inspector to have a closer acquaintance with the capacity of the teaching force, and have his work partake more of the nature of supervision than inspection solely.

In order to make the inspector's visit as helpful as possible, the teacher (if in a school where four or more teachers are employed) now receives a copy of his report as forwarded to the Department. Formerly only city teachers received copies of reports on their work. If the present procedure is found to be satisfactory in 1922, it will be extended to include all teachers at work in the province.

A clear idea of the work of inspection and the educational development in the province may be gathered from the inspectors' annual reports. Extracts which are regarded as being of greatest value have been made from these reports and are submitted herewith.

The following comments of inspectors in charge of various divisions reveal the influence of conditions upon possible results:

General agricultural conditions in this division have not been good and this has had its effect upon matters educational. Selling prices for the farmer have continued low, whilst there has been no proportionate and correspondent fall in the prices of machinery and general commodities. The result has been a scarcity of money. The stringency has been so general throughout the school districts that it is rather creditable that school operation has been so good, and application for government help has been so rare. For only one school district has application been made for help, and here the application was made on quite other grounds than that of agricultural depression.

One usual effect on the farmer's shortage of money is the certainty of his effort to pay the teacher less than he paid him during this year and last. Trustees seem to feel that they are justified by general monetary conditions in lowering salaries. A general lowering of salaries, if applied to the whole Province, will affect the quality of the student, who is attracted to the teaching profession. (Inspector Beveridge, Peace River.)

The crops for 1921 were good, but the low market prices and the excessive freight charges have left the farmers with little or no chance of raising money. This fact is already affecting the operation of schools and teachers' salaries.

However, teachers' salaries have, on the average been good, the majority of the districts, even those in the more undeveloped parts, have been paying in the neighborhood of twelve hundred dollars. Some of the older districts have been paying thirteen hundred, and even sixteen hundred dollars. (Inspector Bremner, Grande Prairie.)

Dear Mr. Ross:

I wish to draw your attention to certain features of your Mr. Inspector Hutchison's reports on Indian schools. Your officer has been quite severe in some of his criticisms and has suggested some rather radical changes. I am confident that a quiet word from you, explaining the situation outlined in my letter of May 19th, last, would be very helpful, and he, in turn, would increase his helpfulness if he understood the conditions under which we have been working for so many years. I am sure Mr. Hutchison is a tactful gentleman and has not been so outspoken in the field as in his reports. At some of our institutions, the public school inspectors have not been welcome a second time because they expected too much upon the occasion of their first visit. Dear Mr. Ross:

I wish to acknowledge your letter of the 11th ultimo and inform you that a cheque for $580, in favour of the Provincial Treasurer, is being directed to your Department. This payment is for the inspection of twelve residential and eight day schools. I wish to take this opportunity to thank you for your Department's cooperation in our effort to provide better educational facilities for the young Indians in Indian wards. Much good has resulted from the helpful criticisms of the Alberta inspectors and there has resulted better teaching services and physical equipment.

I am enclosing a list of the schools to be inspected this year. This is for the purpose of keeping our files up to date. Under separate cover, there is being directed to you 50 copies of a new report form, to be used by public school inspectors when visiting Indian residential schools. The old forms should be used when reporting on Indian day schools.

I note that Mr. Inspector Yule visited the St. Bruno's and Sturgeon Lake Indian Residential Schools in 1923 but not in 1924. If it is convenient to your Department and this inspector, I should be pleased if these two schools are kept on the list. I might also point out that Mr. Inspector Crispo refers to the Cold Lake Day School as the St. Lawrence and to the Goodfish Lake School as the Whitefish. It would be better if the names officially used by this Department were adopted in his reports.

Yours very truly,

Russell M. Kerrison,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Sir:

I have your 400-11 of the 6th ultimo, regarding your reports on your inspection of Indian schools. I regret that a reply to this letter was inadvertently overlooked.

The form in which your reports are submitted is satisfactory and the Department has no change to suggest in the manner in which they are written. It will not be necessary for you to enter into detail with regard to classroom activities or teaching methods. You should state your opinion with reference to the various members of the staff, the condition and cleanliness of the building, the appearance of the children, the manner in which they are clothed and also regarding the food supplied. In reply to your letter of the 19th instant regarding the inspection of the Edmonton, St. Albert and Sturgeon Lake (St. Francis Xavier) Indian Residential Schools, I beg to advise you that these schools were inspected by the provincial school inspectors during the year 1933, and the reports were forwarded to Mr. M. Christianson, Inspector of Indian Agencies at Calgary.

Mr. J. J. LeBlanc inspected the Edmonton Indian Residential School on November 16, 1933, and the St. Albert Indian Residential School on November 13 and 14, 1933. His reports were received on the 20th of November, and were forwarded to your agent in Calgary two days later. The St. Francis Xavier school was inspected by Mr. H. E. Balfour on October 5, 1933. His report was received in this office on November 23, and forwarded to Mr. Christianson on the same day.

I am writing to Mr. Christianson in order that I may learn whether or not these reports were received by him and what disposition was made of them. If the originals are not available I will secure other copies and send them to you.

Your obedient servant,

J. T. Ross.

RE CERTIFICATION OF INSTRUCTORS IN PRIVATE SCHOOLS

Since the new system of recommending students for credit in first year and second year subjects of the revised Programme of Studies for the High School and in optional subjects of the Programme of Studies for the Intermediate School has superseded the former system of Departmental examinations, it has become necessary for the Department of Education to assume the responsibility of accepting such recommendations for credit and of issuing a statement of credits to each student concerned. In schools directly under the jurisdiction of the Department of Education all teachers are required to hold a valid certificate of qualification in pursuance of Section 154 of The School Act. Such valid certificate is, of course, a teacher's professional certificate issued by the Minister of Education.

While it is true that private schools are not directly under the jurisdiction of the Department of Education, it is nevertheless obvious that the Department's responsibility in accepting recommendations for credit from instructors in private schools and in issuing statements of credits to students in such schools must rest on some assurance that the instructors hold valid academic and professional qualifications and also the special qualifications required for teaching certain elective and optional subjects.

There are persons offering instruction in private schools of the Province who hold satisfactory academic qualifications, but who nevertheless have not attended any other training institution such as a teachers' college, normal school, or school or faculty of education, and hold no pedagogical qualifications of a kind that can be regarded as definitely professional.

During the year 1938-39, the Department of Education will continue its policy of accepting recommendations for credit in high school subjects or optional subjects of the intermediate school from instructors in private schools, provided such recommendations are accompanied by a statement of an Inspector of High Schools or an Inspector of Schools to the effect that the instruction, organization and equipment meet with his approval.

This arrangement, however, will terminate on September 1, 1940. Thereafter recommendations for credit in any or all high school subjects and any optional subjects of the intermediate school made by any private school shall be recognized by the Department only in those cases where the recommendations are made by a person holding a valid professional certificate, issued by the Minister of Education of the Province of Alberta.

During the year 1939-40 recommendations for credit in high school subjects (or in the optional subjects of the intermediate school) may be accepted from private schools by the Department of Education if such recommendations are accom-
panied by a statement from an Inspector of High Schools or an Inspector of Schools to the effect that the instruction, organization and equipment meet with his approval and further, that the school concerned is making reasonable progress towards securing teachers who hold valid Alberta qualifications.

From the foregoing statement you will understand that teachers in private schools who do not hold a valid professional certificate are expected to qualify for such a certificate on or before September 1, 1940; if they desire the privilege of recommending students for crediting during the year 1940-41. Members of your staff who hold academic standing obtained outside the Province and who have also taken professional teacher-training courses at institutions outside the Province are asked to have an official statement of such standing and such teacher-training courses sent to this Department from the Department of Education of the province or state where such standing was obtained, or such courses taken.

Those members of your staff who submit official evidence of academic standing and professional training that can be recognized as the equivalent of an Alberta certificate will receive such certificate. Those who are not entitled to a certificate from this Department will be advised regarding further courses or training which may be required before they will be deemed eligible for a professional certificate. The Department will offer special summer-school courses in July, 1939, which such persons may take in order to bring their professional qualifications up to the required standard. These summer-school courses will be spread over a period of two years in order to suit the convenience of the teachers concerned.

It is desirable that you and members of your staff give consideration to this matter of valid certification at an early date, in order that any necessary arrangements may be made for summer-school courses at the 1939 session of the Summer School. A copy of the newly issued pamphlet on the "Training and Certification of Teachers in Alberta," and of the Summer School Announcement for 1939, will be sent to you on request.

Yours truly,

G. FRED McNALLY,
Deputy Minister.
