Ottawa, May 28, 1940.

Dear Doctor McNally:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 23rd instant, in which you submit, for my consideration, an excerpt from a report relating to text books, received by you from Inspector Thomas F. Hamilton.

I find it somewhat difficult to know what I should say by way of reply to Inspector Hamilton.

It may help you to understand more fully the position in which I find myself if I state that, in a general way, we attempt to follow in our Indian day and residential schools the provincial curricula authorized by the provincial departments of Education throughout the Dominion. These curricula or courses of study have been frequently revised in recent years. Indeed I feel I am speaking more accurately when I state they appear to be in a constant state of flux. The courses of study in Manitoba, in Ontario and in the province of Quebec are now in process of reconstruction. All these revisions involve constant changes in text-books and particularly in supplementary readers. In addition to this, our Indian day and residential schools are operated in co-operation with the Catholic, Anglican, Presbyterian and United Churches of Canada, with one or two schools in British Columbia operated under the auspices of the Salvation Army. It is scarcely necessary to state that certain text-books, acceptable to Catholics, would be looked upon as wholly unsuitable in non-Catholic schools.

It is a common experience here for the officials to purchase supplementary readers on the recommendation of an inspector, only to discover that a newly appointed inspector, working in the same school or schools, will point out the unsuitability of the readers recommended by his predecessor and submit a completely new list to this Department. It happens so frequently that an attempt was made to get four inspectors in one of the eastern provinces to meet, in the hope that they could submit to this Department a list of supplementary readers suitable for Indian schools in the province. You may not be surprised to learn that the inspectors failed to agree and sent in four distinct and separate lists.

When I entered the Department and encountered this problem about four years ago, I issued a circular letter, suggesting that the time spent by white pupils in supplementary reading might be profitably spent by Indian pupils in manual training and Indian handicraft projects -

G. Fred McNally, Esq., M.A., LL.D.,
Deputy Minister of Education,
Edmonton, Alberta.
projects, and my suggestion has been adopted in a number of schools in the East. I realize, of course, that there is a weakness in the suggestion in that it is likely to handicap the Indian pupil who is proceeding in the direction of a high school course.

All text-books for use in Indian schools, together with maps, exercise books and school supplies generally, are purchased, not by this Department, but by the Stationery Office of the Government. The officials of this office, together with our own officials here, are naturally anxious in a period like this to keep down educational costs and consequently always aim at buying text-books and supplementary readers in bulk. This fact in itself may explain why we cannot always respond quickly to the recommendation of an inspector while we have a number of undistributed text-books on hand.

And now I come to Inspector Hamilton's reference to the residential schools on the Blood reserve. The last requisition received from the Principal of this school is dated December, 1929. All the regular text-books requested, with one or two exceptions, were supplied together with the regular school supplies. Inspector Hamilton states: "In these reports I have made a protest against the supplementary reading books supplied to these schools. I did the same last year and handed the principals to make a suitable list of books". I can state very definitely that no such list reached this Branch from the Principal of the St. Paul's school. In addition to the regular text-books requested, I am attaching hereto a list of the supplementary readers sent forward by the Branch, in the hope that the principals and pupils would find them interesting and suggestive.

In the case of the Blood R. C. school, a small number of supplementary readers were requested by the principal, but inasmuch as the books requested were not in stock and in view of the fact that we had still a large number of supplementary readers on hand, all the supplementary readers requested by the principal were not sent forward. However, I am sending forward a list of the supplementary readers supplied to this school. It is only fair to the officials here to state that in the case of both schools more supplementary readers were supplied than were requested by the principals.

I certainly appreciate your interest in this particular matter. If you are in the East at any time in the immediate future, I would certainly welcome a visit by you to this Branch. The purchase and distribution of text-books and supplementary readers is one of the most difficult problems confronting the officials charged with the administration of Indian schools, particularly so in these days, when our educational appropriation has been drastically reduced.

Yours very truly,

R. A. Hoey,

INDIAN EDUCATION IN ALBERTA

On August 22, 1946, those school superintendents of our Alberta staff who had had experience with Indian schools met to discuss educational facilities for Indian pupils. The attendance was good and all those present were men of considerable experience with schools for Indians; one superintendent actually grew up on an Indian reserve where his father was engaged in educational work.

The men discussed the topic freely, and contributed a great deal of information about existing facilities which provide for the education of Indians. I have attempted to summarize these contributions in the following report:

MISSION SCHOOLS

On the whole, the superintendents approved of the mission schools, chiefly for non-institutional reasons. When the Indian children come into these schools they are put into a thoroughly hygienic condition and given clean clothing. Medical officers examine them and prescribe any treatment that may be needed. Children showing symptoms of active tuberculosis are hospitalized. Nonactive cases are taken care of quite efficiently; the children are not allowed to over-exert themselves and are allowed at least two rest periods during the day; they are put on a high protein diet, weights are checked frequently, and they are given such other treatment as may be prescribed by the medical officer.

Although the missions are usually overcrowded, the living accommodation for the Indian pupils is usually satisfactory in other respects. Their quarters are clean, well aired, and properly heated, while the diet of the children has been observed to be satisfactory.

Some of the superintendents reported that occasionally the Indians object to sending their children to the mission schools, chiefly because they are taken away from their homes from Sunday night to the following Friday night, except during vacation periods.

INSTRUCTION

It was generally agreed that the instruction given in Indian schools is not up to standard. In the first place qualified teachers are seldom employed; in most cases persons with Grade IX standing, and no professional training, are in charge of the classes. As a result, the teaching done in the schools is usually quite unsatisfactory.

The course of studies used is too indefinite. Usually some attempt is made to follow our own course of studies, but apparently the teachers and principals have a great deal of freedom, with the result that a very mediocre type of instruction is given which does not begin to approach the standards that we set for our public schools.
The library facilities for the mission schools were reported to be inadequate in practically every case. Most of the literature supplied was religious in nature and far above the comprehension of the pupils. Superintendents reported that they had frequently recommended suitable books, but that these recommendations were seldom, if ever, carried out. Several of those present were of the opinion that the books for the Indian schools were chosen in Ottawa by persons without teaching experience who were not conversant with conditions in Indian schools.

One inspector complained that the Dominion Government grants for education in mission schools were very low, and that this fact was responsible for the lack of proper equipment and library facilities that prevailed.

A certain amount of vocational training is offered in the mission schools, chiefly farming. In a number of places the pupils who have reached a suitable age spend half of their school time in the classroom and the balance at vocational work. The latter includes home economics for girls, and shop and farm work for boys. It was observed that very creditable art, embroidery, leather, bead, and needlework is being done in these schools.

**INDIAN DAY SCHOOLS**

There are very few Indian day schools in the Province so our superintendents have not had a great deal of experience with them. However, they report that as far as instruction is concerned the same unsatisfactory conditions prevail in them as do in the mission schools. Teachers, as a rule, have very low academic standing and no professional training whatever. The Provincial courses of studies are followed very loosely and there is a dearth of proper equipment and library facilities.

As in the case of the mission schools, the Indian children are making very slow progress with their studies as compared with our public school pupils. A certain amount of shop work is given to the boys and suitable handwork to the girls, with comparatively good results.

The superintendents complained about the poor attendance at day schools; only about half of the children attend, and the punctuality is most unsatisfactory. In most of the areas where day schools are operated the Indians go on periodical trips to carry on hunting and fishing operations, during which times the children are out of school.

Hygienic conditions in these schools are reported to be appalling as the children live at home under the primitive conditions of their people. They are supposed to be inspected periodically by the health nurses and medical officers, yet in spite of this they are unclean, poorly clothed and apparently not very healthy.

It was reported that in some cases the Indians attend regular day schools in which their progress is considerably better than that of the children in the schools operated by the Dominion Government. However, in practically every case
white settlers have protested against the Indians being in schools on account of their uncleanliness and the possibility of their presence exposing the other children to tuberculosis. The reports of the inspectors who have observed these children under public school conditions indicate that Indian pupils are capable of making better progress than they are doing in the average day and mission schools operated on reserves.

Attention was drawn to the fact that the Indians appeared to absorb very little civilization while in the school. When the young graduate from school most of them seem to enjoy going back to the primitive Indian life and resuming the ways of living practised by their people. Only one exception was noted.

RECOMMENDATIONS

It was considered that mission schools should be continued on reserves where the Indians are comparatively static as these schools provide clean, healthy conditions for the children. In outlying points, where the Indians are somewhat nomadic in their habits, it was thought that day schools should be operated during the spring, summer and early fall. It was considered that no attempt should be made to restrict the Indians in their trapping and fishing as these are their means of gaining a livelihood and it is desirable that the young people should learn to carry on these operations.

It was recommended that a suitable course of studies be drawn up for Indian schools, designed to meet their particular needs. The Indian is artistic and is fond of handwork but he loathes anything pertaining to the abstract. He is fond of nature, athletics and games. Vocational training should form a large part of the curriculum and should occupy approximately one-half of the pupils' school time. Instruction in stock raising, farming, trapping and fishing should be included. In a few cases the Indians operate coal mines so this activity should not be overlooked in the areas concerned. The vocations practised by the Indians in the area of the schools should be stressed in the programme of those schools.

Every effort should be made to provide suitable libraries for the Indian children. The literature should be simple and should deal with those things in which the Indian is interested; such as, art, nature study, adventure and hunting. A good supply of pre-primers and primary supplementary reading books should be provided. They should be well-bound, interesting books containing plenty of colored illustrations.

It was felt important that a full course of studies be drawn up which would be elastic enough to meet the conditions of the various schools. Due to the fact that the teachers who use them are seldom properly trained, the curriculum should be quite comprehensive.

Every effort should be made to provide trained teachers with suitable backgrounds. These people should be imbued with missionary spirit. They should have a satisfactory academic background and adequate training in pedagogy. In addition, they should receive special courses in the teaching of Indian children from experienced and competent instructors.
It was thought that the ideal Indian teacher would be a native Indian who has undergone the necessary training to enable him to instruct in the schools of his own people. One of the superintendents has known such teachers and recommends them highly.

In conclusion, it appears to be evident that the Indian schools in the Province are not accomplishing nearly as much as they might, due to poorly trained teachers, lack of a definite course of studies, and a dearth of proper equipment and library facilities. It is felt that under suitable conditions the Indian may be educated to take his place as a useful citizen of his own community and the country at large. The meeting strongly recommended that the Dominion Government be urged to extend and improve the facilities for the education of Indians in the Province of Alberta.

Report by Hugh B. Wilson, Inspector of Schools for the Alberta Provincial Department of Education, on the education of the Slavey Indians at Upper Hay River, Hay Lakes, Bistcho Lake and Indian Cabins in Northern Alberta. This survey and report is the result of the request by the Indian Department to the Provincial Department of Education.

The Slavey band of Indians located at the above mentioned places are, at the present time, lacking in education, medical attention and department administration. There are no schools where any of the one hundred and fifty children may attend, and a few have attended the St. Henri Mission at Fort Vermilion. However the distance is great and the Indian parents do not wish to part from their children for the time required to receive an education at this school. Moreover the Indians do not want mission—schools.

The medical attention given these people is practically nil. A report on this condition may be obtained from the medical branch of the Department.

There is practically no administration given to this area by the Department. The following recommendations are made with the understanding that an Indian Agent will be placed in the Fort Vermilion area and that this section of the district will be part of his administrative unit. These Indians particularly need some person to advise and help them to care for their immediate needs.

In the following report I wish to stress that the first requirement is more administration and with it education. If the principals in each smaller district acted as sub-agents and advisers, as well as teachers, it would appear that this might be efficient and worthwhile guidance.

The education of this Slavey band, two hundred and seventy-five miles from a railroad, will by necessity cost much more than to operate the same sized school close to a railroad. The department should recognize this fact and be prepared to grant a sufficiently large appropriation.
CURRICULUM:

The education of the northern Indians should not have the same aim as for those of the southern bands. The Indians of this area will not come into competition with the general white population. They are now and will continue to be essentially trappers. They may, at some time, operate extensive fur farms such as beaver and muskrat. There could be limited agricultural activities which should be encouraged to facilitate in obtaining a proper diet for them.

The training of the Indian child should be basically a practical education. At the present time very few of these Indians understand English. They cannot count, calculate or solve the fundamental problems based on arithmetic nor do they know or practise the simple health rules. In this respect they are below the other tribal standards.

The curriculum should be so constructed that the Indian child will be capable of taking his or her place with the tribe and to know and develop better ways of trapping, home building and health development. The curriculum should therefore be simple and as the tribal standard is raised then the curriculum can be expanded.

The chief aim should be to keep the Indian a northern trapper and, at the same time, develop his native ability so that he may, if necessary, be able to meet competition from other traders and trappers. The Indians of this area and especially those trapping in B.C. obtain ample fur to give them a very good living; much better than they are now getting. They are lacking in relative values because they are not educated in the fundamentals as above mentioned. The curriculum for them should be less academic than it is in other Indian schools. It should be more practical. The standard set for them should not be the same as for other schools, it should be made particularly for this area.

Since the main purpose of giving some education to the Indians is to raise their standard of living much of this training should be practical. The boys now are taken on the trap-line by their parents at the age of twelve or thirteen. Here they learn the Indian way of trapping. This state should be allowed to continue and the boys should be excused from school at this age to allow for this training. They should also receive additional training in fur conservation and development from some source within the school.

The Indians are also endeavoring to adopt the methods of the whites in housing, clothes and diets but they are not trained in the crafts for such adoption. They should be given rudimentary courses in wood-craft and its associates, home development and its associates, and in the principles of health. The aim should be to have the Indians able to build and to know what to build for housing accommodation. They should know how to do simple machine sewing and mending.

The curriculum should be so constructed that the Academic training will be limited to a working knowledge of the skills such as reading, number, etc. and be commensurate with the use the Indians will later make of them. They should be able to read, write and have a working knowledge of simple arithmetic. This can be done by the age of twelve or thirteen. This could later be extended as the conditions warrant.

The teaching of health practices is one of the most important. This could only be done by actual usage. It would require the employment of a health and social worker.

It appears that this area requires a particular curriculum and that such curriculum should be carefully planned by the Department giving scope to the above suggestions.
TYPE OF SCHOOL - "A":

A day school situated at Upper Hay River would serve the families from this area and from Indian Cabins. The Indians from this area do not wish their children to be sent too far away to attend a mission or boarding school.

The enrolment at such a school would be between thirty and forty pupils and as this band is not increasing one classroom would be adequate for quite a number of years.

The location should be near the post and on the same side of the river as the proposed highway. This will be approximately two hundred and fifty miles from railway but it will be on the Yellowknife Highway and will thus be quite accessible. This location will also be advantageous in that it will be easier to get staff.

The curriculum for this school should be similar to that for the rest of the area although it may, of necessity, be somewhat restricted by the size of the staff. The building could be one similar to any modern rural school with a small work shop, kitchen and bath facilities. A wood burning furnace should be used as coal would be too expensive. The construction should be such that the material could be readily freighted. At the present time War Assets have two buildings within four miles of the post which could supply a large amount of the material. Good insulation should be provided.

The ideal staff for such a school would be a man and wife. Each should be able to do some of the teaching and each should be trained in some of the practical arts such as carpentering, home economics and health, and social services. The man could instruct in the crafts for the boys and the woman could instruct in the home sciences and do practical nursing.

In my opinion the staff of such a school should also be in charge of the administration of the other Indian affairs particular to this area. They should not only teach in the school but they should be the advisers to the Indians and the social workers amongst them. The success or such a school will depend on having that staff. The department should be prepared to pay sufficient salary and offer sufficiently attractive housing to induce the right people to apply for such position. The cost of this unit in capital outlay will, of course, depend on the non-construction. Transportation of materials will be less when the road is completed, presumably in 1947. I doubt if this unit, school and living accommodation, can be constructed for less than $20,000.00. The furnishing of the house must also be considered.

A day school will have the following disadvantages:

1. Securing a staff will be difficult.
2. Administration problems will be increased.
3. The regular attendance of the pupils may be difficult to obtain although the Indians at this post assured me they wished their children to attend this type of school.
4. Some children will not return to their homes each evening there may be the problem of health and cleanliness. However, this may help to inculcate some degree of cleanliness in the home. The school plant will require good bath facilities.
5. The school will probably have to remain closed in the winter at trapping time and remain open in the summer.
6. One balanced diet meal should be given at the school each day and this will require space, staff and supplies.
TYPE OF SCHOOL - "B":

Situated at Hay Lakes. The actual location of this school will depend on the survey which is now being made by Mr. Brown. The area adjacent to the lake is very low and flat and may flood at high water. There is also consideration being given to the raising of the lake. The trading posts are now situated on the banks of the river. The location would be suitable if flooding could be prevented. As this prairie is large and very flat, levels should be obtained for the whole area.

The Indian families at Hay Lakes are more scattered than those at Upper Hay River. As there are many more families in this area it will probably continue to be the centre of the Slavey settlement. The two lines are now well established and registered. There appear to be facilities for the establishment of a controlled extensive fur farm on the lakes.

This particular area will be some forty miles from the Yellowknife Highway. The winter trail is quite passable but the summer road is very bad because of the muskeg. The lakes are too shallow for the landing of water planes but planes on wheels can readily land on the prairie. With very little clearing and levelling a good air strip could be made.

The enrolment of school age children will be between 110 and 125. This will require at least four classrooms with extra rooms for the practical arts outlined in the proposed curriculum. These will include a room for shop and handiwork, a room for cooking and sewing and girls' handiwork, as well as a room which could be used for a playroom and auditorium, teachers' room, a principal's office, and a room for the nurse and social worker (this however, could be in the hospital or infirmary). Modern plumbing and washing facilities will be a necessity. To provide these will require a modern lighting and water system which might be obtained from some War Assets plant.

With these four classrooms and other necessary teaching rooms this area should be serviced with boarding facilities for the pupils as it does not appear possible to operate a day school. So a number of day schools in the area. The dormitory space required will be the usual for this number of children. Included in the dormitory should be rooms where the children may work or play if it is not sufficiently close to the school. The usual plumbing fixtures should be installed as well as facilities for giving a steam bath.

A small hospital should also be built in connection with this unit. The construction of this building should be such that all the boys or all the girls are not in one room. I suggest three or four to each room.

There should be a good dining room and kitchen with modern equipment.

I would also recommend that a house similar to that which the Department would recommend for the Indians of this area be built. A family of Indians could then be given the privilege of living with their children near the school. In this way some of the health habits and social habits which are desirable could be developed with the family. A change of families could be made from time to time. Such a house should be practical for this area.
STAFF:

The teaching staff of this school should be a principal and three or four other grade teachers. In my opinion the principal should also be the Administrator of Indian Affairs for the area. He should be able to develop, through the school, such ideas as co-operative fur sales, extensive fur farming, health services and in general advise the Indians. This man would need to be well qualified for the work. In addition to the three or four classroom teachers, a nurse and social worker would be required. At least one of these should be qualified to teach the rudimentary shop courses and to assist the principal in developing the other phases. One of the lady teachers should be capable of teaching sewing, cooking, preserving, etc. An ideal set-up would be at least two married couples who could all work.

The dormitory staff would require a cook and possibly a helper. Much of the help with the cooking and sewing could be done by the girls as part of their training. There should, however, be someone in charge of the boys and the girls. They will require careful supervision and training.

The total staff would, of necessity, be four or five teachers, a nurse, and four dormitory assistants. I estimate the cost would be:

- Principal - $3,000.
- Teaching assistants - 2,000.
- Nurse - 1,800 to $2,000.
- Dormitory help - 1,200 to 1,500

making a total of around $20,000, including janitor service.

SUMMARY:

A - Present conditions warrant special attention by the Department.

B - If this report and recommendations are not acceptable some other means should be found to give this band more administration, health services and educational facilities.

C - Two teaching units, one at Upper Hay River and one at Hay Lakes, should be established.

D - The unit at Upper Hay River could be tried as a day school.

E - The unit at Hay Lakes should be a boarding school under the administration of the Department of Indian Affairs.

F - Compulsory education should be required from boys six to thirteen and for girls six to fifteen.

G - A special curriculum should be provided which will be more useful to the northern Indians.

TO INSPECTORS WHO INSPECT INDIAN SCHOOLS:

After a conference recently with the Department of Indian Affairs, the following suggestions are made to Inspectors visiting Indian Schools:

1. The Inspector should be quite frank in reporting the weaker cases of teachers and in recommending the release of a teacher when deemed necessary.

2. The Department of Indian Affairs appreciates the Inspector's recommendation of additional equipment, of repairs to building, etc., and these matters will receive attention when funds are available.

3. Reports of inspection visits should be sent promptly to this office in the Department of Education, in duplicate, in order that a copy of the report may reach the Department of Indian Affairs as soon as possible after the date of visit. It is quite important that the Spring and Fall term reports should be forwarded promptly in order that prompt action thereon may be taken.

4. The chief object of this inspection service is to bring about improvement in the classroom practice of the teacher in these schools.

5. At the end of each half-year (June and December) the Inspector should send his accounts to the Department of Education for inspection of Indian Schools. These accounts should be rendered separately and should not be included in the Inspector's monthly account.

Note: Will the Inspector kindly keep this memorandum on file with other correspondence and reports relating to the Indian Schools, in order that reference may be made to it from time to time.

Chief Inspector.

October 12, 1937.

Dear Phil,

I was sorry that I just missed you, both at Port Arthur and at Sault Ste. Marie. Had I known in time of your being about to visit either of those places, I'd have done my darndest to get up to see you, as there are many things we might have discussed, among others, the effect upon Indian schools of the new curriculum just issued in Ontario. However, I'll be running into you one of these days, no doubt.

The object of this note is to ask if you could send me, say, two hundred Forms 142, Inspector's Report on Indian Day Schools. I use up quite a few of these in the course of a year.

With kindest regards,

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]

Philip Phelan, Esq.,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
Ottawa, October 19, 1937.

Dear Mr. Greening:

I have your letter of October 12th and regret that I missed you when I was west two weeks ago.

I had an opportunity last week of attending a Convention of Indian day school teachers in South western Ontario. At that time we discussed very fully the new curriculum just issued in the Province of Ontario and I feel that it offers every opportunity for Indian school teachers to teach those subjects which they consider most useful to Indian pupils. Apparently the new curriculum allows considerable latitude.

The forms requested will be forwarded to you.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

W.J. Greening, Esq., B.A., B.Ped.,
Inspector of Separate Schools,
Fort Arthur, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I am writing this letter to remind you regarding the transfer to me of the Indian School on Christian Island. This school should have been on my list from its organization as it is directly in my territory. It is only a few miles from Tiny Township in which I have all the separate and most of the public schools (catholic). I also have the Catholic Schools in Penetanguishene which is the nearest town and I also have Midland. I am in a position to do this school during my regular rounds and instead of paying expenses for an Inspector from Toronto to the Island, there would only be expenses from Penetang to the school and return. However, the real reason why the change should be made is that it has always been understood that Indian Schools should be given to the local Inspector and there is no reason why I should be discriminated against in this case.

That is my side of the matter but, if this should in any way be a cause of any personal inconvenience or difficulty to you I should be quite satisfied that you disregard this letter.

Thanking you, I remain,

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 27th ultimo enclosing a copy of a letter received by you from Inspector Clarke in connection with the report form.

For some time past we had received several objections from Inspectors regarding the form that we were using and very serious thought was given to the preparation of the new form. One of its very good qualities is that it is on a single sheet and, therefore, can be used conveniently in a typewriter, especially if the Inspector wishes to keep a copy of his report.

Regarding the grading you will note that "low" and "high" are divided into two sections. This makes four sections for each heading and as a matter of fact the first space would mean 25%, the next space 50%, the third space 75% and the fourth space 100%. Mr. Clarke considers that "low" should be divided into "poor" and "fair". This is exactly what we have done. If the teacher's appearance is poor a mark should be made in the left hand blank column under the heading "low" or, in other words, give her 25%. The other markings will at once occur to you.

The word "relations" has special reference to the efforts that the teacher makes to keep in touch with the parents with a view to encouraging them to have the children attend school regularly. I think you

V. K. Greer, Esq.,
Chief Inspector of Public and Separate Schools,
Department of Education,
Toronto, Ont.
will agree that this is a very important part of the work of a teacher of an Indian Day School as in so many cases the parents do not display the interest in their children's education that we desire.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Sir:

I note from your letter of the 16th ultimo that in the future you will inspect some of the Indian Day Schools on the Muncey Reserve, also the Mount Elgin Institute.

You can obtain the necessary forms for this purpose from the Department of Education in Toronto to whom we send a supply of forms every year.

As you are aware Indian schools do not necessarily have to follow the Provincial curriculum although our teachers endeavour to conform with the curriculum as far as possible. At the Mount Elgin Residential School the half day system is practiced in the case of the older pupils. This is due to the fact that we desire these pupils to receive as much vocational training as possible in order to prepare them for their future life.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,

Dear Sir:

The purpose of my letter is to find out from you further information regarding the pupils in the Indian School at Spanish. Is there any French taught to any of these pupils? I may say that we have changed the inspector of the Spanish School. Mr. W.J. Greening, Port Arthur, was the former inspector, and Mr. Carriere of Sudbury, who is both a French-speaking and an English-speaking inspector, now inspects the school. It seemed desirable that the one inspector should also visit the Indian School, and therefore lessen the expense for travelling, etc. Do you believe there would be any objection to placing the Indian School at Spanish under Mr. Carriere? Are there any other Indian Schools in this immediate area, or in Manitoulin, where in your estimation the French-speaking inspector would be as acceptable as the English-speaking inspector?

I shall be pleased if I may have your reply at your early convenience.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Chief Inspector of Public and Separate Schools.

Dear Mr. Greer:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 25th instant in connection with the inspection of the Spanish Indian residential school and the Indian day schools on the North Shore and on Manitoulin Island.

English is the only language taught in any of the Indian schools mentioned above and as we have always had one of your English separate school inspectors I feel that it would not be advisable to make any change at the present time. It is unnecessary for me to add that any of the English separate school inspectors on your staff would, I am certain, give entire satisfaction not only to this Branch but also to the staffs of the schools concerned.

Dear Mr. Greer:

On my return to the office this morning after three weeks' absence on holidays I find your letter of the 25th instant in connection with the inspection of the Spanish Indian residential school.

Macdonald, Separate School Inspector in Ottawa. As you are aware Dr. Macdonald inspected the Spanish school for several years previous to the date of his coming to Ottawa. The officials of the Indian Affairs Branch, who have made a careful perusal of the files relating to this matter, inform me that only two letters on the subject reached that Branch. The second letter is dated April 8, 1940, and is signed by the Chief Accountant of the Department of Education. Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Payment of inspection fees,
Province of Ontario.

I have for acknowledgment Mr. Jackson's memorandum of May 2 and also letter received by the Minister from Mr. S. Walters, Controller of Finances, Province of Ontario, attached thereto.

The records here indicate that the sum of $4,700.00 was included in the 1939-40 estimates for professional and special services and that this sum was exhausted prior to the receipt of the Ontario account, which reached the Department on February 14. It was not possible, therefore, to pay this account until funds had been secured by Governor General's Warrant.

It would appear that the amount of $4,700.00, included in the 1939-40 estimates, was equal to the amount that has been included in the estimates for this service for number of years. I should point out, however, that under the old financial set-up, appropriations, when exhausted, were replenished from such appropriations as the per capita grants to residential schools or from any other appropriations where surplus funds were available, nor was it necessary in the old financial set-up to secure a transfer from the Treasury Board. The Treasury Regulations now in force impose upon the officials the obligation to exercise the greatest possible -
possible care in setting up appropriations and in working out sub-allotments.

You will note from the draft reply to Mr. Walters, prepared for the signature of the Private Secretary, that only two letters relating to this matter reached this Branch. It would appear from the records that for some reason that one cannot easily explain it has never been the practice of the officials of this Branch to formally acknowledge receipt of letters requesting the payment of accounts or the payment of grants, unless the officials were in a position to make the payment at the time the letter was received. In the case of the Department of Education of Ontario, cheques for such payments are sent out by the Treasury and are not accompanied by letters from the Welfare and Training Service. I am of the opinion that all letters reaching the Department, particularly letters from the officials of the provincial government and from members of Parliament should be answered promptly, and in cases where it is found impossible to comply with the request contained in such letters, the receipt of the letter should at least be acknowledged. It is my intention to issue instructions to the Heads of the Services in this Branch, asking them in future to promptly acknowledge receipt of such communications.

Director.

RAH
Toronto, April 16th, 1940.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Music is now being taught in practically every school room in Ontario. In the rural areas, itinerant Music Supervisors are visiting the classrooms once a week with very beneficial results. The local boards engage these supervisors, paying usually $60.00 a year for a one-roomed school and slightly more for each additional room in the same building.

I have received many requests to make this service available to Indian schools, the latest from Cape Croker Indian Reserve in Bruce County. After discussing the matter with Mr. V. K. Greer, Chief Inspector, I am writing to you to request that you give some consideration to this matter.

If your Department could pay the salary of the Music Supervisor, we would be glad to recommend properly qualified supervisors who are already working in that locality. These supervisors would be under the authority of the local School Inspector, in the same way as other teachers.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan, Esq.,

Dear Doctor McArthur:

The officials of the Indian Affairs Branch inform me that, by an agreement entered into several years ago between your Department and the Department of Indian Affairs, provision has been made by you from year to year for the inspection of our Indian day and residential schools in the province of Ontario.

It would appear that in practice each school has been inspected twice annually and that payments at the rate of $15.00 per inspection per classroom have been made to your Department for this service.

You can readily appreciate that the Government, in this period of national crisis, is anxious to conserve public funds to the greatest extent possible. I regret to state, therefore, that it was not possible to include in the 1940-41 estimates a sum greater than the amount necessary to pay your Department for the inspections made during the period January 1 to June 30 of this year and one inspection per classroom for the period September 1940 to June 30, 1941. This decision will mean that during the years immediately ahead of us we shall make provision for one rather than two inspections of our Indian day and residential schools in Ontario and throughout the Dominion.

I am writing to you at this time, in the hope that you will be able to make the necessary adjustment in your own appropriations of this year with the least possible inconvenience.

Yours very truly,

D. McArthur, B.A., LL.D.,
Deputy Minister of Education,
Legislative Buildings,
Toronto, Ont.

THE DEPUTY MINISTER

Schools on Dokis & Garden River Indian Reserves.

Dr. J.R. Hurtubise, M.F., called at the office yesterday concerning a letter he received from Mr. L.F. Levesque, of Michaud & Levesque Ltd., Departmental Store, Sturgeon Falls, Ont., a translation of which is attached.

Dear Doctor Hurtubise:

I desire to refer to the letter which you received from Mr. L.F. Levesque, Sturgeon Falls, Ont., in connection with the inspection of the Indian day schools on the Dokis and Garden Village Reserves.

As you are aware, Mr. Charvon, the School Inspector, is a Provincial Government official but inspects some Indian day schools owing to an arrangement made by this Department with the Department of Education for the Province of Ontario.

For many years both the Dokis and Garden Village Schools had been inspected by an English-speaking Separate School Inspector. Some two or three years ago there was no English-speaking Inspector available and the Department of Education suggested that we use the services of Mr. Charvon. Recently the Department of Education appointed an English-speaking Inspector for that district and in a letter received from them, they intimated to us that, if we so desired, we could again use the English-speaking Inspector.

However, no definite decision has yet been made in that regard and, in view of your representations, I have arranged with the officials of the Indian Affairs Branch to notify the Department of Education for Ontario that we desire Mr. Charvon to continue inspecting the Dokis School.

Mr. Levesque's letter is returned herewith.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Doctor Hurtubise:

I desire to refer to a letter received by you from Mr. L. P. Levesque, Sturgeon Falls, Ont., in which Mr. Levesque discusses the inspection by this Department of the Dokis and Garden Village Indian Day Schools.

As you are no doubt aware, Mr. Charron, the present inspector, is a provincial government official, who inspects a number of Indian day schools, by an arrangement between the Indian Affairs Branch and the Ontario Department of Education.

The records indicate that for many years both the Dokis and Garden Village Schools were inspected by an English-speaking separate school inspector. Some two or three years ago, however, there was no English-speaking inspector available, and the Department of Education suggested that we use the services of Mr. Charron. Recently, the Ontario Department of Education appointed an English-speaking inspector for the district, and in a letter received from them intimated that if we so desired we could again use the English-speaking inspector.

In view of the fact that there are English-speaking teachers in charge of these schools, that the textbooks used are English and that English is the language of instruction, it is felt that it would be advisable to have the schools inspected by an English-speaking -

The officials of the Indian Affairs Branch feel that it would be rather unusual to request the Ontario Department of Education to continue the inspection of this school by a bilingual inspector. Some two or three years ago, however, there was no English-speaking inspector available, and the Department of Education suggested that we use the services of Mr. Charron. Recently, the Ontario Department of Education appointed an English-speaking inspector for the district, and in a letter received from them intimated that if we so desired we could again use the English-speaking inspector.

In view of the fact that there are English-speaking teachers in charge of these schools, that the textbooks used are English and that English is the language of instruction, it is felt that it would be advisable to have the schools inspected by an English-

Dr. J. R. Hurtubise, M. P.,
House of Commons,
Ottawa, Ont.
speaking inspector. The officials of the Indian Affairs Branch feel that it would be rather unusual to request the Ontario Department of Education to continue the inspection of this school by a bilingual inspector. These officials take the position that to make such a request would in all probability create a precedent that might lead to difficulties and misunderstandings in the future.

Mr. Levesque's letter is returned herewith.

Yours sincerely,

Enclosure.

W. J. F. Pratte,
Private Secretary.

Memorandum:

Re: General educational matters on the Six Nations Reserve

On Thursday, May 25, accompanied by Indian Superintendent Randle, I spent two hours with Mr. J.C. Webster, Inspector of Schools for Brant County. Mr. Webster was appointed last year as a successor to Colonel Joyce and is now the Inspector for the schools on the Six Nations Reserve. Mr. Webster brought up the following points:

1. Inspection of schools

He expressed a very decided opinion to the effect that two inspections a year instead of one would be very valuable in the case of the weaker teachers and also in the case of the new Indian teachers. He pointed out that one of the three new Indian teachers appointed last September should have done much better than she has and he feels would have done better if she had had some guidance early in the academic year. I advised Mr. Webster that I would recommend to you that permission be granted him to make two inspections a year of those Six Nations schools which he considers require same.

2. Books

As usual with public school inspectors, he brought up the old question of books. I pointed out to him the number of inspectors that we are dealing with all over the country and that our experience shows that in the majority of cases every inspector suggests different books. He realized our position in the matter and, therefore, limited his argument to books supplied for reading. As a matter of fact we have already requested the Government Stationery Office to place in stock the series of books mentioned by Mr. Webster and it is our intention to supply these books to the Six Nations schools for the academic year 1944-45.

3. Pupils attending high schools and collegiate institutes

Mr. Webster was very decided in his opinion that our present system of conducting Grade 9 in the reserve schools is not wholly satisfactory. He expressed the opinion that while the brighter pupils pass their entrance examination they should immediately be sent either to Brantford, Hagersville or Caledonia High School. He has received complaints that, while
our Grade 9 teachers do their best, they have other grades in the same room and consequently are not able to devote as much time to the Grade 9 subjects as they should. As a result many of our pupils, when they have completed Grade 9 in our reserve schools, find it difficult to keep up with the work in Grade 10 when they attend one of the high schools or colleges just mentioned. Mr. Webster is prepared to recommend those pupils who he thinks should be sent directly to high school rather than take Grade 9 in our own schools. He further expressed the opinion that it was advisable to continue the Grade 9 in our own schools for those pupils who do not desire to proceed to high school or college, but at the same time whose parents may wish them to have an additional year's education following entrance examination. In carrying the Grade 9 course in this manner in our schools Mr. Webster suggested that he felt it would be practical to drop French and Latin and concentrate on other subjects that would be of practical use to the pupils in after life. I pointed out to Mr. Webster that while I agreed that there was considerable merit in his proposal, at the same time it presented considerable administrative difficulties, due to the fact that it may prove difficult to convince certain parents that only some pupils having passed their entrance are sent immediately to one of the white high schools or colleges, while others are retained in the reserve school. He had not realized this particular point and agreed that this was something that Departmental officials would have to consider carefully. I promised him that I would bring this to your attention and that we would later consult with Indian Superintendent Randle with a view to making a definite decision in the matter.

4. Following the discussion on the above points we considered the possibilities for the coming academic year regarding teachers. From all accounts I do not feel there is much advantage in continuing the services of Mrs. Sandy. We found it necessary to dispense with her services some years ago and later we re-engaged her, but it is evident, both from her lack of interest in the programme on May 24 and the comments of Inspector Webster, that she has lost all interest in school work. There are one or two other teachers that we have in our Six Nations schools who are married women and who have only been teaching to oblige us. It is quite possible that they may leave on civil service duties at the end of June. This will probably mean that we will be looking for at least three teachers for the coming academic year and both Mr. Webster and Colonel Randle agreed that it was going to be a very difficult
matter to secure them. However, Superintendent Randle intends to interview immediately two or three Indian women on the reserve who were formerly teachers and whose household duties are such that would probably permit them to handle a school at least during the present crisis.

Inspector Webster is a comparatively young man and appears to be keenly interested in our schools and is also quite evidently anxious to assist both teachers and pupils as far as possible.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

EXTRACT FROM LETTER FROM W. E. DITCHBURN,
INDIAN COMMISSIONER, VICTORIA, B. C.,
dated September 27, 1927 - His No. 14779981.

Original on 59335-1.

Having reference to the report of the Special Committee of the Senate in Parliament, dealing with the claims of the Allied Indian Tribes of British Columbia, in which it was recommended that the Government of Canada should spend $100,000.00 annually in excess of its regular estimates on Indian administration for:

1 - Technical Education -

I am submitting herewith my recommendations as to how this sum should be apportioned and giving my reasons therefor.

---

1. Technical Education - $20,000.00

I am of the opinion that in the main the State should not be expected to go to any greater lengths in this regard for Indians, except possibly in a few special instances, than is the case with the education of white children. Technical education, so far as Indians are concerned, should not be considered anything more than a full course in manual training under competent instructors at all our residential schools, and as many of the Indian day schools as is practicable. There, however, may be a case crop up from time to time in which exceptionally well educated Indians might be assisted to take a course in some particular subjects. The main thing, to my mind, is to be assured that Indian boys, when they leave our residential schools, will have a practical training in order that they will be able to assist themselves after they have been discharged, and I believe that carpentry, joining and boat-building are the lines in which their efforts should be specially directed. The first requisite, therefore, in this connection would be to have a fully equipped manual training room at each of our residential schools where the boys who are properly instructed along the lines of work which would be most useful to them. For instance, there would be no practical purpose served in teaching a boy from an interior district how to build boats. Nevertheless, they should have a good knowledge of how to build houses, make furniture, etc. The boys from the coast districts should learn both. So far as the boys from the farming districts are concerned, their future is along the lines of agriculture, and it is important that they be given instruction by competent men on this particular study. It, of course, will take a few years to properly equip all of our schools.

Memorandum:

DR. SCOTT

With reference to that portion of Mr. Commissioner Pitchburn's letter of the 27th ultimo which is relative to technical education for the Indians of British Columbia, I have to suggest that the following be incorporated in a reply to him:

With reference to your recommendation that $20,000 of the special appropriation be available annually for technical education, I wish to state that I believe rapid improvement in our residential school work can be effected with this amount. I agree that different subjects should receive the emphasis at different educational centres - carpentry with emphasis on boat-building at one school, farming at another, etc. In farming communities, our schools already give a fair training in the subject and we should consider ways and means of improving this instruction.

Manual training has been undertaken with some success at the Coqualeetza, Kootenay and Alberni Residential Schools. At each of these institutions, the Department pays for the services of a special instructor and supplies tools and materials with which to work. There is also similar training instruction at the Nesolum Indian School. This system should be extended to other schools and I should like your opinion concerning the advisability of appointing a special organizer for this work. Such an officer could visit the various schools, determine what physical equipment is required, make the purchase and employ an instructor. On the other hand, such an appointment might not be necessary if we could get the principals and agents to enter whole-heartedly into the proposal. Perhaps a decision in connection with the appointment of such an officer could be better made after receiving recommendations from each school principal regarding the activity generally. I propose to circularize the schools with a view to learning just what trades would be most useful to the graduate boys and what additional equipment and services would be required to give an efficient training along these lines.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 11th with further reference to the matter of advancing the teaching of manual training in our residential schools and asking if it would be possible to expend $10,000.00 on equipment at once.

In reply I beg to say I regret it has taken so long for me to report fully on this subject, but it has taken some time to organize a system and to get data on what should form proper equipment, and besides this, other Departmental matters have occupied much of my time. I am pleased to say, however, that Mr. Kay, the Provincial Government's instructor of manual training, has rendered me valuable assistance whenever it has been possible for him to do so, though, of course, you will understand that he also is a busy man and has to travel a great deal to various points in the Province. I also am pleased to say, as will be shown further on in this report, that it is very doubtful if $20,000.00 per annum, as suggested in my letter of the 27th September, will be required each year for technical education, though, of course, as time goes on equipment such as that used in blacksmith shops, machine shops, shoe repairing, etc. will be required. This report, however, deals only with manual training in wood work as it is considered that all pupils in Indian schools should have a fair training in this particular line.

In April last I wrote to the Principals of the Kuper Island, Sechelt, St. Mary's, Kamloops, Cariboo and Fraser Lake Schools asking them what position they were in to carry out instruction in manual training to their male pupils. In short the replies were as hereunder:

Kuper Island School------The Principal stated that while he had a fair supply of tools purchased by the Department in 1915, six of the eight benches supplied them had been taken away for use at the Nanaimo Day School Manual Training room, and others would have to be supplied. He also informed me that the services of a manual training instructor from Ladysmith could be obtained, if necessary, but some arrangement would have to be made with regard to transporting him to and from the School each week. It may be possible that an addition to the staff will be made of a competent carpenter.

Kamloops School----------Reverend John du Planil will be very pleased to have a start made in manual training. He has a building 33' x 34' suitable for the purpose and he can get the services of the manual training instructor of the public school, at Kamloops, to teach his pupils.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
St. Mary's School, Mission----------Reverend Father Maillard was very pleased to hear about the new step being taken by the Department and he states he has a good room which can be utilized for manual training purposes. Instruction can be given either by a member of the staff or by the manual training teacher of the public school, at Mission.

Cariboo School---------------------Reverend Father Rohr advises me that he is very desirous of advancing the boys at his School along practical lines if supplied with proper equipment; but he regrets that it takes so much of the pupil's time in getting wood for fuel, and suggests if the Department would provide him with $2,500.00 per annum for fuel, he would be in a much better position to carry out our policy than he is at present.

Fraser Lake School-----------------Reverend Father Coccola, the Principal, states he has for some time endeavoured to give the pupils instruction along manual training lines and for this purpose he obtained some funds for the erection of a blacksmith shop and a carpenter shop, but the amount was not sufficient to complete the buildings and furnish them. To do this he said would take $1,200.00.

You will note further on in this report I am providing for the furnishing of tools and I will let you know in the course of a few days as to how much it will take to complete the carpenter shop.

Sechelt School---------------------Reverend Father McCaffrey's reply was not as satisfactory as I would have wished, as he was of the opinion that it would be a mistake to give Coast Indians any technical education as it might induce them to migrate to the more populous centres where they would have to compete with white labour. He is of the opinion, however, that a properly equipped plant for the repair and making of shoes for the pupils would serve a useful purpose. Father McCaffrey, however, is a new man in the Indian work and what I have seen of him leads me to conclude that he is most anxious to see practical. In view of the attitude of this School, I am of the opinion that no manual training equipment should be purchased as the phase of technical education at present being dealt with has reference to manual training only. Possibly next year the Principal may become possessed with a broader vision.

Squamish, North Vancouver---------Full reports on the desirability of putting a manual training equipment in the second story of the new community building have already been furnished by Mr. Indian Agent Perry. The room for manual training purposes is 40' x 42', and a class of sixteen pupils is assured with probably more, as some of the boys who have completed their school terms also desire to take up instruction in manual training during their evenings. The services of an instructor, a Mr. Shockley, have been secured.

As regards equipment for manual training rooms, I have found that in the public schools this comprises one

Drawing
Drawing Set for each pupil, one individual set of Carpenters' Tools for each pupil and one General Set for the whole class. Quotations have been obtained from several hardware and stationery firms for the articles required which go to show that the cost of each Drawing Set will be approximately $8.73; $9.69 for each individual set of Tools and Bench Screw, and $124.59 for a general set of Tools which will include such accessories as screws, nails, glue, sand paper, stains, oils, etc., etc., etc. These prices will depend entirely upon the prevailing discounts allowed at time of purchase.

As regards benches I may say that some time ago Mr. Indian Agent Perry furnished me with a tender from the Shockley Planing Mills, of Vancouver, for sixteen single benches 2' x 3'6" complete, the cost being $250.00. This works out at approximately $14.36 each. Mr. Kyle, however, is of the opinion that it would be much more preferable that the pupils should make their own benches and that they should be of the design shown on the blue print enclosed herewith. It will not in any event be possible to have ready-made benches supplied to schools in outlying districts and the only thing to do in this regard is to make a cash allowance of $12.00 for material for each bench, exclusive of the bench screw, which is included in the equipment of tools. So far as North Vancouver is concerned, however, possibly it would be just as well to get the benches made at the planing-mill, as the Agent is very anxious to get the manual training classes started.

Please also note that I have put down certain amounts for material for each school. This means lumber of various dimensions to be utilized by the students. A cash grant should be made for the first year, but thereafter each school should then apply to the Indian Agent for whatever material may be required.

In addition to the equipment for the above mentioned schools, I may say that Mr. Raley, Principal of the Coqualeetza School, at Sardis, wrote me some time ago asking for some further tools for the usual training room and blacksmith shop which he estimates will cost $50.00. These, therefore, are included in the list of equipment attached hereto which I would recommend should be purchased.

You will observe that I have included equipment for St. Georges School, at Lytton, and the new school at Alert Bay. This I have done in order to absorb as much of the $10,000.00 available as possible. The tools could be shipped to these Schools and stored until required to be put to use. At Lytton I understand the old school building is being torn down and the material is to be used for a carpenter shop, a blacksmith shop and a gymnasium in the second story. I have provided $1,000.00 being charged against the Special Vote to be expended on that portion of the building to be used for technical training, but this is only an estimate.

In establishing the manual training classes at the various schools, I would recommend that the Department supply each school with one or more copies of the book on manual training used in the Ontario and British Columbia Schools. This is published
is published by the MacMillan Co., of Toronto, and the cost is .47¢ per copy. Also one set of "Job Sheets in Practical Wood Work" (31 sheets). These are supplied by the Bruce Publishing Co., of Milwaukee, Wisconsin, and sold at .55¢ per set. They are used in the British Columbia schools and Mr. Kyle highly recommends their use. I have written to the Stanley Tool people of Montreal, for a number of copies of their book on "How to Work with Tools and Wood" which I believe they issue free to manual training instructors, and if I obtain the same, I will send one copy to each school which is being supplied with equipment.

The main thing is to get these schools supplied with the equipment for manual training and then to see that instruction is given along that line. In regard to instruction I may say that it will not be possible in all cases for the Department to make use of the services of instructors at the public schools. At schools in the outlying districts, the Department must be prepared to assist by way of cash grants to help pay the salary of a competent member of the school staff who is capable of properly instructing the pupils.

I have endeavoured to work this scheme out on a practical basis and I trust that my report will prove satisfactory.

Yours respectfully,

W.E. Ditchburn
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Mr. Ditchburn:

I have your letter of the 25th ultimo, with reference to manual training at the Indian schools of British Columbia. I am very desirous of getting this activity extended without delay, and, as a preliminary step, I have to authorise you to purchase the materials listed on the enclosure you forwarded. The materials for work benches, the individual and general sets of tools and the drawing sets indicated should be supplied to Kamloops, Neskonlith, Kuper Island, Cariboo St. Mary's, St. George's, Alert Bay and Fraser Lake Schools. The Department is already in correspondence with the Reverend Mr. Lett, concerning suitable workshops for St. George's. I rely upon you to purchase to the best advantage and to write to the Principals concerned, explaining the use to which this equipment will be put. You may also authorise each Principal to purchase lumber with which to work, as soon as the classes can be started. You may fix the amount to be expended on these materials from $50 to $100, as indicated in your letter, and you should direct principals to make requisition to the Indian agent for further materials, when required. Manual Training to Be Instituted In Indian Schools In Province By Federal Department

This is the handsome Indian school erected at Kamloops. It is one of the several schools under the direction of the Federal Department of Indian Affairs to which manual training is to be added to the curriculum in cooperation with other schools of the Province.

Manual training is to be instituted in order of pupils of ten years of age forming them that it is expected that Qualicum School at Chilliwack, and the Indian residential schools will be fitted up with carpenter shops. The pupil will receive instructions for two or possibly three days a week, but where there are sufficient pupils to make a class, one individual set of carpenters will be employed for each pupil, and one general set for the whole class. Besides this, a liberal supply of materials and tools will be supplied. In cases where equipment has been purchased for the various schools, it will be possible to give instruction to sixteen pupils in one day, and so forth.

There is accommodation for the following number of pupils: Qualicum eight, Fraser Lake eight, Lytton ten, North Vancouver, Mission eight, Williams Lake twenty-two.

After the courses in carpentry are well advanced, the system will be extended to include other forms of manual training according to the general educational requirements of the various sections of the Province.

INDIANS THE ADEPT

The Indians are adepts at woodwork, and it is thought that by teaching them how to make up various articles along mechanical lines they may stimulate their interest in their school work, but when the time comes for them to leave the schools, they will have a first-class knowledge of not only the various tools used in manufacture everything in woodwork used in daily life, thus opening the possibility of their being able to earn a livelihood in the future.

I note in your letter you state that the Department is anxious to commence a course in manual training at this school, and in this connection I may say that I have not found the manual training taught at our schools in the past to be of very great benefit to the pupils, and I am of the opinion that we would get much better results if this time were spent in giving them a proper equipment to farm with and teaching them how to handle it at the schools. In the past we have equipped hundreds of Indians with outfits of tools and fitted them up as carpenters and not one per cent of them are working at their trade on the reserve, and I do not know that the boy who has had manual training is any better fitted to go out on the farm and make a living than the fellow who has not. The general training that a boy receives at the school fits him for handling machinery and doing any repair work that might have to be done around the farm, and I think our efforts should be along the lines of agriculture, and agriculture only.

We found this out long ago. At one time at the Qu'Appelle School we had a carpenter shop, tin shop, shoe shop, and so on, and the boys received a thorough training in these lines of work, but this has all been done away with and I do not think we should start it up again. I am stressing this point, because I would hate to see any expenditure on this particular line of work, as I know we have not obtained results from it in the past.

Foreword

WHILE we are assured that the Department of Indian Affairs desire that the Residential Schools shall be centres of cultural education, we are also aware that they are most anxious that we should stress technical training. Hence, though we are not slackening our efforts in the classroom, as witness the fact that we have this year the largest number of pupils trying the entrance examinations, and have been successful in getting the Department of Education of the province to establish an examination centre at the school, yet we are concentrating strongly on technical training and vocational guidance.

We consider the most important step we have taken in that direction this year is the establishment of a Department for instruction in the internal-combustion engine, called Auto-Mechanics.

We feel this course will vitally affect the industrial advancement of the native people of British Columbia, inasmuch as boys taking two years in it should be capable of handling all general repairs to the engines of power boats. These boats, which have everywhere replaced the beautiful and graceful canoe of thirty years ago, are the mainstay of the fishing industry, whose products are sold in the future a large number of the boys—will earn a livelihood. At present if anything goes wrong with an engine, delay and great expense is necessary, as the engine has to be sent to some distant city for repairs, which often means the loss of a season's work and consequent hardship. If the boys are trained to do the repair work all this will be avoided.

In the matter of vocational guidance for the Indian girls and boys a very interesting movement is now afoot for the appointment of a Vocational Supervisor, with headquarters in Vancouver who can assist the graduates from residential schools to obtain positions for which their particular training and natural talents fit them. It is also suggested that a residence should be established in Vancouver, which would serve not only as a home, but as a social centre, for native young people who are either employed or are pursuing post-graduate study in the city. The need of this "follow-up" work has long been felt, and it is hoped that this step may soon be accomplished.

Heavy Bolt Re-enforced Drawing Tables

Our reasons for using heavy bolt re-enforced construction in our Drawing Tables will be of special interest to you, when we admit that we built our drawing tables of light material until experience proved that we were wrong!

Our Experience With Light Construction

Up until 1917 we used the ordinary light construction common to prevalent school drawing room furniture. At that time complaints began to come in to the effect that, after six or seven years of service, the tables no longer gave satisfaction. A careful investigation was made and we became convinced that the light construction was not satisfactory for school use. Drawing tables are higher than work benches or laboratory tables, pupils lean against them, creating a tremendous transverse and longitudinal strain, doors and drawers are jerked open and slammed shut, changes in temperature affect them, and ordinary construction will not stand the strain.

Present Sheldon Drawing Table Construction

As the result of the above experience our present drawing table construction was developed. To show this new construction clearly we turned a table upside down and photographed it for you. One and one-fourth inch panels and stiles are used throughout, and all joints are mortised and tenoned, glued under high pressure and cross-tie-bolted as shown. This construction, which increases the weight of our drawing tables twenty per cent, entirely eliminates the weaknesses found in the tables incorporating light construction. They will give years and years of service long after tables of ordinary construction have been discarded. The initial cost may be a little more; the final cost will be a great deal less. We build over a dozen different types of drawing tables to accommodate from one to eight classes. Literature will be sent free for the asking.

Dear Mr. Scott,—

I have your letter of the 19th instant No. 110-1-1, and I note your remark regarding the girls milking cows at our schools, and that you cannot agree that the girls should do the milking as a regular practice, but that you believe they should be trained to milk and that such training should be once a week during the summer time.

In my opinion, such a practice would result in very little benefit to the girls and would most certainly be detrimental to the cows, as the cows would not continue to yield a satisfactory supply of milk if milked by a different person each day. I think it would be much more satisfactory to have each girl milk a certain cow every day during the summer months. This would give the girls a thorough training in this important branch of farm work and would be of great advantage to them in later life.

It is also necessary for them to know how to look after the milk and cream and to make butter. It may surprise you to know that about 80% of the girls after eight or ten years' training do not milk, simply because they have not been taught to do so at school. They do not realize the value of it and consequently they do not enjoy the benefits they might enjoy if they always had plenty of milk and butter for their families.

Ottawa, March 18, 1931.

To Principals of Indian Residential Schools:

The Department desires, at this time, to emphasize the value of vocational training at Indian residential schools. In practically all our institutions, we find that the academic work receives proper emphasis. In the vocational departments, the danger is that, in the rush to complete the routine work, the instructional function will not receive sufficient prominence.

The instructors in the various departments, both domestic and outdoor, should be selected with as much care as your classroom teachers. They should be impressed with the fact that their most important function is instructing. For example, in the kitchen, occasionally, the girls assigned to that department should look upon their tour of duty as practice training for their future life and, among other activities, they should bake in the kitchen range a small batch of bread. Similarly, in the laundry, from time to time, a small washing should be put through entirely by hand, with the instruction side of the work receiving all the emphasis.

On Indian reserves, much of the gardening falls to the lot of the women, and this suggests that the teen-age girls in your school should be given training in this interesting outdoor subject. It is also true that, where cows are owned at Indian homes, the milking is nearly always done by the women. At Indian residential schools, summer milking should be done by the girls, under proper supervision. It might be advisable to have a special milking yard for the period and each girl who is receiving instruction should milk the same cow for one month continuously. Of course, the girls should be trained in the art of butter-making.

Indian boys who will go home to farming communities should receive a thorough training in farming, gardening and the care of stock. Those boys who will spend much of their time in boats upon graduation should have a full course in boat making and repairing and in gasoline engines. At all Indian residential schools, the boys should receive some instruction in carpentering - those showing particular ability being given a complete training as carpenters.

Principals, teachers and instructors should keep ever in mind the fact that the school is to prepare pupils for the future. Much of the expenditure on Indian education will be wasted if there is not a direct correlation between everyday exercises and duties and home life on the reserve.

Your obedient servant,
