I have nothing whatever to do with the judging which is left to the exhibition authorities to handle and do not know who act as judges. The Okanagan exhibited some work this year for the first time, due to the keen interest of the teacher, Anthony Walsh, but of course being a small day school, can not compete against the larger residential schools. Next year I will have the school exhibits in two divisions, Day and Residential, so as to encourage more of the day school exhibits.

Considerable work such as totems, basketry, etc., was sold to the public and good prices obtained for the Indians as a reward for their industry. The exhibition exhibitors gave us four times the space this year than has been allowed in the past and the Indian section was well patronised. One of the Squamish chiefs exhibited at the entrance a twenty-five foot totem made by himself and also lectured several times a day on totem lore but most of this was imagination and nonsense and the effect was spoiled by his continual plea for money.

The Exhibition has been a great success especially as far as our section was concerned, this being due to the committee of three, Mr. Macdonald, the general manager, Mrs. De Brilay, a keen student and collector of Indian works, and my own who has had the task of receiving, unpacking and displaying all the exhibits and is responsible for their safe return to the exhibitors.

B/HM.

The Small General Shop

In the Small General Shop, the fundamentals of several practical trades, such as auto mechanics, electrical work, machine work, wood work, mechanical drawing, etc., may be taught. The average size of one instructor shop such as outlined in this bulletin, will take care of 15 or more boys each period. With additional equipment a larger number of boys can be taught by one instructor.

The most desirable location for a General Shop is on the ground floor where automobiles, trucks, tractors, etc., may be driven in, so that they may be worked on by the boys in the motor mechanics unit. Plenty of light and good ventilation are valuable features. However, the ideal room is not always available and many shops are doing excellent work in rooms not originally intended for shop work.

If a school already equipped with a manual training or woodworking department the General Shop may be built up by adding the various units to that department. If there is no available room in the present school building it is advisable to erect a separate shop building. Some schools have built their own shops at a very small cost as a project in carpentry and building trades. See page 24.

The principal machine equipment of the General Shop consists of a back geared screw cutting lathe, a bench drill press, bench grinder and a forge. These machines, as well as a number of small tools and other shop equipment are used in common by all units of the General Shop, as the occasion may require. The average life of this equipment is about 25 years.

In planning a General Shop for the small school we have studied many of the leading manuals and consulted with many foremost educators in the subject. In addition, we have drawn on our experience of 25 years in our own manufacturing plant where we have trained more than 2,000 apprentices. The machines and tools in the shop equipment have been selected to meet the requirements of the boys in General Shop work from the 7th to the 12th grades.

Outline of a General Shop Course

For One Instructor—15 or more Pupils at One Time

The General Shop course outlined briefly below includes six important subjects that are widely used for instruction in shop work in the 7th to 12th grades. This shop is of a suggestive nature, and may be varied to suit local conditions. If any particular trade or occupation dominates the community, it should be included in the course.

Subjects Taught:

- Machine Shop
- Electrical Work
- Forge Shop
- Motor Mechanics
- Mechanical Drawing
- Wood Working

Principal Equipment:

In teaching the fundamentals of machine shop, electrical work, forging and motor mechanics, the machines and tools listed below are recommended. These are illustrated, described and priced on pages 10 to 13.

- 16" Back Geared Screw Cutting Lathe.
- 8" Two-wheel Bench Grinder.
- 10" Bench Drill Press.
- Forge and Anvil.

Also benches, cabinets and an assortment of small tools and supplies.

Room Size:

The size of the room required for a small General Shop, as outlined in this bulletin, is approximately 24'x36', or from 800 to 1,000 square feet of floor space. Plenty of daylight is a very desirable factor, but good artificial lighting is satisfactory.

Instruction Methods:

- Project system used (see pages 16 to 21).
- Blue Prints, Job Sheets aid instructor in teaching.
- Skilled mechanic may be called in occasionally for demonstration.
- Visits to commercial shops and factories.
- Lectures and class discussions.
- Study texts and reference books.
Machine Shop Unit of the General Shop

This is the mechanical age. So many mechanical devices are now a part of the ordinary farm and home equipment that elementary training in machine shop practice is essential. The ever-increasing use of machinery in offices, factories, transportation, construction and all other branches of industry makes the machine shop unit the most important part of the general shop.

Operations Performed

1—Sharpen center punch or cold chisel.
2—Measure and lay out work at bench.
3—Cut metal with cold chisel and hack saw.
4—File and draw-file.
5—Bend and shape.
6—Drill and tap.
7—Sharpen drills correctly.
8—Drill small holes in thin metal.
9—Drill holes in thick metal.
10—Sharpen the tools.
11—Turn center—mark and drill center hole.
12—Mount work on centers and set lathe tool to correct position.
13—Turn, face and bore to dimensions.
14—Machine cast iron.
15—Machine steel.
16—Machine brass.
17—Turn tapers.
18—Knurl in the lathe.
19—Cut internal and external threads.

Related Knowledge

1—How to read a scale up to and including 64ths.
2—The use of the micrometer for measurements accurate to .001".
3—Differences in lengths of fractional parts of an inch and how to use them.
4—How drills are dimensioned.
5—Sizes and kinds of common bolts, nuts, screws, etc.
6—Grades and uses of emery cloth.
7—Reasons for various finishes on metal and methods of applying.
8—Names of not less than 10 common metal working tools.
9—Reading of working-drawing or project plans made by the machine shop.
10—Names of various operations in metal work: turning, facing, etc.
11—Various kinds of metals, their uses and how distinguished.
12—Elementary heat treatment of steel.
13—Laced and glued belts joints.

Motor Mechanics Unit of the General Shop

The motor mechanics section of the General Shop is devoted to instruction in the care and upkeep of automobiles, buses, trucks, tractors and farm stationary engines. Old automobiles for demonstration and practice work can be obtained from dealers at reasonable cost. Some of the more important units such as the motor, transmission, axle assembly and differential can be cleaned and mounted on stands for study.

4—Repair puncture with a hot patch.

Electrical Unit of the General Shop

The ever-increasing use of electricity in homes, business, industry, transportation and communication, and the fact that so many people are employed in work requiring some knowledge of the fundamentals of electricity makes general instruction in this subject desirable. All electrical work should be accompanied by discussions and carefully selected readings on the principles of electricity involved.

3. Construct simple bell circuit.

Mechanical Drawing Unit of the General Shop

Mechanical drawing may be considered related work in each section of the General Shop. Some of the projects that the boys is to make in the shop may first be drawn or sketched in the mechanical drawing unit. This will familiarize the boy with the work he is about to do, and it will also impress upon him the necessity of making his drawings accurately.

1. Simple two view drawings of objects in horizontal and vertical lines with all edges visible.
2. Drawings involving invisible edges in two or three views.

Floor Plan of a Small General Shop

Designed by PROFESSOR WILLIAM E. WARNER
Ohio State University, Columbus

Shop teachers and public school officials are usually on the alert for new ideas and improved ways of equipping and teaching industrial arts work. The problem is unusually important and difficult for the small school and for the rural consolidated school.

After considerable study of the problem Dr. Warner has made a short report in connection with an extensive exhibit of such work at the Ohio State Fair in 1929.

The equipment described above provides provisions for a planning or drawing center for two pupils. Either cabinets or pedestal type tables may be used. Also included is a two or more speed wood-turning lathe, two double four-vise table-type woodworking benches, a portable hand drawing board, a small 6" to 8" motor-in-head circular saw, a 16" to 20" band saw, a good 6" to 8" jointer, a hand or motor planer, a drill press (portable), a 13" x 5' back-geared screw-cutting metal-working lathe, a portable automatic forge, including a rebuilt Ford or other engine that will drive a forge, bench, a sheet metal or soldering bench, an electrical area, and equipment for experimental and assembly work, lumber storage, blackboards, bulletin boards, a supply closet, and magazine racks.

The arrangement is not only convenient and interesting but efficiently planned as well. How many shop teachers would not be eager to get into such a laboratory? It may be termed a Laboratory of Industries, where individual pupils have opportunity for exploration and try-out. All of it can be housed in a room no larger than 35' x 70', which will cost less than two thousand dollars. Not all of the units need be developed at once, but those of the operation most in play afford for doing a better and more varied type of shop work.

Separate Building for General Shop

Many schools, in considering the installation of a General Shop, postpone action because there is no suitable room available in the school building. The illustrations show how one of many schools solved this problem.

On a corner of the school grounds a frame shop building about 25 feet by 40 feet was erected. The construction of this building is such that the cost was low but the improved conditions have been preferable.

The building is designed for ideal shop conditions, having large windows along both sides, affording excellent lighting for the entire shop. A large double door in one end permits easy access and mobility into the shop for use in the instruction of auto mechanics. Steam pipes running underground from the main school building supply heat. The floor is of concrete.

Some schools are fortunate enough to have an old shop building attached to an old building that can be used for shop work. Sometimes temporary school buildings, erected for use while the main school building is being built or repaired, are remodeled for shop use. Another plan is to rent a nearby building for a temporary shop.

In some schools a separate shop building has been erected as a project for the advanced classes in woodworking and building trades. The construction of a shop building is a good project as it may include experience in concrete work, plastering, electrical wiring, painting and plumbing, as well as woodworking.

Equipment for Small Machine Shop

Lineshaft and Countershaft Drive

The above illustrations showing the arrangement of equipment for a small machine shop are taken from a booklet entitled "How to Run a Lathe." This equipment is for larger and heavier work than is usually done in the small machine shop. The machines are driven by the countershaft drive type and are driven from an overhead lineshaft, the lineshaft being driven from a motor attached to the side wall.

The countershaft drive can be used in the General Shop instead of individual motor drive, but when the size of the motor, lineshaft, hangers, pulleys, belting and the extra labor of installing are considered, it is doubtful whether there would be any saving. However, if the shop already has several countershaft driven machines which are to be replaced, it would be advisable to retain that type of drive.

The individual motor drive equipment as shown on pages 10, 11, 12 and 14 is considered more modern and is much easier to install, as it affords a more flexible arrangement of the machines than the countershaft drive. The modern tendency in small shops is to install the individual motor driven type of machine.

Notes On the General Shop

Organizing the Shop. The General Shop should be the first shop built in any school. It should be located in a well lighted place in the building, preferably with an outside door. The shop should be thought out thoroughly as given in this bulletin as they represent the most popular industrial activities throughout the entire state. A fundamental training in these subjects is of importance to every boy.

Engineering Advice. If you are in doubt about the plan or lay out of your General Shop, method of placing the benches, machines, etc., write to us. Give us a rough sketch of the location of the shop and you will receive a plan showing location of windows, doors, ceiling height, and general dimensions. Our Engineering Department will submit suggestions and provide you with a blue print layout to meet the conditions and requirements of your shop.

Blueprint Plans of Other Shops. We have equipped hundreds of shops throughout the United States and have prepared blue prints of these shops. Many of the original drawings are on file in our office and blue prints will gladly be made available to any interested person whose instructor is interested.

Course of Study. The best method to follow in teaching the General Shop is the project method using job sheets and blue prints for each project made or handled in the shop. If you are not yet getting started in a course of study, write to us as we have abundant information and are able to which we shall be glad to supply on request.

Job Sheets and Blue Prints. We have job sheets and blue prints ready made and are preparing job sheets and blue prints for the course in woodworking, forgings, castings and other activities of the General Shop. Details regarding these job sheets and blue prints will be sent to anyone interested in the General Shop.

Reference Books. Suitable reference books on the General Shop are described in this bulletin. In addition there is a book on Auto Mechanics. This book will be a valuable reference in the auto mechanics course in the General Shop. A copy will be sent free of charge to anyone interested.

Making Wood Benches. Drawings and construction plans for benches of various types suitable for the General Shop are on file in our office. As we make our own benches because of the saving in expense, we shall be glad to supply blue prints of these workbenches without charge to anyone who is planning the installation of a General Shop.

Extending General Shop Activities. The General Shop will be found to be one of the most popular courses among the students in the entire school program. It offers practical, interesting training. As the number of students increases, the capacity of the shop can be enlarged by purchasing new equipment each year. To those who have already started General Shop work and are interested in extending their activities we have also sent plans and more comprehensive training materials, details of which we shall be glad to supply on request.

Printing in the General Shop. The fundamentals of the printing trade are also taught in some General Shops. Printing is a trade which has been in the United States hence offers a good field for properly trained personnel. The press, type case and an assortment of type make up the proper equipment for the printing unit of the General Shop. One of the best texts of the printing trade used in school shops is "The Practice of Printing" by Ralph W. Polk. Price per copy $1.50.

Farm Mechanics. The constantly increasing use of machinery in agriculture makes training in the fundamentals of mechanics essential for every boy attending consolidated schools located in rural districts. A course in Farm Mechanics is offered to pupils in the General Shop. This will be added to the General Shop Course outlined in this bulletin and include instruction in the following subjects: farm electricity, mechanical drawing, farm buildings, concrete work, etc. We are preparing a course covering the Farm Mechanics course and will mail a copy on request to anyone interested.

Purchasing Equipment. In this bulletin we have listed all the machine equipment, essential tools and accessories and reference books to make up the General Shop complete in every detail. All of these materials are in stock and ready for ordering the prices given in the bulletin, or may be purchased separately. Some of these tools may be ordered from your local hardware store if desired. We do not manufacture these items ourselves but list them for accommodation to our customers. Any item you already have in your shop or may purchase yourself may be omitted from the list.

Quotations Supplied. Itemized quotations will be supplied on all material described in this book and any additional supplies approved by you will be supplied upon request. The Educational Department of The South Bend Manufacturing Company sincerely invites you to serve to schools all over the world and will welcome inquiries from anyone who may be interested.

June 17th, 1932.

My dear Mr. Ferrier:

A gentleman in the United States has been corresponding with me concerning the Goodwill Industry idea. I am taking the liberty of giving to you a quotation from his letter received here of June 10th, 1932.

"I do not know your Indian Schools, their location, their curriculum nor methods of maintenance. On this depends just what could be done. Missions are learning to take whatever material is at hand and without expensive equipment make saleable articles from the very beginning.

I taught one season in the South and aside from the construction of doors, sash, etc., for our own work, we made cedar chests. These chests cost something like $3.00 and it took a fair sized boy to make one in an evening which brought $10. This was lower than the stores, brought ready sale, and some ten boys earned their way.

I do not think there is cedar up your way but there probably is black walnut at a reasonable price and other hard woods that would make up into fine occasional tables, jardinere stands, bon bon stands, screens etc., which pack in small space for transportation.

One thing I feel most sure of is leather and fur work. If there are deer and other skins they can be tanned very simply by any boy into valuable rugs and the fur to neck pieces. Bichromate of potash and hydrochloric acid make good serviceable chrome leather in a few hours. Then any old boy with a jack knife can cut fringe, thong and lace a cushion in half an hour which will bring $5.00 and cost a few cents.

And if you have art students in the school a whole world of dying, enameling, carving, turning, stamping, sketching, carding, graining and fluffing, can be done all by hand and double the value. There are hundreds of saleable articles from the leather coat down to moccasins, all easy to make and ready sale at a good price.

No need to mention the many toilet articles and cases made from the cuttings and even the scrap can be ground up into artificial leather. There is very little duty on leather goods to this country or on furs providing the furs are not completely finished, but Eatons or the Missionary Societies of the Dominion could probably absorb the output for quite while."
There may be even better material at hand and thus
either put in the school quite a number of new boys or
pay for boys already in. One thing is sure. No matter
where the school or by much industry if not practical,
that is if they cannot earn their way with it, it is
a failure. The reason industrial and agricultural work
has been so costly and disappointing is because they
are taught to do things with Western appliances and
methods that they as individuals cannot duplicate and
for that reason never earn their way or become independ-
ent. In my teaching, mechanics, have never used a text
book. We go to work on whatever we have, my bench in
the centre and when finished and sold, the boys get the
profit. Technical questions are explained as they arise
in the work and have built entire houses that way. Manu-
facturing in the school work will lift the depression in
a dozen or more cases and as soon as everybody gets
practical the depression is gone from the Dominion."

I think these suggestions may be of interest to you
in connection with the future of the Indian work, and if at
any time you feel like taking the matter up by direct cor-
respondence, I am appending his name and address:

Dear Sir:

Re-Manual Training Course for Students in Indian Schools.

In carrying out the work of above it was at once evident that the courses of instruction for Indian Schools would have to be very different from that work conducted in the ordinary schools of the Province at which white children attended.

Problems in carpentry and joinery, building construction and boat-building had to take the place of the smaller models which characterize the course for white children.

The Provincial Department of Education has been able to assist your Department from time to time owing to the fact that they had ample projects in Woodwork, Carpentry and Joinery and House-building but we have no projects in boat-building, and it is with a view to adjusting this defect that I write you.

Mr. T. Halliday, Marine Architect, 650 West Hastings St., Vancouver, is willing to produce a set of working drawings of a forty foot boat at a cost of fifty dollars. These drawings would be prepared specially for instruction purposes and would be well worth the money; moreover, they would be valuable to a great many Indian Schools although, according to Mr. Anfield and Mr. Jordan, the needs of the school at Alert Bay are of outstanding importance.

Capt. Barry, I may say, is in complete accord with this idea.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sir;

With reference to Departmental letter 1-1-11 dated December 14th and your reply of the 20th instant and numbered 182/32407, I beg to report as follows.

I have this afternoon had a long talk with Mr. J. Kyle, Director of Technical Instruction for British Columbia. Mr Kyle and I are in complete agreement with regard to the matter of plans for a 40 foot fishing boat.

1. Mr T. Halliday, of 650 West Hastings Street, Vancouver, is a Naval Architect, and is willing to draw a complete set of INSTRUCTIONAL PLANS for a 40 foot fishing boat for the sum of $50.00.

2. The above plans are quite different from the ordinary plans from which boats are constructed. They would be drawn for teaching purposes, and would be used to construct such a boat as a project in Manual Training.

3. The necessary reproduction of these plans as Blue Prints would be undertaken by the Department of Technical Instruction.

4. The fishing boat to be constructed from such plans would be very suitable for the purposes of fishing on this coast.

5. Mr. Kyle and I are quite certain that the boys of the Alert Bay, Coqualeetza, and Ahousaht Indian Residential Schools are well able to construct boats of this type under the instruction of the Manual Training Instructors.

6. I do not recommend that the Department provide engines for any boats constructed under this plan. I do think that for the first year or two, there should be a grant for the necessary lumber for the FIRST BOAT at each school, and that after this grant has been made out of the Special Vote, the schools finance the building of the next boat by the sale of the hull of the boat previously constructed. One boat should be made yearly at each of the above mentioned schools.

7. Mr. Kyle will visit Mr. Halliday on his next visit to Vancouver, and inspect Mr. Halliday's work. Mr. Kyle will then write to Mr. C.C. Perry, Assistant Commissioner for Indian Affairs in British Columbia, and make a report on the whole proposal.

I would recommend that no further action be taken in this matter till the report of the Director of Technical Instruction has been received.

Your obedient servant,

Gerald H. Barry.

District Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

Dear Sir:

Further to our conversation of recent date pertaining to my application for position as Manual Training Instructor, I hereby present an outline of my experience and qualifications:

I was apprenticed to the Woodworking business (Carpenter-joiner) in England at the age of 13. Two years later, I commenced to attend night classes, taking up theory for the teaching of Manual Training, and at the age of eighteen, I obtained a position as Manual Training Instructor at Shuben Industrial School, Halifax, Eng., which position I held until the Home Office closed the school in 1924. All manual training work at this school was under the supervision of Home Office inspectors, who laid out a schedule of work to be taught to the various grades, and an inspection of this work done by the boys was made every three months by the Home Office.

In 1924, I arrived in Canada, and obtained a position as Manual Training Instructor at St John's Industrial School, Toronto, which position I held until the spring of 1930. Then a new school was opened at Alfred, Ont., and over 50% of the boys from Toronto were transferred there. This caused a reduction in the staff, and as I could
not obtain another position of the same kind at that time, I entered the business world and have been engaged in some ever since. At the present time I am employed as district supervisor for the P.F. Collie Co. of Toronto, Canada.

I might say here, that in teaching manual training in Canada, we followed a wider field of work than was practised in England. That is to say, besides the usual model making in the class room, I instructed the boys in outside construction work and other handicrafts, with the idea of giving them a working knowledge and ground work to enable them in obtaining a position as an apprentice or helper to a carpenter or a construction company, when their time at the school expired.

If my services can be used by any branch or school under your supervision, I would greatly appreciate same, as my most earnest desire is to continue in the line of endeavour, in which I feel I can accomplish the most good, in the training of boys or young men, who have been deprived of serving an apprenticeship, or who desire to start in same.

I am enclosing a copy of an unsolicited testimonial from the Director of St John's School, under whom I worked. Thanking you,

I remain

Sincerely yours,

John Lawler.

My dear Mr. Hoey:

I beg to acknowledge yours of the 5th instant enclosing excerpts from your inspectors' reports for the month of December 1938. These reports are quite interesting and I am glad to notice that manual training in its various forms is being taken up with zeal in most of our Schools.

The tendency in quite a number of Catholic Residential Schools during the last seven or eight years has been to dismiss boy-pupils on or about their fifteenth year. This was done for two reasons:

First, the age limit for Indian Boarding Schools having been changed from eighteen to sixteen, Indian parents were very often insistent that their boys be dismissed on their fifteenth birthday claiming that when their fifteenth year was fully accomplished they were really to be considered as sixteen year old children.

Secondly, our Residential Schools being over-crowded, the older pupils were dismissed to make room for younger ones.

This condition has rendered manual training a rather difficult matter for boys. Indian children are admittedly about two years below the average white child in intellectual development. The consequence of this is that what can be taught successfully to a white child of fourteen years of age can only be taught to an Indian child who has reached the age of sixteen. As a consequence, all farm work and all mechanical training can be best taught to Indian boys when they have reached their sixteenth birthday.
This should be taken into account in any system of manual training which the Department may wish to institute either in Residential or Improved Day Schools. Doctor Westgate, in his memorandum on Indian education, a copy of which you must have on file, suggests that the age limit be placed again at eighteen. Most Indian educators would subscribe to this suggestion of Doctor Westgate.

What I have just said about Indian boys applies more forcibly to Indian girls and as far as the latter are concerned, the moral aspect of the question of age must not be lost sight of. Our Indian girls are exposed to great many dangers when they are dismissed from Schools at the age of sixteen. They are too young to marry and the home environment does not contribute to their moral well-being; the homes are so small that privacy of any kind is impossible of attainment.

The nuns who are in charge of our Schools have always made the statement that it is with girls between the ages of sixteen and eighteen that the best results in all the domestic arts can be obtained in Residential Schools.

At the present time, whilst Principals are desirous of keeping these girls after the age limit, the parents, relying on the Indian Act, demand the dismissal of their daughters and it is very difficult for Principals not to accede to the wishes of the parents.

Would it not be possible for the Department to have the Act changed or, at least, to give the agents and Principals some authority in the matter of dismissals from Residential Schools?

I hope to have time shortly to write you at length concerning the progress being made in manual training in the Alberta, Saskatchewan and Manitoba Catholic Residential Schools. I think you will be pleased with the response given to your suggestions by the Principals and by the Sisters in charge.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

INDIANS RESPONDING TO MANUAL TRAINING

Manual training in Indian schools is playing an important part in Canada's efforts to advance her Indians to a position of independence and self-support, according to Mr. J. H. Andrews, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa. In addition to the regular school work and equipment, the Department has endeavoured to emphasize the advantages of manual training and vocational instruction to the teachers by stressing the importance of such instruction in Indian schools and the response of the instructors and students to these efforts. These efforts have been a major factor in the success of the work.

Indian schools are equipped to provide an educational program designed to meet the needs peculiar to each school. When they are located, in order to fit the Indians for such occupations as may be within their reach. Courses in agriculture, carpentry work, tailoring and, in some cases, meat butchering are available for the boys, while at all residential schools there is given similar training in cooking, dressmaking, and hand-loom weaving.

Vocational instruction is now being extended to the day schools, where the Indians are taking a particular interest in the manual training courses. At one day school, the teacher reports that the boys in the manual training class have carried out extensive repairs to the school building in addition to doing work benches, cupboards, picture frames, saw-horses, and many other articles for use in the school.

Dear Sir:-

As suggested to you in our recent conversation, I enclose herewith a prospectus on Mink ranching, which I feel will give you a little clearer insight into the costs of animals, pens, and food, together with estimated income over a period of four years. Have viewed the feeding situation at the above mentioned points, and find they are all ideally situated, fish is in abundance at every point, with the exception of Brandon. Their supply can be obtained from Lake Manitoba without any great difference in costs.

There is plenty of time at our disposal for pen erection, also to acquaint those interested in the necessary ground work. The sooner these chaps make a start with this mink production the quicker they will be able to start out for themselves.

If there is any further information that you require, or any manner in which we can be of further assistance to you, will you please feel free to call upon me at any time.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd.) Morley B. Pirt.
Dear Sir:

I believe an effort should be made to educate some of our better Indian boys in the care and manner of operating a Mink Farm. In view of the supervision required I would suggest that this education be started at certain boarding schools where boys are enrolled from the bush or lake country.

I would like to see a start made at three schools, providing the principals are willing to undertake the work. I would suggest the following:

1. The Roman Catholic School, Kenora, Ont.
2. The Church of England School, Sioux Lookout
3. The United Church School, Brandon.

These three units would cost approximately $500.00 each or a total of $1,500.00. I would recommend Mink that produce pelts that will bring $10.00 to $12.00 each rather than a cheaper class ranging from $6.00 to $8.00. The cost of feed and care is the same, therefore it is foolish to start with low grade stock.

Mr. W. P. Pirt, perhaps the outstanding Mink breeder in the West, is prepared to supply the stock and has offered his services free of charge, except for transportation and meals. He figures two or three visits to each point might be necessary, after which further information can be secured through correspondence.

I am writing this because I believe it is the type of work that will appeal to the more intelligent Indian boy, and most of the bush and lake Indians can secure fresh fish at all seasons.

I would like to know if funds are available to start this work and if not would the Department consider including $1200.00 in the 1940-41 estimates for this purpose.

Mr. Pirt has called several times and I enclose a copy of a letter just received, together with his estimates of the cost of one unit. Personally I would prefer to start at three points and reduce the number as set forth by Mr. Pirt to 3 females and 1 male.

I would be pleased to hear from the Department concerning this matter.

Yours truly,

I am personally of the opinion, however, that very few of our residential school Principals have the training or experience, or even the inclination, to make a success of anything outside the routine school duties. It seems to me fairly safe, however, that Dr. Robertson is likely to take immediate steps to dispose of the mink now at Qu'Appelle it might be well to communicate with him in respect to the matter. The Department would have no serious objection to the transfer of a few of the mink now at Qu'Appelle to one or two of our residential schools in Manitoba. Dear Captain Barry:

I have your letter of the 27th ultimo and was quite pleased to notice your various remarks with respect to the use of the Job Sheets. I would like to draw your attention to the following fact: These Job Sheets are very flexible. The analytical sheet, called the Student Record Sheet, is very important.

After the pupils know how to handle a hammer and a saw, they pick out an article which appeals to them. For this purpose I am sending you, under separate cover, a list of plans for the use of the first year. If you think that these plans will be of any help to your schools, a set is available for each school and will be sent on their request. After the pupil has made his choice and it has been approved by the instructor, the tool processes are checked on the analytical sheet. From this sheet, then, the pupil and instructor notice which operation the pupil does not know. He is then referred to the job sheets and taught the operations, after which he constructs his object. You will readily see that the pupil always has an objective before his mind, which is of the utmost importance for efficient work. I am drawing your attention to this because to use the job sheets otherwise would somewhat destroy their effectiveness.

I would be pleased to read the suggestions and comments made by your manual training instructors. Nothing will please me more than to be able some day to visit the schools of B. C. The Minister read the report of Mr. Doucet following an inspection made of a number of residential schools in Western Canada. He expressed the view that it was an excellent report and inquired what work Mr. Doucet was doing now. He suggested that it might be well worth while to have him make a careful survey of the possibilities of increasing the teaching of manual training in the schools in Eastern Canada.

While it is appreciated there are more day schools and fewer residential schools in the east than there are in the west, the Minister thought that serious consideration should be given to changing the present curriculum in our day schools, which it is understood closely follows the provincial curriculums, and provide for more instruction in manual training and handcraft work. And, further, that if this policy is decided upon there should be a more thorough and frequent inspection for the purpose of seeing that the curriculum is carried out and what progress is being made.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER,

I am sending forward herewith a report dated December 20, 1941, received by me from Mr. Doucet, immediately following his inspection of the Maria, Restigouche, Lorette and Caughnawaga Indian Day Schools.

You will note with interest Mr. Doucet's reference, on page 3 of his report, to the Indian Agent at Maria. The service rendered by this agent since his appointment has never been wholly satisfactory. Mr. Jacobs, the father of the two girls mentioned in the report, is not a member of the Maria band but was visiting Maria early this year. At that time he asked the Indian agent to secure the release of his two daughters, who were pupils at the Shubenacadie Residential School, and the agent, without consulting us, instructed Father Macdonald to return the girls to Maria. We have found it impossible to return these girls to Shubenacadie until their case has been dealt with by the courts. Apart from the expense involved, this has been in my judgment a very unfortunate incident and one that could easily have been avoided if we had been able to persuade the Indian agent to accept instructions from this Department rather than from other sources.

This report on the whole, however, is somewhat encouraging. I was particularly pleased to learn of the willingness of the Quebec Department of Education to cooperate with us in the promotion of worthwhile vocational courses at our Indian schools.

Acting Director.

Memorandum:

MR. ROEY.

Report re Visit to Restigouche, Maria,
Lorette and Caughnawaga.

I wish to express my appreciation for the kind attention extended to me by Indian Agents, Dr. Richard and Mr. Bastien.

MARIA: I was quite pleased with the plan of the Maria School. The large basement consists of two rooms, one of which is used for domestic science and the other may be used for activities for the boys.

The school has no tools and no work benches. The rooms are at present rather dark. A whitewash of Casein paint would greatly improve the brightness and appearance of these rooms. A wood stove has been installed in the domestic science room. This was necessary for teaching cooking and to wash the military clothing that has been sent to be repaired, remodelled and distributed among the needy.

I was very greatly pleased to notice the splendid use made of the socks sent from military sources. These were the only articles received by this school, so far. These socks were unravelled and the wool rolled into balls -
balls. These machine-knitted socks consist of one-strand yarn, which is not suitable for hand knitting. The teachers, by means of the spinning wheel, twist this wool into a double-strand yarn, which then can be used for hand knitting. The Maria School has not as yet been able to prepare all the wool for this kind of work, as the school does not possess a spinning wheel. However, the Sister Superior feels sure that she will be able to borrow a spinning wheel from her Community.

Besides observing work in the classrooms, I had two teacher meetings, at which I outlined the subjects to be taught to Indian children. I dealt with the use of methods more appropriate to Indian education. I wish to express here that the teachers showed a great deal of interest and enthusiasm for the work of Indian education, and a translated extract from a letter written by one teacher to their Supervisor of Studies would, I believe, prove interesting:

"This gentleman, an ex-teacher, has entertained us for too short a time with his methods - pedagogical methods of a remarkable realism. Here I must say that his visit will leave its mark."

Re: Jacobs Family

Acting Indian Agent Cyr had ordered discharged from the Shubenacadie School the two Jacobs girls - one 11 and the other 13 years of age - for their summer holidays. This was done without the authorization of the Indian Affairs Branch. Jacobs was known to be irresponsible, and the fact that the Acting Agent allowed these girls to live in the home of an equally irresponsible old man, without any womanly care, seems to me an indication of rather poor judgment. I expected to be able to settle the whole matter at the time of my visit, but due to complications, as already reported, I was unable to do so. The Indian constable had affidavits from these girls -
girls of indecent conduct towards them. Acting Agent Cyr, instead of communicating with this Department, made a report to the Provincial Police at Quebec City, asking them to conduct an investigation. This, it appeared to me, was taking the matter completely out of our hands. In his last report Mr. Thibault warned Acting Agent Cyr that this method of procedure could not be tolerated and that when he was in doubt he was to consult this office before making any decision. This, the Acting Agent is unwilling or unable to do. If this procedure is allowed to continue, I fear many unnecessary difficulties are bound to arise frequently.

RESTIGOUCHE.

I observed the work in each classroom. The reading in general is good. The methods used are the conventional methods generally used in the classroom. A change of method in some instances was recommended. Methods more suitable to Indian education were explained at the teachers' meetings; two such meetings were held. At the first of these meetings the Pastor and his assistant were present. At the teachers' request, another meeting was held on Saturday. I wish to give these details to show the eagerness with which the teachers endeavor to accept all help given them. I am confident that complete co-operation will be given by the teachers of both Maria and Restigouche.

Re Military Clothing -
Re Military Clothing:

The use made of the clothing given at the Restigouche School is truly worthy of mention. The socks are unravelled and the wool is then twisted into a 2-strand yarn, by means of the spinning wheel. Then the children knit hose for themselves. I have witnessed the whole process and have examined a completed pair of stockings. The result would do credit to any institution. I have also seen skirts and jackets made from sailors' trousers. These appeared as beautiful as new articles. I examined dresses made by the girls and also gloves made from used wool. The teachers deserve commendation for the splendid use made of the used clothing sent to them. Besides clothing these children, the training given them in the use of used material is beyond doubt the best training that can be given them.

Re Manual Training and Agriculture for the Boys

I had several meetings with Mr. Arsenault, the new farming instructor. I feel confident that here we have an ideal set-up. During the winter months the instructor can teach manual training to the boys and prepare the boys and girls for gardening. A school garden is all important, and the pupils should also be encouraged to have their own garden plots at home. Using the proper methods of encouragement, competition, various clubs, etc., great results may be expected. I was pleased to note that school gardens had already been started at the school. Here, with the co-operation of the authorities on the reserve, the home and the school, the results should be very satisfactory. The concerted effort of these three agencies towards one objective cannot but produce splendid results. In order to bring the home more efficiently into the cycle, a Parent School Association is being organized at Restigouche. A definite program was discussed with the Pastor and the teachers - this to be followed with a definite outline of procedure, objectives, etc.
On my way back to Quebec City, I stopped at Rimouski, to interview the Director of Studies for the Congregation of the Holy Rosary, Mother Mary St. Fortunat. We had a 2-hour discussion on educational methods and subjects that should be taught in our Indian schools. She is very anxious to co-operate with the Department; she is even anxious to train the teachers that will take charge of our schools along the lines we wish to indicate. I am very pleased with her extended cooperation on these teachers. They are willing, I might say, they are anxious to follow the directions we wish to give them. I hope that it will be possible to revisit this school in order to make sure that they are using the right principles necessary for success.

Quebec City

In my interview with B. O. Filteau, Secretary of the Catholic Council of Education, I discussed the problem of preparing our students to live. The claim of cultural course as given by the Provincial Course of Study does not meet the requirements of our schools. This, Mr. Filteau has readily conceded. He has promised full co-operation in the promotion of a program suitable for Indian schools. He feels we are justified in corresponding directly with the inspectors responsible for the inspection of our schools.

I also interviewed Mr. Percival, Director of the Protestant Board of Education. He also has offered us the full co-operation of his department. He wishes us to issue instructions to the inspectors when he deems it necessary. I must say that I was cordially received by these officials. This co-operation is sure to result in a better understanding between those responsible for the administration and inspection of our Indian schools.
While at Quebec City I visited the Technical School, to study the methods that they are following. The methods followed in this school would not, I believe, give us in our schools the results we would expect.

MONTREAL

In Montreal I had an interview with Instructor A. E. Wescott, of the Caughnawaga School. I discussed with him the difficulties he met with in introducing woodwork at this school. I gave him definite directions by which he could overcome these difficulties. I let him understand that I would send him definite instructions on the manner of using the analytical sheet and the plans supplied to them from this Department. I also passed part of an afternoon in his shop while he was instructing the pupils. I was quite pleased with the attitude of the pupils in general. They have shown a great deal of skill in the work completed so far. The progress made is quite satisfactory, under existing conditions. The fact that some of the pupils have asked to put in extra time is quite significant.

I visited the U. C. School, which was closed due to convention at my last visit, and had a meeting with the teachers, after school. The teachers are doing good work. I had met these teachers, however, on my last visit in Montreal. They have carried out the suggestions made at this meeting and state that they are very pleased with the results. As for manual training, another attempt is to be made by the teachers and the Minister, Mr. Wheeler, to send the two or three boys old enough to take manual training to attend the classes given at the R. C. School. This is to take place on Thursday afternoon, if arrangements can be made. I discussed the problem with Mr. Wheeler. He made this suggestion and is to make a survey of the possibilities of carrying out the plan. Junior activity may be carried out by Miss Bryan, while Miss Joblin instructs the girls in sewing. A survey is to be made on the possibility of forming a student council in order to develop responsibility among the pupils.

Lorette -
LORETTÉ:

At Lorette, conditions that do not exist in any other of our schools require special attention. Instruction in this school is carried out in the French language - the language spoken in general in the surrounding community. The teachers state that their greatest difficulty seems to be the teaching of language. Definite instructions were given in order to overcome this difficulty, which seemed to be due to the fact that too much was attempted. This school possesses a few tools but has no space outside of the classroom itself where this activity could be carried on. The teachers are anxious to have specific directions as to the work that should be carried on. As these teachers are not very familiar with the English language, all directions will of necessity have to be given them in the French language. This will entail a great deal of work in translating into French the various directions we have given to the other schools.

Respectfully submitted,

[Signature]

DOCTOR MCGILL,

As you are aware, increased efforts have been made, since Mr. Doucet was appointed, to encourage the teaching of vocational work at the Indian residential and day schools. It would be appreciated if you would advise the Representative of the Treasury accordingly.

R.A. Hosy,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Mr. Archibald:

RECOMMENDATIONS

During my thirty years experience with Indians and Halfbreeds I have observed, where such people have an opportunity to receive either manual or domestic training, by attending training schools or through association with persons in places of business or homes, a fair percentage of them become quite proficient and useful citizens. Observation during my trip down the Mackenzie River, showed a definite decrease in practical knowledge and ability of these people as I proceeded north. Discussing the matter with Drs. Truesdell, Harvey and Livingstone all agreed with me, that manual training to include agriculture, animal husbandry, horticulture, carpentry and general mechanics should be included in the school curriculum and that experts should be engaged to give such instruction. While it must be admitted that such training, no matter how efficient it might be, would not increase the intelligence one hundred percent, I am of the opinion that a large percentage would become better able to serve a more useful purpose in the development of the country, for they would at least provide a source of intelligent help, which at present is almost un procurable.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa,
January 29, 1943.

To principals and teachers of Indian schools:

Re: Proficiency Badges

As illustrated by Mr. Doucet on various occasions, the proficiency badges will soon be ready and it is our intention to award badges for cooking, sewing, weaving, knitting, housekeeping, gardening, leather work, dairying and poultry raising.

Before making these badges available the Indian Affairs Branch desires the teachers of the various manual skills to make a list of the basic operations which, in their opinion, the pupil should cover for each year of a three-year course in order to entitle the pupil to receive a badge.

These basic operations should be progressive from the easiest to the more difficult. It must be kept in mind that the operations listed must be basic; namely, operations that are absolutely necessary in carrying out the simple duties of a housewife, or a cook etc. There should be about twenty basic operations for each year.

Principals should notify the teachers concerned and forward their lists as soon as possible to the Training Division, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
To principals and teachers of Indian schools:

Re: Chart for Proficiency Badges

You are being forwarded two charts illustrating the proficiency badges about which you were advised in circular letter of January 29, 1943. These charts should be framed and one posted in the boys' side of the building and the other in the girls'.

You will note that these charts indicate the basic operations which pupils must know in order to qualify for a badge.

When a pupil has efficiently covered the first group of basic units a green badge is awarded. When the second group is covered a red badge is awarded. Later you will be advised regarding the badge which will be awarded for covering the third group of basic units.

In the majority of cases it will require one year for a pupil to cover each of the groups of basic units. In some cases a pupil may cover this group in less time than a year, while other pupils will require a longer period than a year.

For reasons that will readily suggest themselves to you, it has been decided not to award any badge to a pupil under twelve years of age. It is true that some of the operations recognized for badges will have been learned before that age is reached, but these operations will not be recognized for badge purposes until the age mentioned.

When a pupil has qualified for a badge a special form is signed by the instructor and the principal and forwarded to this office. The badge will then be sent to the pupil. This badge should be awarded publicly as soon as possible after its reception, either by the Student Council or any similar school organization.

Teachers should keep in mind that the success of any enterprise depends on the enthusiasm shown by the teachers themselves. The Department, therefore, depends upon principals, teachers and instructors to use every possible effort to create interest and enthusiasm among the pupils in the badge system.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Before making these badges available the Indian Affairs Branch desires the teachers of the various manual skills to make a list of the basic operations which, in their opinion, the pupil should cover for each year of a three-year course in order to entitle the pupil to receive a badge.

These basic operations should be progressive from the easiest to the more difficult. It must be kept in mind that the operations listed must be basic; namely, operations that are absolutely necessary in carrying out the simple duties of a housewife, of a cook etc. There should be about twenty basic operations for each year.

Principals should notify the teachers concerned and forward their lists as soon as possible to the Training Division, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Tue., May 18
An interesting display at the exhibition is that of the work done by Indian pupils throughout the province. Classes include writing, manual training, sewing, mechanics, art, social studies and hobbies.

Big winners were pupils of the Thunderchild Industrial School, Lloydminster; the residential school at St. Philips and the residential day school at Duck Lake. Awards were as follows:

* **Grade 1 – Margaret Henderson, Anglican Indian Res. School, Lloydminster**
* **Grade 2 – Glenna Ray, Anglican Indian Res. School, Lloydminster**
* **Grade 3 – Lucille Sansom, Anglican Indian Res. School, Lloydminster**
* **Grade 4 – Elmira Brown, Anglican Indian Res. School, Lloydminster**

The exhibits on display include paintings, drawings, and miniatures made by the students.

**Bright Indian Work Displayed**

Gaudy-colored bead jackets, of what can be done by hand, are striking to the eye. They represent work of half-breeds as well as full-bloods Indians.

Drawings, paintings and miniature figures in skeletons, depict the skull of the Indians. Tiny tepees, patterned to fit miniature buffalo skin hides, used in the Indian encampment, are also on display.

Attention has been drawn to the Indians' full dress and headgear, tomahawk, and snowshoes.

Soapstone pipes, moccasins, used for household use made from tin cans further demonstrate the ingenuity of the students.

There is a definite contrast in designs on exhibits entered by full-breed and half-breed Indians. The half-breed designs, especially on wearing apparel on display, are extremely attractive. The exhibits themselves are in conservative colors. Designs on pieces of furniture vary and are mostly square-shaped. The exhibits are brightly-colored.

One of the Indians' wares on display are fruit and pickle preserves, a new class of Indian exhibit. These are canned wild and cultivated fruit, jam made of wild and cultivated apples and cucumbers.

The entries are from scattered reserves in the province and compared favorably with past years. These items are increasingly popular in some of the sections.

Dear Mr Hoey,

I trust apologise for a little delay in sending my thanks to you for the copy of the new Technical Training Courses for Boys and Girls in the Indian School with samples of the Padres, etc. In these as in all school work the prime factor in success is of course the teacher; and as one of fifty years experience in the field of education in Great Britain, the U.S.A., and to my regret a very small degree in Canada, I beg your forbearance in writing that until the teachers in our B.C. Indian Schools have special preparation for this line of work we must not expect the results some of us desire. However, you do not ask for my opinion, so I apologise for intruding it upon you.

I think you will feel our Society, struggling against great difficulties in yet serving these "Wards of the Federal Government." Last year I was nominated to their Indian Committee by the Canadian Handicraft Guild as well as Anthony Walsh. The result is that for the very first time some examples of our B.C. Indian skill has been shown at this year's Exhibitions of Handicrafts not only in Montreal but at the Royal Academy of Quebec. Possibly you know that for the first occasion in its 67 years of existence the Quebec Royal Academy opened its doors to a few examples of Handicrafts, metal, pottery, weaving, etc. Articles submitted had to satisfy 3 Committees to gain a place; the beautifully fine basketry of two Nootka women were selected and perhaps one of the finest reproductions in needlework of a complicated Haida design I have ever made; more intricate even than the much larger specimen I worked by our Queen's request. This week I have received a cutting from The Montreal Star of Oct. 8th, which gives space to the fact that examples of highly praised handicrafts from four of our B.C. Indian Schools were on view at this "All Canada" Handicrafts Exhibition; a small testimony of our work among them. We had no prior notice of the exhibition that it was no easy undertaking to collect these specimens; the schools were closed, children and teachers dispersed except at the Christie and the Alex Bay schools; the other two schools which earned this approbation were Inkaneeep (paintings on doe skin executed before Anthony Walsh left) and St Catherine's School, Duncan.

Trusting I have not trespassed unduly on your time,

Sincerely yours,

Alice Ravenhill.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.

I have just been reviewing our expenditures from the B.C. Special appropriation for the nine-month period April 1 to December 31, 1945. As you are aware, $10,000.00 of the total amount was assigned to technical education. Part of the 1945-46 allotment lapsed at the end of March last and for the nine-month period under review it would appear that a considerable amount will lapse at the end of March, 1946.

I realize that the residential schools and the day schools at which vocational training is given in British Columbia are becoming fairly well supplied with necessary equipment and consequently the only expenditure necessary in this particular regard will be for some replacements. Highly qualified instructors are unavailable at the present time and consequently the increased expenditure that might be made for their salaries is unnecessary.

It is possible that you could secure some materials for the use of the vocational training classes at the schools where this is taught and this would ensure a supply for some months to come. If you feel it is desirable to take this action, the total expenditure between now and the end of March should not exceed $2,000.00.

However, I think the time has arrived to give the matter very serious consideration with a view to determining if we should make advanced education
available for more pupils. I refer particularly in this regard to vocational training. This might include encouraging some of the more qualified girls to take nursing courses. Evidently the Coqualeetza Hospital is having considerable difficulty in securing staff and it is quite possible that this condition may continue for some years to come.

With the contents of this letter in mind I wish you would give the matter some consideration and let me hear from you.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

Memorandum:

MR. ROEY.

With reference to our recent interview regarding an increased effort to encourage vocational work at certain schools, I have again discussed the whole matter with Mr. Doucet.

To carry out a proper vocational program, it is necessary to have a qualified teacher. It is possible that qualified teachers can be secured for the academic year 1945-46.

The residential schools and the larger day schools in British Columbia have given considerable attention to vocational work for many years and have been assisted in that regard by the allowance of part of the salary of the teacher, plus the supplying of equipment and supplies. Funds for this purpose are available in the B.C. Special Appropriation.

In each of the fiscal years 1943-44 and 1944-45 we provided a special amount of $7,500.00 for vocational equipment at residential and day schools other than in British Columbia. A similar amount is included in our appropriation for the fiscal year 1945-46.

However, we do not make any allowance towards the salary of qualified vocational teachers as we do in British Columbia. Owing to the financial condition of most of our residential schools, I believe that it will be necessary for us to make an allowance towards the salary of the vocational teacher, if we wish the work to be handled in a proper manner.

In view of the above, I recommend that provision be made for the following funds in a supplementary estimate when Parliament reconvenes:

1. AN AMOUNT OF $17,250.00 TO ASSIST CERTAIN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOLS IN SECURING QUALIFIED VOCATIONAL TEACHERS AND IN ENGAGING VOCATIONAL TEACHERS AT CERTAIN DAY SCHOOLS.

If the above amount were available, we would communicate with the residential schools we have in mind for the academic year 1945-46 and advise them that the Department is prepared to make an allowance of one-half the annual salary of a vocational teacher, provided such teacher could be secured for $1,500.00 a year, or less. This would mean a maximum allowance from the
Department of $750.00 for the academic year. If a teacher could be secured at a lower salary, the allowance by the Department would be proportionately less. On their part the residential school would be required to pay the other half of the salary and provide room and board. Before any residential school would be allowed payment of half the salary for the vocational teacher, it would be necessary for them to submit the name, address and qualifications of the person they propose to appoint. In order that the Department may assure itself that such teacher possesses the necessary qualifications. The residential schools that we suggest be given this offer for the academic year 1945-46 are as follows:

**ONTARIO:**
- Cecilia Jeffrey
- Fort Frances
- Mohawk Institute
- Shingwauk
- Sioux Lookout
- Spanish

**MANITOBA:**
- Birtle
- Brandon
- Elkhorn
- Pine Creek
- Portage la Prairie
- Sandy Bay

**SASKATCHEWAN:**
- Qu'Appelle
- Duck Lake
- Cowessess

All of these schools have some facilities at the present time and it is felt that the suggested program would function well at them.

In the case of the day schools, it will be necessary to pay the full salary of the vocational teacher and in these cases also we should have authority to employ a qualified vocational teacher at a salary not exceeding $1,500.00 a year. The day schools suggested for this increased activity for the academic year 1945-46 are as follows:

**QUEBEC:**
- Caughnawaga
- St. Regis

**ONTARIO:**
- Six Nations No. 3
- Rama

At all of these schools considerable vocational work has already been done and it is felt that decided progress would be made if a fully qualified teacher was engaged.

2. AN ADDITIONAL AMOUNT OF $5,000.00 FOR EQUIPMENT AND MATERIAL.

As mentioned above, $7,500.00 is available in the current year's appropriation for the purchase of vocational equipment and material, but, if the proposed intensive program is carried out, an additional amount of $5,000.00 might be required.

The total -
The total estimated expenditure would therefore be:

Allowance towards Salaries of Teachers .... $17,250.00

Equipment and Supplies ............... 5,000.00

Total ...... $22,250.00

Arrangements will be made to have Mr. Doucet visit these schools early in the new academic year, with a view to determining the specific procedure to be followed for vocational work.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa, June 6, 1945.

MEMORANDUM:

- The Deputy Minister -

Re: Promotion of Vocational Instruction.

I am sending forward herewith a memorandum received by me from the Chief of the Training Division.

An attempt has been made during the last three or four-year period to organize worthwhile vocational courses at Indian Residential Schools and at a number of Indian Day Schools. Suitable subjects and courses have been outlined and a measure of progress has been made; however, in that fully qualified teachers have not been available for this work and latterly it has been increasingly difficult to secure tools and equipment. A careful survey of our whole field of educational effort has recently been undertaken. We have decided to ask Mr. Doucet to devote practically all of his time to the organization of vocational courses at Day and Residential Schools. The recommendation made by Mr. Phelan that a supplementary estimate be asked for to enable us to start this program at the beginning of the next academic year (September 1st) is well worthy of consideration. This program of vocational instruction might well be carried out in conjunction with the program of Physical Fitness, for the organization which Major Eisehardt of the Department of National Health and Welfare is responsible. It is unnecessary to say that I shall be glad to discuss this matter with you personally at any time.

Dear Father Lavigne:

I understand from Mr. Doucet that when he was in the West recently he discussed with you our desire to make an increased effort to encourage vocational work at certain residential schools during the current academic year. As you know, it has not been our policy, in the past, to pay any amount towards the salary of teachers at residential schools, but we are hopeful that the Principals of certain schools, at least, will co-operate with us in having this important phase of education placed on a firm basis.

Our proposal for the current academic year is that if certain residential schools can obtain a qualified vocational teacher, the Department will pay one-half the salary provided the service of a teacher can be secured for $1,500.00 or less. Dear Mr. Melan:

In reference to your letter of the 14th Inst. regarding the hiring of a vocational teacher for the school here, I have consulted many times with the staff and put before them a financial condition report. We do not see it at all possible. We have two paid teachers already plus several other workers in the house who are drawing monthly wages.

It is very regrettable that the offer cannot be accepted. We have looked at it from every point of view and discussed it several times at great length, but financially it is impossible.

From a point of view of the class work, these boys come for the most part with no previous schooling or it is not until they are here three or four years that they can be put at any work which takes them from the three Rs. The boys from grade five and up are the only ones who really have enough school work done to give time to the vocational training. The amount that is done now in the grades from four to six (not including the latter) is the usual Ontario hour a week. In the last three grades six seven and eight they have the system of a day in class and a days work. I need not go into the different trades poultry farming etc. If the new course were to take the boys out of their classes for many hours a week it would hardly seem feasible.

One solution offered by a member of the staff was that we should have a maintenance man who would teach at the same time. If such a man were willing to come under those conditions that is, do the regular required number of hours a week and teaching the matter assigned and then looking after repair work in electricity etc., then we would be able to bear the burden of the expense. This plan of course would depend on the number of hours required in the new course and of course on the Department's acceptance of such a plan. At any rate we shall most likely be forced by circumstances to hire such a man for maintenance. There are many difficulties in getting teachers.
especially qualified ones in that line. As for maintenance men, it will soon be possible to get a good man for the ordinary maintenance work at a fair rate. If this last suggestion should find approval then we can believe, get the person we want. Gerard "Sibley" came here before the war, and subsequently joined the R.C.A.F., did the full course of Technical training at one of the Vocational Institutes in Toronto, had part of his high school and the full five years of Tech School. He visited here just before your last letter and was waiting discharge but did not think of coming back here at all because we could not offer the wages that we should pay a man of his training (here I speak of an offer to hire him for maintenance).

This was the only plan suggested and it was agreed that we could not possibly stand the expense of hiring a teacher along with the Department as outlined in your letter.

Hoping that this makes the matter clear and waiting your answer as to the suggestion offered

Very truly yours,

(Rev) J.R.Oliver S.J.

With reference to your letter of the 17th instant, we are anxious to make an increased effort to encourage vocational work at some Residential Schools during the coming academic year. As you know, it has not been our policy in the past to pay any amount of the salary of teachers at Residential Schools but, as the result of a special appropriation that we have just obtained, we are now in a position to assist some Principals in obtaining a qualified Vocational Teacher.

We have communicated with some schools and if Vocational Teachers are secured, it is our intention to watch their work carefully with a view to providing such assistance at all Indian Residential Schools within the next year or so.

Before any Vocational Teacher is appointed, an application form is submitted to the Department in order that we may decide if the qualifications of the applicant are satisfactory. The Department would pay one-half of the salary provided the services of the teacher can be secured for $1,500 a year or less. Of course, the school management is expected to provide the other half of the salary, plus maintenance.

No doubt Mr. Doucet has called on you recently, as he is conducting a short course at Sandy Bay Residential School for certain Manual Training Teachers whose qualifications we consider are satisfactory. In conducting this course, Mr. Doucet is simply endeavouring to outline to these teachers the Department's policies and wishes regarding manual training work at Indian Residential Schools.
I have already been in touch by correspondence with the four Churches associated with us in Indian work, and have settled with them the schools at which we are prepared to grant assistance during the current academic year.

Some of them have been successful in obtaining teachers and others have not yet secured one. As soon as the teachers are definitely selected, you will be advised regarding the schools in Manitoba where such assistance is being given.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

During the course of the last few weeks, I have had the opportunity, either of visiting or of hearing from a number of our Indian Residential Schools. I am pleased to report that the craft and trades instruction program, such as it was outlined by yourself, has begun in a very satisfactory manner and that the boys' response seems to be quite in keeping with the hopes you founded on this venture.

I was pleased to note also that the teachers are cooperating with the instructors by insisting in the classroom on such topics as are related to the particular item of manual training actually under way. I take much pleasure in expressing my thanks to you for having brought about the realization of this plan and for having so liberally supplied the equipment required therefor, as well as for many other highly appreciated favors which it would be too long to enumerate at the present time.

FOREWORD.

Manual Training is a departure from the traditional forms of education. Very few teachers have had any opportunity to train in the technique required to teach subjects successfully. These Job Sheets have been prepared to help those Instructors who are endeavouring to carry on notwithstanding this great handicap. These are intended as guides. They will also provide Instructors with a clear objective.

A student analytical and record sheet is supplied. The pupil will select a project either from plans supplied or from other sources. He will have this project approved by the Instructor, who will make sure the article is not above the pupil's ability. The Instructor will then proceed to analyse the object to discover the operations required for its fabrication. This may be done in the presence of all the pupils, although each has chosen a different article. It will give practice in analysing from a sketch. After a check mark (v) is inserted in the first column, (Process required), opposite the operation necessary for the construction of the chosen project the student checks the other two columns. (At first this is done by all the students under the supervision of the Instructor).

These Record Sheets are handed in to the Instructor who files them in some manner easily accessible for himself and the students. By observing these complete records, the Instructor can easily notice which pupils require instruction on the same operation, (obviously these may be given simultaneous instruction). After the operation has been performed the Instructor grades, with a colored pencil, the operation by means of "A, B, C, D or E", as the case may be in the last column. The grading is then transferred by a pupil on the "Monthly Report" which is to be sent every month to Head Office.

A. Excellent
B. Good
C. Average
D. Fair
E. Unsatisfactory.

Each project is similarly analysed. A glance at the pupil's charts discloses repeated operations. An inferior grade for a repeated operation would probably indicate lack of application. In brief, this chart is in reality a record of pupil achievement.

The repair job sheet is self-explanatory.

No. 228
GENERAL PRINCIPLES.

A few preliminary lessons are required before starting the actual work. Shop rules and regulations should be thoroughly discussed. The pupils will understand the reasons for the regulations. They will be impressed with the importance of system and cleanliness. They will know the simple rules of prevention of accidents. Prevention and First Aid posters should be displayed in the workshop. Posters illustrating the tools and the various joints should also be posted.

The preliminary lessons should also include - How to Use a Hammer, How to Use a Hand Saw and How to Handle a Plane.

The selection of a project should be the next step taken by a student of woodwork. The project, of necessity, will be very simple. This project should be one which will furnish the desired training as well as prove interesting to the pupil.

Books of projects, drawings, current magazines, etc., should be a part of every shop library. Many publications are available free of charge: Government bureau of publications, manufacturers of woodworking tools, manufacturers of supplies of all kinds, etc. These companies are only too pleased to furnish publications and charts, which should prove beneficial to the students. Pupils should get good practice in writing themselves for these.
