Provision of power tools for the Schools of British Columbia.

You have recently requested that we clarify the whole situation insofar as the provision of power tools to Residential Schools of British Columbia is concerned. Therefore, in answer, we would like to point out the following general policy which will be followed by the Department in this regard:

1. MANUAL TRAINING TEACHERS

The Department will provide power tools for manual training shops where the teacher is fully qualified and holds the proper teaching certificates granted by the Department of Education of the Province of British Columbia. In all other cases, each individual instructor's qualifications will be carefully considered before approving expenditures for power equipment.

The grants to be made by the Department for the purchase of power tools will be based upon the attendance at the residential school concerned.

2. USE OF POWER TOOLS BY STUDENTS

It is understood that in the manual training shops of the junior and senior high schools of the Province of British Columbia, pupils use power operated machinery

........ only when in
only when in view of the instructor. It is most essential that a similar precaution be employed in our schools, especially in view of the fact that our manual training begins often at an earlier age for Indian boys than for boys in the provincial schools.

3. **INSPECTION OF SAFETY DEVICES**

It is understood that the workmen's Compensation Board of the Province of British Columbia will send one of their Inspectors to check the installation of these power tools and will be glad to give whatever advice is required in their operation. In all instances where residential schools have such equipment or are installing such equipment, this service of the workmen's Compensation Board should be used.

4. **SAFETY LITERATURE FROM THE WORKMEN'S COMPENSATION BOARD**

It is most essential that all such literature receive the fullest distribution throughout the manual training shops of our schools using power tools. These posters must be displayed in our manual training shops and the Inspector of schools will ensure that this is done. Indian agents should also check on this practice in their visits to our schools.

5. **SAFETY PRECAUTIONS REGARDING THE USE OF POWER TOOLS**

(a) Saws: It is now generally agreed by the various Directors of Technical Education for the Provincial Departments of Education that there are fewer accidents when power saws are used than with circular saws. In industry the band saw is more generally useful than a circular saw and is also less dangerous.

The band saw should at all times have a guard over it, leaving only the opening exposed where the actual sawing takes place. Boys should not stand at the side of a band saw.
5. (b) Planers: It is unlikely that an accident should occur when pupils are using this tool. However, care should be taken that the feed is not too heavy and that no one stands in front of the plane.

(c) Jointers: The most serious thing that is likely to happen in an accident using this tool is that 1/8" of the finger might be taken off, which would of course involve only the fleshy part. However, this would only happen in the case of gross carelessness.

The jointer should have a telescopic rear-guard as well as a standard swing-guard in the front so that at no time any portion of the knife is open other than that over which work is passing. When using short material, pupils should always use a push stick.

6. CONCLUSION

It is felt that if the principals of residential schools and Indian Agents are all made aware of the above precautions very few accidents should occur in our manual training shops. It is realized that this training in operating such machinery will be most valuable to our Indian students and will enable them to obtain better positions in the mills and factories of your province.

WILLOW CRAFT IN INDIAN SCHOOLS

The Welfare and Training Service, Indian Affairs Branch, is securing a supply of fine peeled willow, suitable for use in basket weaving—as well as a small supply of heavier grade willow for use in making basket bottoms.

In the past, many teachers have requested supplies of Reed and Raffia for handicraft purposes. As these supplies are not available, we wish to suggest the use of willow, which can be supplied in reasonable quantities.

On pages 43-45 of the publication "Arts and Crafts for Canadian Schools", by Louis A. Short, will be found directions and illustrations dealing with "reedcraft". Practically the same directions are applicable to the use of willow, but it must be mentioned that it is necessary to soak willow in water for at least 12 hours before using, and only the supplies to be used the next day should be soaked at one time.

If it is desired to split a willow wand, to secure flat strips for binding handles, etc., a simple tool can be made by sawing 2½ or 3 inches off the end of a broom handle (or by using a piece of hardwood of similar size, texture and shape). As it is difficult to describe the tool, an Indian worker has been requested to make a small supply, and one tool which can be copied will be sent to each school in which willow basket making is undertaken as part of the craft program.

When a supply of flat strips is needed, select a few thick willow wands, and with a sharp knife make three incisions (from one to two inches in length) in the heavy end of the wand—dividing it into three sections. The wooden tool to be used is also shaped in three sections. Insert the centre of the tool in the centre of the willow wand to be split, and ease it through the length of the wand, endeavouring to "feel" the fibre of the willow, and to steer the tool in such a way as to produce strips matching reasonably in width. With a little practice it is possible to secure in this way long flat strips of willow which are as pliable as the expensive bamboo strips formerly used by professional craft workers for binding handles.

Should schools interested in such a project send in a requisition on form I A 413 covering the following items:

(a) Willow (10 lbs. per residential and 5 lbs. per day school)
(b) One peeling wand
(c) One copy of "Arts and Crafts in Canadian Schools".

FOREWORD

LESSON PROCEDURE.

PREPARATION:

The pupil will read the "Reading Course" listed at the bottom of Job Sheet #1. This may be done at his study period, during free periods or at any other suitable time.

It may be wise to let the pupils, coming to the workshop for the first time, move freely about the room. They will examine the posters, the tools, the furniture; in one word they will familiarize themselves with the quarters assigned for this study.

At the proper time the Instructor will call the students to order; he will assign a place to each one; he will discuss with them, the "Shop Regulations". He will make sure that the pupils know the reasons for these regulations.

Shop responsibilities will then be assigned: Care of the tools; List of groups responsible for tidiness; Heating of the Shop, etc., A list of those responsible for the above will be posted at a convenient place and a standing, A, B or C recorded for the accomplishment of these tasks.

DEMONSTRATION:

In the presence of the pupils, the Instructor will dismantle a plane. A general discussion will follow: What is the purpose of this part? Why is it constructed in this manner? What would happen if it were constructed in such a manner? This discussion should last as long as the pupils show interest. The Instructor will then proceed to put the plane together, again seeking the reasons for such a procedure in preference to another.

STUDENT ACTIVITY:

The pupils, each at his work bench, dismantles his plane, afterwards putting it together. They will follow the Procedure indicated in Job Sheet #1.

NOTE:

It may readily be seen how easily the above could become a lesson in oral or written language. This is integration as recommended for Indian schools.

SECOND LESSON: The Hammer and the Saw.

The pupil will read:

a. Hand Woodworking p. 91 No. 128 and p. 47 to 56 Nos. 81 to 90.
b. Woodwork for Junior High Schools p. 16 and p. 14.
c. Instructional Units in Hand Woodwork p. 152 to 154 and p. 33 to 38.
1. The Hammer: Proper method of handling, its history, the simple scientific principles involved.

2. The Saw: Its use, the difference between the rip saw, the crosscut saw, the back saw, the panel saw. The methods of handling to secure a square cut.

SUBJECT ACTIVITY:

1. The Instructor will continually check to make sure the pupils form the correct habits in handling these tools.

2. Choice of Object:

It is of the greatest importance that the work of the pupils at this stage should be motivated. To learn joints in succession lacks interest. Joints should be learned as they are required. For this purpose the Instructor will have each pupil pick an object which he desires to make. This project may be selected from the set of sketches sent or from any other source. The Instructor might approach the subject in the following manner: - Here are some drawings and pictures of what you might choose an article you would like to make. These sketches will be placed in the shop hall so that you may look at them during your free time. On a piece of paper write your name, the name of the article you have chosen and the reason for your choice. Hand this paper to your teacher. I will get these papers and we will discuss the articles you have chosen, next time we meet in this shop.

The Instructor must prevent failures. It is important that the project chosen by the pupil be an article within his ability. He must be reasonably successful with his first article, otherwise all future interest may be lost. Should the Instructor judge the project presented by the pupil as too difficult he will suggest to him to make another choice. The former object may do for a second or third project. With the proper approach the pupil will be led to pick a suitable project. Besides avoiding the risk of ruining the pupil's future attempts, the Instructor will have led him on a reasoning process which is a definite part of his education.

After the various projects have been approved the analysis takes place. The purpose of this analysis is fourfold:

1. To teach the pupils to read and understand simple sketches.
2. To teach the pupils to recognize the construction process of the described project.
3. To discover the Basic Operations required for the manufacture of the project.
4. To help the Instructor to group his students.
The following example will illustrate the above points, (each pupil uses a separate analytical sheet for each project).

John Doe selects a project. Suppose he selected a Book Rack. (See Job Sheet #4). This project will require a knowledge of the following processes. (Numbers refer to Student Record Sheet).
1,2,4,5,6,7,8,9,10,11,14,15,16,19,21,29,31,35,38,50 and 51.

Adam Smith selected a Knife Box, (See Job Sheet #7). This project will require a knowledge of the following processes. (Numbers refer to Student Record Sheet).
1,2,4,5,6,7,8,9,10,11,14,15,16,19,21,28,31,34,37,38,50 and 51.

In both cases students have already learned the following. (Second Column "Process Learned" on "Student Record Sheet"). 1,2,4,5,6,7,8,9, and 11.

The students have to learn the processes checked in the third column on Students Record Sheet (Process to be learned). In each case they are:

John Doe - No. 10,14,15,16,19,22,29,31,35,38,50 and 51.

Adam Smith No.10,14,15,16,19,21,28,31,34,37,38,50 and 51.

After all the projects have been analysed, the instructor can readily organize his students and group those who have similar processes to learn. The "Student Record Sheets" are kept in a handy place and the processes checked off as they are learned. The check consists of A, B, or C standing as the quality of the work warrants. Each student should have a copy of his own and check his progress.

Notice that the student practices the process on scrap lumber not only to learn the process but because he needs that operation to construct his project. This motivation is essential to the pupil's progress.

AIRMAIL

Ottawa, April 3, 1946.

Mr. J.F.B. Ostrander, Inspector of Indian Agencies,
414 Federal Building, Regina, Sask.

I have your letter of the 30th ultimo, with reference to the proposed establishment of a Technical School at North Battleford.

I discussed your letter with the Director this afternoon. I note, from the fourth paragraph of your letter, you recognize the fact that if the proposal contained in your communication were followed, it would mean the establishment of another residential school, because we would have to provide adequate living accommodation for the Indian children who would attend the technical school.

We have been in communication recently with all the Churches operating residential schools and have offered to pay one half the salary of a qualified manual training teacher, to a maximum of $750.00 a year. For instance, if the salary paid by any residential school to the manual training teacher was $1,500.00 or less, we would pay one half the salary and the school management would pay the other half and provide living accommodation. Several schools have already taken advantage of our offer and others have written to us, expressing appreciation of the offer but regretting that they cannot accept it at the present time, due to the difficulty of obtaining qualified manual training teachers. If more schools take advantage of the present offer, we hope, in a year or so, to be in a position to pay the full salary of the manual training teacher. In addition, we are prepared to provide the equipment that we consider necessary and to make payment for the material required. We feel that our program would be more effective than to take part in the proposed technical school. I would appreciate hearing further from you when you have had an opportunity of considering this letter.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I have been informed by the Superintendent of Schools of the Department of Education in the Battleford area that some of the buildings of the Air Training Centre at North Battleford are being taken over by the Department of Education for the purpose of establishing a technical school.

The Superintendent of Schools, Mr. C. Innis, informed me that he had been asked by his Department to enquire as to the possibility that our Branch would wish to co-operate with the Provincial Department of Education with a view to having a number of Indians attend this school.

It would be necessary to provide living accommodation for the Indians near the school and some of the buildings are being held for our Branch. These buildings were first spoken for in the hope that they could be used to establish a hospital and are still available.

I realize, of course, that a residential technical school would be no small matter for us to undertake but it would appear that a move should be made in that direction to provide some useful training for young Indians who do not intend to become farmers.

Mr. Innis asked to be informed as soon as possible whether there is any probability that our Branch will co-operate in this connection. If it is decided to co-operate in the near future, arrangements should be made, as soon as possible, to take over as many buildings as would be necessary. I believe we could have as many as we wish and this is a matter for a more detailed report if considered advisable and I am so instructed.

J.F.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Manual Training Buildings Required at Some Residential Schools.

At any residential school where there is a building that can be converted and used for manual training purposes, we are making necessary changes at the lowest possible cost. This avoids the erection of a new building at the present time.

However, there are some schools at which no building is available for reconversion and, consequently, it is absolutely essential to provide a new building in order that manual training may be properly taught.

Mr. Doucet has drafted a plan of a manual training building that will meet our requirements for the next few years. The approximate cost of material and labour for this building will not exceed $5,000.

In order to carry out our manual training programme during the fiscal year 1947-48, it will be necessary to erect at five different residential schools, one of the type of building mentioned above.

We would, therefore, appreciate the authority of the Minister to include an item of $25,000 in the supplementary estimates, 1947-48, for the purpose mentioned above.

Director.
Superintendent of Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Attention of Mr. Doucet

Re: Indian Exhibit for the Calgary & Edmonton Fairs

In compiling the classes for exhibits of pupils at schools, they fall into three definite groups:

1. Classroom
2. Sewing
3. Cooking & Manual Training

It has been our experience that there is a good representation in all but manual training as laid down in the course of study. The manual training exhibits, which come under your general supervision, are not the sort of stuff that really demonstrates that the boy is learning his craft. Furthermore, it is generally some fragile or more or less useless article, that is very difficult to transport.

I do not know how to classify it, but it seems that the boys, who do carpentry or metal work, should exhibit that which they have been taught to do throughout the year. Could you give any suggested articles or pieces of work that should be exhibited, eliminating, as far as possible, such fragile articles as miniature hayracks, sleighs and oxcarts, which have been very much exhibited in the past?

I am attaching hereto list of classes for the Calgary Stampede 1946. We are trying to remodel it and include something more of general value, adding farm produce, preserving and canning for adults.

Any suggestions and any comments, that can be given by yourself and others in charge of Welfare and Training, will be very much appreciated.

G. H. Gooderham,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,

I have taken careful cognizance of your letter of March 14th.

I wish to pass on some remarks which I heard while visiting schools. I had intended taking these up before but time seems to be a great determining factor. The teachers complain that they are not given the objects required for exhibition purposes until late in the year. This, apparently forces them to devote more time at a certain period of the year. In other words, it becomes a drive for exhibition purposes until the exhibition should be a display of the actual work done during the year. We are wondering if anything can be done about the complaints or whether the complaints are justified.

Dear Colonel Neary:

I have been hoping that you would have had some word from Mr. Doucet as to the woodworking book. The most important point to be decided is, of course, whether you wish the Stock Bills and Record Sheets to be separate or whether you like my suggestion to have them bound in the book but on perforated sheets so that they may be torn out.

For technical reasons in manufacturing the books, we should require to have either 16 or 32 pages perforated, but these could be either Stock Bills or Record Sheets. With this letter I am sending you the manuscript as revised by our editor. The editorial work has consisted chiefly of laying the manuscript out page by page, with suitable spacing left for the illustrations. We shall, of course, want Mr. Doucet to read the edited manuscript with the utmost care. You will see that the manuscript is laid out to occupy 31 pages. We can either insert another page somewhere, or else leave page 32 blank, and then give you 32 pages—that is, 16 sheets of paper with a Record Sheet printed on one side and a Stock Bill on the other side. Since there are twelve jobs in the book, you will see that this would leave a small margin to allow for the inevitable spoilings of one or two sheets by the student. These last 16 sheets (32 pages) are the ones which would be perforated.

You will note that I say the present manuscript runs to 31 pages, which would allow us to add another page. However, if an additional page is to be inserted, it should be done with some care. For example, pages 6 and 7 must face each other because the illustrations on page 6 relate to the job on page 7. By the same token, page 2 should properly face page 3 because there are cross references. It would appear that if an additional page is to be added, it should be towards the end of the manuscript. We are all ready to go ahead with the composition and manufacture of this book just as soon as we get clearance from you.

We are laying out the second book in much the same way and hope to send it out to you for examination in the next two or three days. We have a number of minor questions to ask Mr. Doucet. These questions are on a separate sheet with the manuscript. Perhaps Mr. Doucet would answer them in the spaces provided on the sheet. We have provided a duplicate copy of this for his file.

Dear Colonel Neary:

This letter follows the discussion which we had today regarding the format of the wood-work job sheets which Mr. Doucet sent to us. Since he is out of town, I am following your suggestion and writing to you about this.

We have given quite a lot of consideration to the format and, as I explained, have two alternative ideas.

In the first, the sheets would be bound together at the top of the page and reinforced there with a cloth strip. In the second plan, the sheets would be printed on stout paper and inserted in a manilla envelope which would bear suitable printing indicating the content. I am having dummy copies of both of these formats prepared and hope to be able to send them to you tomorrow.

Following the first suggestion of binding the books at the top, we estimate the cost at approximately 55¢ for the larger book and approximately 35¢ for the smaller. The second style, using the envelope, would be quite a bit cheaper than this.

I hardly need to assure you that these prices contemplate giving you a first-class job with an attractive page printed in a good, legible type. The size of the page is something to be considered. I am thinking of a page of approximately 8½ x 11 with a ruled border of a single line all around the page, and the type and illustrations set inside this border. This is slightly wasteful as regards space, but I am trying to make these look something like the job sheets which a youngster would actually use in industry. However, I shall not be offended if you tell me that I am altogether wrong in this, because perhaps very few of the Indian children who use these sheets will ever be employed in industry.

If you will indicate the format which you prefer and the size which you think the pages should be, we will then have some specimen pages put in type and submit these to you for your approval. I have thought of setting the actual job sheets in imitation typewriter type with the headings, et cetera, in a bolder;
perfectly plain type which would harmonize. Here again, my point is to simulate somewhat the actual sheets which an industrial worker would have.

Mr. Doucet, in his letter, indicated that you are running short of the mimeographed copies of these job sheets and that you will either have to re-mimeograph them or have finished books quickly. I find that we can put this work in hand for you quite promptly as soon as you give us the go-ahead signal. I shall be quite happy to go to Ottawa and discuss the matter further with you, or, what might be better still, would be to have Mr. Doucet, if he has any business in Toronto, visit us here where we have all our samples of paper, type, and so on, readily available.

It was a great pleasure seeing you today and I was glad you were able to have lunch with us.

Cordially yours,

[Signature]

MEMORANDUM TO THE COMMISSIONER

Re: Kuper Island Residential School,
Manual Training Instructor

I refer to the letter of Superintendent Moore, dated August 2nd, concerning the above-mentioned school.

It will be noted that Mr. Moore has suggested a salary grant of $125.00 per month for this purpose. It seems rather large, considering the fact that the enrolment at this school is only 100 pupils and that probably not more than six to ten hours of the Instructor's time would be taken up with manual training classes. It is assumed that the remainder of his time would be occupied in doing maintenance work and other duties about the school which would normally be borne by the per capita grant.

From time to time, requests for increases in the grants towards manual training instructors' salaries pass through this office, and I believe that the time has come for a definite policy to be established with respect to the amount of the grant which would be paid by the Department for this purpose.

I suggest, therefore, that a schedule of grants should be drawn up in the light of the factors of school enrolment and the instructors' qualifications. I would also suggest a maximum grant of $100.00 per month be set for schools having an enrolment of 100 or less. At schools where the enrolment is over 225, the grant...
should be paid on the basis of the instructors' qualifications and in accordance with the salary schedule already in use for our Day Schools.

In the case of the Kuper Island Residential School, I am prepared to recommend a grant of $100.00, providing the instructor is suitably qualified.

R. F. Davey
District Inspector of Indian Schools.

SCHEDULE OF SALARIES FOR MANUAL TRAINING INSTRUCTORS
IN BRITISH COLUMBIA

Grade I $75.00 per teaching month for ten months.
While this group need not be certificated, the Department expects these teachers to be practical men with experience as skilled laborers. They should also be able to handle young people.

Grade II $100.00 per month for ten months.
While this group need not be certificated, teachers applying for this grade must have followed courses for the teaching of Manual Training at some school satisfactory to the Department. They should have practical experience and should be able to handle young people in the shop as well as on the playground.

Grade III $150.00 per month for ten months.
The teachers in this group should hold a Manual Training certificate issued by a school acceptable to the Department. They should also be able to handle young people in the shop and on the playground.

It will be noted that the Department desires more organized play in its Residential Schools. Some schools have this activity well organized already, others are sadly lax in this respect. The Department strongly disapproves the method of allowing the children to roam around during their spare time with nothing definite to do. The reason for this is obvious.

The school is expected, as its contribution towards this training, to furnish board and lodging.

The school must follow the programme outlined by the Department and furnish the Indian Affairs Branch with a schedule of the time allotted to this training.
A monthly voucher for the payment of the Instructor should be submitted through the office of the Superintendent of the Indian Agency. This voucher should be accompanied by a monthly report on the training accomplished. No salary will be paid unless this regulation is adhered to.

DEVELOP INTEREST FOR BETTER RESULTS

Preparing three meals a day, every day, can be a monotonous job for children, especially if they have had no part in planning the meals. Without interest the girls do not do their work well nor will they be interested in repeating the work in their homes later. So that the girls may get the most out of their training in the kitchen you must present meal preparation as a whole.

It is much easier for us to plan a menu and tell each girl her duties but that is not the purpose of kitchen training. She might never realize that she would have to combine all these duties to prepare meals in her own home. Only with practice and assistance from us is the girl going to be able to adapt her training to her specific home conditions. If we take time to train the girls to plan the menus and work out the duties of others, she will see meal preparation as a whole. This can be done by having the senior girl as kitchen supervisor for a period of two weeks or longer. During this time she would prepare the menus with your assistance and develop a work plan for the other kitchen workers. So that this duty would not prove too strenuous or foreign to them, and at the same time develop an interest, it is advisable to take each day's menu as planned and discussed with the group. Explain the good and bad points of it and why it is necessary to serve certain foods. The girls will show eagerness to learn and it will give them a background for preparing meals when they return home.

Often any deviation from our present method of operating our kitchens seems too much. However, if we look at the future we will see where a little extra effort today might improve the method of our kitchen operation tomorrow, send the girls out to their homes better equipped, and ease the burden on our own shoulders.

Memorandum:

SUPERINTENDENT OF EDUCATION

Report on Vocational Education

RESIDENTIAL SCHOOLS

For many years Manual Training in Residential Schools had been carried on mostly as a time-consuming activity, with little thought being devoted to its educational possibilities. Playrooms in these schools were generally very inadequate as far as size and equipment, but children after classroom periods had to be kept busy. To do this girls were taught to do knitting and fancy work and boys were given coping saws to make toys and bird houses. Some of the older girls were needed for laundry, housekeeping, kitchen work and to mend the younger children's clothes. The older boys were needed for repair work, to assist with the dairy activities or to perform other farm operations. As many of these chores were done through necessity, in general very little educational value was obtained from them.

In order to obtain educational value from the various activities to which the student must participate a method of awards was introduced. This is known as the "proficiency badge system". A badge is provided for eleven activities; see Appendix A. A definite number of the basic operations are required to earn these badges. (Appendix A1) In order to encourage the pupils of various ages and abilities the badges are divided into three steps referred to as first, second and third year. Pupils who become proficient in these basic operations and earn a sufficient number of badges are awarded a silver brooch or class pin.

The philosophy behind these awards is to make every activity of the child meaningful and at the same time a part of the educational process. Every activity of the child in residence should have an educational value. This system was received with a great deal of enthusiasm at the beginning and is still operating in a commendable manner. However, the lack of supervision and encouragement has prevented this system from bearing as much fruit as could have been expected. It is gratifying however to note the number of badges that have been awarded. A total of 7,648 badges have been distributed to date. This may be broken up in the following manner:

|                | Girls | Boys | Total |
|----------------|-------|------|-------|
| First Year     | 4113  | 977  | 5090  |
| Second Year    | 1750  | 332  | 2082  |
| Third Year     | 337   | 11   | 348   |
| Class Pin      | 122   | 6    | 128   |
| TOTAL          | 6322  | 1326 | 7648  |

The above figures mean that approximately 5000 pupils have learned basic operations which they will find very useful in life. The above figures include both residential and day schools.
In order to encourage the teaching of this subject in residential schools a special grant towards the payment of the salary is awarded by the Indian Affairs Branch. (Appendix B.) The Department purchases the equipment necessary for this instruction besides allowing a special grant for the purchase of the expendable material. These grants depend on the enrolment for the courses.

DAY SCHOOLS

The encouragement of Manual Training activities in day schools has been a difficult problem due to the fact that a teacher in a one-room school has so much to do that her efforts have to be restricted primarily to academic subjects. Moreover there are two groups to be handled - the girls and the boys. It is obvious that one teacher cannot handle the girls for sewing and the boys for woodwork at the same time. At some schools the wife of the teacher has taken charge of the girls when the teacher took the boys but there are not very many of these combinations. However, in many rooms where the teacher is familiar with the activity or project method of teaching, he has been able to teach many simple basic operations that should prove useful.

At our larger day schools it has been possible to provide a teacher who devotes his entire efforts to the teaching of Manual Training and another to the teaching of Domestic Science. It has been rather difficult to obtain Manual Training teachers. Teachers who have taken this training are quite scarce.

At the end of this report self-explanatory tables are appended in order to give a more complete picture of these activities. It must be remembered, however, that many schools are making a good attempt at teaching this subject but who do not submit regular reports. The activity is due mostly to the enthusiasm and devotedness of the teacher, as the Department does not allow any special remuneration to these.

In order to help our Manual Training teachers, especially those who have not had an opportunity of receiving training for this form of education, we have prepared lessons that have been edited and bound in books entitled "First Year Woodwork" and "Second Year Woodwork". "Third Year Woodwork" which completes this subject is being prepared. Lessons have also been prepared for first and second year metalwork and for mechanical drawing. Teachers who have used these helps have expressed great satisfaction for them. These booklets are distributed on requisition and it is expected that each child taking the course will have a copy.

The teaching of Manual Training has been affected greatly by the following:

(1) The impossibility of obtaining fully qualified teachers. However, to encourage this training the Department has divided residential school teachers into three classifications Grades I, II and III. (See Appendix C.)

It has been possible to obtain several fully qualified Manual Training teachers in our Day schools who come under the classification of teacher, Grade IV.
(2) The lack of teaching accommodation.

Many of the residential schools had but small shops that were sufficient for repair purposes but were very inadequate for instructional purposes. Many of these schools have been given plans and financial help to enlarge and remodel these shops. Other schools were provided with a small grant to build a shop. In order that this teaching may expand, more shops will have to be provided. The inclusion of these activities in our schools has been one of the factors that has led to a change of spirit among the students in the school and made the school a happier place where children find greater contentment and satisfaction, thereby causing the truancy problem to rapidly disappear.

Respectfully submitted,

A.J. Doucet,
Supervisor of Vocational Training.

PROCEDURE:

1. Frame the facsimile of the badges and hang one in the boys' quarters and one in the girls' quarters.
2. Post the "Basic Operations Required to Obtain Proficiency Badges" near the facilities.
3. Post the "Student Record of Mastered Basic Operations" in a place readily accessible to the students, preferably the class room. Each pupil should rule a sheet for his own record. (See "Student Record Sheet" for woodwork). At a definite period, once or twice a week, each pupil calls out his standing: Badge No., Basic Operation No. and standing A, B or C. The teacher enters these on the class student record. The teacher should take advantage of this period for a general discussion.

The eleven badges so far provided do not comprise all the training that may be given to Indian children. Badges may be added from time to time. Comments and suggestions from principals and teachers will be appreciated.

SCHEDULE OF SALARIES FOR MANUAL TRAINING INSTRUCTORS

Grade I $75.00 per teaching month for ten months.
While this group need not be certificated, the Department expects these teachers to be practical men with experience as skilled laborers. They should also be able to handle young people.

Grade II $100.00 per month for ten months.
While this group need not be certificated, teachers applying for this grade must have followed courses for the teaching of Manual Training at some school satisfactory to the Department. They should have practical experience and should be able to handle young people, in the shop as well as on the playground.

Grade III $150.00 per month for ten months.
The teachers in this group should hold a Manual Training certificate issued by a school acceptable to the Department. They should also be able to handle young people in the shop and on the playground.

It will noted that the Department desires more organized play in its Residential Schools. Some schools have this activity well organized already, others are sadly lax in this respect. The Department strongly disapproves the method allowing the children to roam around during their spare time with nothing definite to do. The reason for this is obvious.

The school is expected, as its contribution towards this training, to furnish board and lodging and any additional salary above amount allowed by Department.

The school must follow the programme outlined by the Department, and furnish the Indian Affairs Branch with a schedule of the time allotted to this training.

A monthly voucher for the payment of the Instructor should be submitted through the office of the Superintendent of the Indian Agency. This voucher should be accompanied by a monthly report on the training accomplished. No salary will be paid unless this regulation is adhered to.

Bernard F. Neary,

Dear Mr. Doucet -

We are pleased that by your letter of November 4th you have requested one of our Handicraft catalogues — this went forward under separate cover and you will undoubtedly have received it prior to this letter.

We hope to make our handicraft catalogue as explicit as possible for those who wish to order from it. We do feel however, that in your particular case, we would like to make some special remarks regarding the services which we are prepared to offer to the Department of Mines and Resources.

While we have not to date been privileged to supply the Department of Mines and Resources in many parts of Canada, considerable handicraft supply material has gone out to the Northern parts of B.C., and into the Yukon and from reports by the Vocational teachers in these outposts, our services have been much appreciated.

Realizing that the Department of Indian Affairs is extensive and that should a broad policy of introduction of handicrafts into different outposts be considered, the business resulting would be valuable and we are most anxious to prove our worthiness of your support!

If you will be so kind as to leaf through our catalogue you will note that under "Bedford Services" we offer to handicraft groups, schools and hospitals, the privilege of sending to us for displays of made-up articles to be used both for inspiration for them on the verge of taking up handicraft work and to be used also as models from which to work. Where a 16 Millimeter projector is available our film The Art of Leather Carving will be sent out on loan to those interested. It would be only fair to say that in regards to this film, the demand for it is great, and requests for loan of it should be made well in advance of its showing.

....../2

AIRMAIL
We offer also a Craft Consultant service whereby an instructor in a school or hospital may write to us for any information pertinent to the handicrafts which we carry. We will send a bulletin on the organization of handicraft groups and clubs. All orders by your Department will be subject to a 10% courtesy deduction.

So much for the services — some other particular features which might be of genuine interest especially to those with little previous experience in Leathercraft, is our Project Kits shown on pages 12 to 16. These Project Kits represent a tremendous saving in time, in bookkeeping and since they contain patterns, designs and all requisite material, they are in a sense a Leathercraft instruction course in themselves.

Our leathers, tools, fittings and all materials requisit to carrying on Leathercraft work are of the very finest! We consider quality the prime requisit to the building of our handicraft service, equalled by none in Canada!

With these few words of introduction beyond the actual catalogue forwarded to you, the writer hopes that you will consider us seriously as a source of supply for your different outposts and we will be more than pleased to forward upon request, catalogues wherever you might suggest. We are here to be of service to you. May we help you?

DESCRIPTION OF HINGE
Read This Carefully---It is Important

NO Chain is stronger than its weakest link. Also the life of a school desk cannot be greater than the life of the hinge. In the development of the New Globe Automatic our energy was directed toward the elimination of faults in the Hinge.

OUR SUCCESS IS COMPLETE

We sincerely believe that the Hinge in the New Automatic is the strongest Automatic Seat Hinge ever invented and comes nearer to being noiseless than any other now on the market.

Absolute noiselessness can only be secured by the use of rubber or leather buffers, or springs and when such parts are used it is only a question of time till they become worn or dislodged and must then be replaced or the desk is too noisy for further use.

Those who have had experience in getting repairs for school desks know how difficult and unsatisfactory it is, and, therefore, the desk that will wear the longest without needing repairs is the most valuable one to the school.

There are fewer parts in the Hinge of the New Globe than are found in any other School Desk Hinge on the market. This alone reduces the possibility of its getting out of order.

It does not depend on lumps or rubber, leather or other material, nor on springs of any kind for its noiseless action.

The steel balls used in the Hinge are one-half inch in diameter, being twice as large as those used by any other manufacturer, thus giving greater wear resisting qualities.

The balls in the Hinge of the New Globe ARE NOT held in position by means of springs, because when such is the case the spring will in time lose its tension allowing the balls to get out of their proper position, or drop out entirely.

In the Hinge of the New Globe the steel balls absorb the friction and bear no wearing contact of iron against iron. In every other so-called Ball Bearing Desk there is a wearing contact of iron against iron.

The accompanying illustration, Fig. 1, will give you a fairly accurate understanding of the great simplicity of the Hinge and also show you that "P" is the Seat Arm. "B" shows a portion of the Desk Leg or Casting. When the Seat Arm is in its place, the Ball "P" fits into the socket "Q." The Shoulder "R" on "A" rests in Groove "S" on "B" when the seat is raised or lowered. Ball "P" runs in socket "R" and runs along the inside of the Casting "B" at "S," between "J" and "K." The Casting grows gradually thicker as it nears the point "K," so that the Ball runs less easily as it approaches the lower end. This brings the seat to a gradual stop without jar or noise. When the seat is lowered the ball rolls towards "J," where the casting is also thicker. The seat comes to a gradual stop in the same way and for the same reason as when it is raised.

The office of the Bolt "F" and the Cap "D" is merely to hold the parts together. The bolt passes through the Seat Arm "A" in Slot "G" and through Casting "B" at "H." The notch "E" Casting "D," is placed over the Slot "G" on "B" to prevent "D's" turning with the Seat Arm.

The Lugs "L," "M" and "N" prevent the Seat from raising or lowering beyond the proper position and also carry a part of the weight of the pupil, thus relieving the working parts of some of the strain.

DESCRIPTION OF HINGE

Read This Carefully---It is Important

No chain is stronger than its weakest link. Also the life of a school desk cannot be greater than the life of the hinge. In the development of the New Globe Automatic our energy was directed toward the elimination of faults in the hinge.

OUR SUCCESS IS COMPLETE

We sincerely believe that the Hinge in the New Automatic is the strongest Automatic Seat Hinge ever invented and comes nearer to being noiseless than any other now on the market.

Absolute noiselessness can only be secured by the use of rubber or leather buffers, or springs and when such parts are used it is only a question of time till they become worn or dislodged and must then be replaced or the desk is too noisy for further use.

Those who have had experience in getting repairs for school desks know how difficult and unsatisfactory it is, and, therefore, the desk that will wear the longest without needing repairs is the most valuable one to the school.

There are fewer parts in the Hinge of the New Globe than are found in any other School Desk Hinge on the market. This alone reduces the possibility of its getting out of order.

It does not depend on bumpers or rubber, leather or other material, nor on springs of any kind for its noiseless action.

The steel balls used in the Hinge are one-half inch in diameter, being twice as large as those used by any other manufacturer, thus giving greater wear resisting qualities.

The balls in the Hinge of the New Globe ARE NOT held in position by means of springs, because when such is the case the spring will in time lose its tension allowing the balls to get out of their proper position, or drop out entirely.

In the Hinge of the New Globe the steel balls absorb all friction, there being no wearing contact of iron against iron. In every other so-called Ball Bearing Desk there is a wearing contact of iron against iron.

The accompanying illustration, Fig. 1, will give you a full and complete understanding of the simplicity of the Hinge, and you will note that "A" is the Seat Arm; "B" shows a portion of the Desk Leg or Casting. When the Seat Arm is in its place, the Ball "I" runs into the Seat "O," and the Ball "K" on "A" moves in Groove "S" on "B," when the seat is raised or lowered. Ball "I" rests in Socket in "R," and runs along the inside of the Casting "B" at "G," between the Lugs "M" and "N." The Casting gradually thickens as it nears the point "K," so that the Ball runs less easily as it reaches the end of its course. This brings the seat to a gradual stop without jar or noise. When the seat is lowered the ball rolls towards "J" where the casting is also thicker. The seat comes to a gradual stop in the same way and for the same reason as when it is raised.

The office of the Bolt "F" and the Cap "D" is merely to hold the parts together. The bolt passes through the Seat "O," the Seat "G" and through Casting "B" at "H." The notch "I" in Casting "D" is placed over the Lug "C" on "B" to prevent "D's" turning with the Seat Arm.

The Lugs "I," "M" and "N" prevent the Seat from raising or lowering beyond the proper position and also carry a part of the weight of the pupil, thus relieving the working parts of some of the strain.

Sir,

I have to inform you that the Purchasing Commission of Canada has recently ruled that requisitions in future for all purchases exceeding $100.00 are to be submitted to it before action is taken, except in emergency cases when time will not permit of doing so. Such cases, however, should be rare, as generally, requirements can and should be foreseen, and the regulations complied with. When such purchases have to be made all possible competition should be obtained and full records kept of those who were asked to quote; also their replies. This information together with a proper description of articles on which prices were obtained to be submitted with the accounts.

It must be understood that Canadian made goods are to be purchased where possible and the lowest tenders are to be accepted. When the lowest tender is not accepted, a full explanation should be made.

When a requisition is referred to the Department for authority to purchase and a list of names from whom to call for tenders, a full description of the article or goods required should be given, and if possible, a catalogue reference as a guide to those tendering. Requisitions should always give the name of the nearest City, Town, or Village, to the Reserve where it is proposed making the purchases.

An abstract, in duplicate, of all Tenders received should accompany all accounts.

These regulations will not apply to authorized purchases, the account for which does not exceed $100.00, which may be made without further reference to the Department, after obtaining competitive prices, but to such an account an abstract in duplicate of the tenders received should be attached for the information of the Purchasing Commission, to whom all accounts for are submitted before payment can be made.

Competitive prices need not be obtained for purchases the value of which do not exceed $15.00 but the account should bear a certificate to the effect that the purchases have been made to the best possible advantage and that the prices are fair and reasonable. It is the desire of the Purchasing Commission that this business shall be divided as much as possible and when there is more than one store in the Town where the purchases are made. That is meant by this is, that should you be purchase one week at a certain store in the Town where you do business, the next purchase should be made at another store, if the goods can be purchased to advantage. In this way the Government business will be equally divided amongst interested Merchants throughout the year. The accounts for these as well as all other purchases should be forwarded in duplicates, direct to the Department monthly, and not allowed to accumulate for months.

Purchases of Live Stock and Seed Grain are exempt from these regulations; also purchases of Beef, Hay, and Food, when made from Indians.

These
These regulations cover all purchases made by any officials of the Department whether on behalf of the Department or for Indians and irrespective of the Fund from which payment is to be made.

You are therefore required to carefully observe these regulations and acknowledge receipt of this letter.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLean
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

The Prince of Wales Technical Benches are built with heavy angle iron legs rivetted and bolted together, making them thoroughly rigid and practically indestructible.

TOPS - The tops are made from clear maple, and are assembled with the Linderman joint, which makes the top about as strong as a solid piece of wood. A series of six square holes are provided for a wooden plug for use in connection with the wooden plug in the vise. A handy tool rack is also provided at the rear face of the bench. This rack has five holes for chisels, files, square, etc., and one square hole for marking gauge, one oblong hole for the saw. The drop board at the back, which is fastened in place with bolts acts as a shield (Safety first) to protect the worker at the bench ahead from injury on the edge tools. The well in the rear section is edged with bevel strips so as to enable the worker to clean shavings away quickly. Not a screw or bolt head is visible on the bench tops, which prevents injury to the tools.

VISES - Two vises are mounted on each bench. These vises have a double pitch screw and one complete turn of the handle moves the jaws one half inch. These vises are made from iron, the iron jaws being dropped 1/4" from the top of the bench.

Gentlemen:

I have been directed to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 16th instant, enclosing a folder illustrating the manual training bench manufactured by your firm, and requesting that you be given an opportunity to quote on our requirements for these benches for the use of Indian schools.

In reply I beg to say that we use very little of this equipment, but, should any manual training benches be required in the future, your firm will be given an opportunity to furnish a quotation for supplying the same.

Your obedient servant,
